name: GenerateHope
content: There are a lot of misconceptions about sex trafficking. The first step to making a difference in our local community is education. There are many reasons women are unable to leave their current situation. It’s important to understand how manipulation and coercion play a big role in victimization. Share this post to start the conversation in your circle and educate your friends!

name: GenerateHope
content: It’s not too late to take a stand with the “Ending Trafficking is Within Reach” Pledge, a commitment to EDUCATE, EMPOWER, and SUPPORT the fight to combat human trafficking in San Diego. Click here to take the pledge today >> bit.ly/Pledge2EndTrafficking

name: GenerateHope
content: Hard conversations are better than hard lessons. Having conversations with children about internet safety can prevent online exploitation. Swipe through to read some resources we are re-sharing from @sandiegotpc about good questions to ask your kids, red flags to pay attention to, and recommendations for how to practice internet safety.

name: GenerateHope
content: Do you know the #redflags of online grooming? ⁠ ⁠ The pandemic has made it a vulnerable time to be online because predators are using this as an opportunity to entice unsupervised children into producing sexually explicit material. A predator may often develop rapport through compliments, discussing shared interests or “liking” a child’s online post - also known as grooming. This can lead to sending/sharing inappropriate images, engaging in sexual conversation, and ultimately exploitation.⁠ ⁠ Pay attention: it’s a red flag if your child or teen suddenly becomes involved in a relationship which seems “too close” with someone they know solely on social media or online.⁠

name: GenerateHope
content: Practice Internet Safety | As part of Human Trafficking Awareness Month, we think it is imperative to discuss the ways sex trafficking most commonly impacts our youth: via the internet. Online enticement, or 'grooming', is a common way that traffickers will connect with youth, lure them into a relationship, and take advantage of them. GenerateHope, in collaboration with the REACH Coalition, will be sharing more resources about internet safety over the next few days.⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠... .⁠ .⁠ #humantrafficking #nonprofit #endit #childtrafficking #education #stoptrafficking #antitrafficking #enditmovement #sextraffickingawareness #sextrafficking #traffickingawareness #community #charity #donate⁠

name: GenerateHope
content: ✨We have an exciting update!✨  We are happy to announce that a woman is  graduating from our Recovery Program! She has put in a lot of hard work, time, and intentionality into her program and we are so proud of her accomplishments. She will be starting college classes in the coming month. We are excited to see where her future will take her. We are looking forward to many more women following in her footsteps. .⁠ .⁠ .⁠... .⁠ .⁠ #humantrafficking #nonprofit #endit #childtrafficking #education #stoptrafficking #antitrafficking #enditmovement #sextraffickingawareness #sextrafficking #traffickingawareness #community #charity #donate⁠

name: GenerateHope
content: GenerateHope staff are committed to being a part of the generation that works to END human trafficking!  Today is #nationalhumantraffickingawarenessday and here are some great ways to take action:  - Donate your time or money to the work being done at GenerateHope - Pledge to having a conversation with someone (friend, family member, colleague, etc.) about the reality of human trafficking  - Commit to educating yourself and learning more. Check out this compilation of resources we put together with our partner Dear Survivor: https://dear-survivor.com/pages/how-to-help

name: GenerateHope
content: ❗️Today is National Human Trafficking Awareness Day❗️ ⁠ This is a big issue in our own community because there are 3,000 - 8,000 estimated trafficking victims in San Diego during the year. Sex Trafficking brings in an estimated $810 Million in annual revenue from the underground commercial sex economy in San Diego alone. GenerateHope works towards helping survivors in our program to achieve their goals, get an education, and leave a life of exploitation for good.   Today we want to pledge our support to end human trafficking. Help us educate our neighbors on this critical issue by sharing this post & starting the conversation in your own community!

name: GenerateHope
content: Have you ever considered the meaning of 'hope'? ⁠ ⁠✨⁠ It's both a noun and a verb - a thing you can have and an action you can choose. As a verb, hope is to "expect with confidence" or "to cherish a desire with anticipation".⁠ ⁠✨⁠ Every time you support GenerateHope, you are tangibly providing hope to women who feel as though they have lost it all. They've come to the end of their rope and have no where else to turn. We provide holistic services to ensure survivors know where... their future is headed. One of the survivors in our Transition Program said it best when she said, "I have the ability to dream again".⁠ ⁠ Hope changes lives. We are hopeful and eager for the future, and grateful for all you have done this year! Happy New Year!

name: The Genesis Project Seattle
content: Here are some January updates and accomplishments that we have been able to celebrate at the center this month!  • The Genesis Project was able to transport and support a client at their court hearing.  • We have assisted multiple survivors in filing protection orders against their abusers to keep them safe during this quarantine.  • Many survivors have been able to enjoy a warm meal here at the center thanks to our wonderful volunteers. ... • Genesis Project staff has been able to utilize zoom to assist clients in crisis.  • A very hardworking and determined survivor is one exam away from completing her GED! • Several clients have been able to use our facility to do laundry and receive hygiene products.  • Many clients have been able to use our center laptops to zoom into court comfortably and with a support system around them.  • A new virtual support group was started this month to help survivors who may be dealing with loneliness or isolation.  Thank you to all our donors and supporters for joining in the fight against human trafficking and sexual exploitation! We would not be able to serve these women without you. If you would like to financially support our organization, visit our website at https://www.genesisnow.org/take-action/donate to aid in the fight!

name: The Genesis Project Seattle
content: →A testimony from a client I want to start off by saying thank you and may God bless you all. I have started all in a small building that you all provided a safe place. A place to sleep and eat. Truth, Honesty, and most importantly...my recovery! I am here now at my new program writing how thankful I am to meet you. Without your guys’ help, I wouldn’t have got here to change and accept it...I have been in this facility 2 days shy of a week. I did y’all on my own–by myself and... God, for God and myself, so I can get my kids back. I’m happy, safe, and in treatment for recovery and healing. I got over my fears and tried something new! Today I was drug tested and OMG! I am almost clean for THC! Thank you so much! I can’t wait to show you guys and tell you more!  Thank you. Love y’all. Miss y’all. #sextrafficking #notforsale #endexploitation #peoplearenotproducts

name: The Genesis Project Seattle
content: The Genesis Project End of Year Campaign! The year 2020, has been a long, drawn-out smothering battle with COVID-19. We wish you all comfort and prayers in this time of uncertainty. Through these constant pressures, we ask that you join us in supporting someone in an additional struggle. We ask that you see the need and donate on behalf of someone trying to escape the world of sexual exploitation. We ask that you lift-up those that want a better life out of a horrible situati...on. The sale of child pornography has become a $3 billion dollar industry. Over 100,000 websites offer child pornography. 55 percent of internet child pornography comes from the U.S. 12 is the average age of entry into porn and prostitution, but their ages are often mislabeled.  The Genesis Project is a non-profit organization focused on providing healthy solutions for individuals trying to leave sex trafficking and sexual exploitation. GP provides counseling, substance abuse support, job and life skills classes, paid internship opportunities, transportation to medical appointments and court, free legal counsel, and access to educational programs such as GED completion. We also support these survivors by offering connections to housing programs, transportation to residential housing (long and short-term). Our mission is to uplift and support these girls through this tough transition to normality. This organization exists, where there is no other solution to offer these services in South King County. If you see the importance of these issues, please join us at: https://genesisnow.ejoinme.org/GP_DONATE Our donation site is fighting to keep our doors open. Thank you for your faithful support!

name: Hagar International
content: It’s almost over!! We can’t believe that today is the last day of 2020 and the last day to donate to our end of the year campaign, Reality Check: Finding Hope. We had to find new ways to deliver our services, create new solutions to problems and help lift up survivors (past and present) who saw their jobs taken, trauma resurface and on top of that, respond to crisis situations arising from multiple natural disasters and attacks of terror in the communities we work within. We ...have been able to continue to help our clients FIND HOPE. Unfortunately, we have only been able to help 1 in 10 women and children that are referred to us today. We would like to remedy this, and with your help, our goal is to be able to help 150,000 victims of human trafficking and modern day slavery by 2022. To do this, we need YOU! We hope that you have been able to see that your donations and partnership have allowed us to do during this unprecedented year and helps you understand how much we need you. Will you help us get to our goal? DONATE NOW: https://hagarusa.org/donate/

name: Hagar International
content: We hope you are loving seeing how your partnership and donations make such an impact on our Hagar clients. All because of you, our supporters, can we help so many victims Reality Check become about Finding Hope to become survivors. With Buddhism being the leading religion in Cambodia, Christmas is not celebrated by most of the population. However, Christians still come together to celebrate and there are still lights and trees in the cities!  Due to a recent case of community... COVID transmission, all schools have closed down again for the next 2 week period. Gatherings of over 20 people are prohibited and the Ministry of Health has instructed people to wear masks and practice social distancing.  Hagar’s services and programs in Cambodia continue to be implemented as normal, however, staff are observing the continual impacts of COVID in the lives of clients and their families.  There is evidence that domestic violence and rates of child sexual abuse have been increasing in Cambodia. COVID has also had a significant impact on the nation’s economy with our staff on the ground reporting that 50% of the businesses run by families we work with are experiencing lower incomes. There are fewer job opportunities in communities, and with the Thailand border closed there are limited options for gaining employment elsewhere. Our staff are concerned about the vulnerability this creates and the potential for illegal migration across the Thailand border and/or the falsehoods traffickers could tell people about their ability to get people across safely and into jobs.  Hagar continues to work closely with clients and their families during this tough time and supports them as much as possible with food assistance, counseling and help finding employment. Hagar staff also continues to work with the Government and other partners to coordinate the provision of resources to families impacted by the recent floods. Such support is deeply appreciated by those who receive it. Will you give today so Hagar can continue our mission of walking the Whole Journey with so many that are in need of our services? https://hagarusa.org/donate/

name: Hagar International
content: As we mentioned in our last post, we are proud to share with you how your partnership helps us from both a macro level to a micro level.  In Vietnam, Christmas isn’t an official public holiday and sometimes Christmas Eve is more important than Christmas day. However, there are still many Christmas trees and light displays in the major cities and carols, markets and meals are enjoyed! Due to COVID however there was not a concert outside the cathedral in Hanoi which is a much e...njoyed celebration.  As of December 13th, Vietnam had 1397 confirmed cases, 1241 recoveries and 35 deaths. More than 1.3 million tests have been performed. Recently, there have been 4 cases of community transmission in Ho Chi Minh and a consequent increase in social distancing has followed here.  Hagar’s programs continue to operate as normal and staff continue to walk the long-term recovery journey with survivors, as well as practically supporting those in need as a result of COVID. Hagar Vietnam’s COVID interventions in two provinces (distributing personal protection kits and the establishing hand washing stations in 8 schools) continue to be used.  The Hagar Vietnam team are very busy as the end of the year concludes. They are travelling a lot to try and complete 11 months worth of training sessions with other organizations into 7 months in addition to providing direct support to survivors.  Continue to support Hagar today: https://hagarusa.org/donate/

name: Hagar International
content: We are excited to share with you some updates from the ground today.  Because of you, our supporters, we can make Reality Check: Finding Hope a reality for so many! In Afghanistan, Christmas is not celebrated by the general population. However, expats working in different organizations sometimes have parties inside their offices to celebrate.  The latest numbers from Afghanistan report a total of 49,273 cases of COVID, with 38,384 recoveries and 1971 deaths. Afghanistan has also experienced a significant economic decline as a result of the pandemic due to reduced activity and trade disruption. Such a decline has put financial pressure on many, including current and former Hagar clients. Hagar continues to provide assistance where possible in finding work and has experienced meaningful success.  For example, some of the women participating in Hagar’s women’s project had been struggling to provide food for their families. In addition to providing counseling sessions, Hagar’s team introduced some clients to factories and now several are working sewing masks and medical clothes and have a source of income.  In addition to providing help finding employment, Hagar Afghanistan also distributes emergency funds to help those who are desperate to cover basic expenses.  Given the economic slowdown, a second wave of the pandemic, continued conflict, and an uncertain peace process and political environment, the country will continue to need grant support from the international community to address its fiscal deficit and maintain its current provision of basic services.  Overall however, Hagar Afghanistan’s activities are almost back to normal. Recently, one of the women in Hagar Afghanistan’s women’s project expressed to Hagar staff that she wanted to start a tailoring course in the basement of her house and teach women to sew as a way of trying to improve her poor financial situation. However, she needed help buying the equipment she needed to get herself started. Hagar purchased for her a sewing machine, some fabric and some essential tools like scissors, chalk and paper and were happy to be able to support this client as they try and explore a different source of income. The client will hopefully be starting to run lessons soon!  Donate today so we can continue to walk the Whole Journey with so many that need us: https://hagarusa.org/donate/ #thewholejourney #afghanistan #realitycheck #findinghope

name: Hope for Justice
content: We hope everyone enjoyed the #empowerall event for International Women's Day last week. We're incredibly grateful for the speakers who inspired us with their career stories.  During the event we explored the work being done in Ethiopia and Uganda through our Self-Help Groups to empower vulnerable women and young girls in business to prevent the risk of slavery. To support this impactful anti-slavery work you can make a donation here https://hopeforjustice.org/empowerall/ No gift is too small because every cent will help us continue this work to protect children and vulnerable families from traffickers. If you missed #empowerall you can watch the full event on our YouTube channel.

name: Hope for Justice
content: A mother who was struggling to make ends meet and whose children could have been vulnerable to trafficking is now running a small business and building a modern house for her family, thanks to Hope for Justice.  37-year-old Aberash and her husband worked as labourers in Ethiopia to support themselves and their six children, but it was tough for them to provide, with so many mouths to feed.    But then with the support of one of Hope for Justice’s community development workers..., Aberash joined one of our Self-Help Groups, which empower women through parenting and child protection, anti-trafficking and exploitation, communication and a range of other skills.    At first, Aberash lacked confidence. But through the group sessions, she learned life-changing lessons about how to form working relationships, identifying needs, saving money, and other skills vital for running a small business.    Aberash benefitted from the Self-Help Group loan system, which helps women become more financially stable. The loans allowed her to begin selling a local soft drink, and then cabbages too. She then bought a cart to help her husband with his work. Another loan, plus the profits from her business, meant she was able to buy some land upon which she is now building a home.  Thanking Hope for Justice for its support over four years, Aberash said: “I was in the dark waiting for people’s support, but Hope for Justice opened my eyes and now not only I am economically strong, but also respected in my community.”  Aberash is now paying back her loans and is looking forward to expanding her business. She also wants to help other women in a similar situation as she once was.    Through education and sensitisation to child protection issues, family strengthening via Hope for Justice’s Self-Help Group model enables greater support for those most at risk of exploitation and trafficking. The model is a long-term, sustainable solution, directed by community members’ own efforts. This approach protects against family breakdown, a major risk factor in child trafficking.

name: Hope for Justice
content: What brings you happiness? For survivors of human trafficking, happiness can be a distant memory. From the minute they are in our care, our goal is to change that. To provide a space where they feel safe, hopeful and eventually whole again. Every survivor's journey is different and some have more complex needs than others but your support is their pathway to happiness. Tailoring care to meet their individual needs is imperative in order for them to heal and begin to thrive in... their new life. By learning new skills and participating in group activities or games, they have the opportunity to make their own choices and begin to find out what makes them happy.  Thanks to you, our generous supporters we are able to provide aftercare that reignites hope, happiness and love in the lives of survivors of human trafficking. You are the reason they find happiness again and that's what we celebrate this #InternationalDayOfHappiness Find our more about becoming a Guardian here, https://hopeforjustice.org/become-a-guardian-uk/

name: Hope for Justice
content: We're proud to support the Free For Good campaign, which is calling on the Government to commit to introducing the modern slavery (Victim Support) Bill in the forthcoming Queen's Speech, to ensure that survivors of modern slavery are provided with the support that they need to be #freeforgood.  The campaign, which we have supported since January 2018, calls for the introduction of legislation as laid out in the Bill. This would provide survivors with at least a year’s support, with leave to remain. This vital time would allow them to recover more fully from their ordeal, as well as participate in proceedings to bring perpetrators to justice. Read more from Phillipa Roberts, our Director of Legal Policy and Solicitor, about why the Bill is so vital: https://hopeforjustice.org/…/survivors-of-modern-slavery-m…/

name: Hope for Justice
content: School closures over the last year have meant many parents all over the world have had to homeschool their children. But what if that wasn't an option?  For many families in poor and vulnerable communities in Kagugube, Uganda, like so many others around the world, the parents have had no option but to leave their children at home and travel to work. Because the schools have closed because of the pandemic, the risk has increased for children to be recruited into trafficking an...d exploitation via child marriages, domestic servitude, street vending and sexual exploitation.  To reduce children's vulnerability, Hope for Justice has trained "active citizens" who are now steering community education by working with caregivers and the local education department.  The Hope for Justice Active Citizen Training, in partnership with the British Council, aims to empower local leaders to engage with their communities peacefully and effectively. This incredible group of individuals has stepped up to put the needs of the children and their families first, effectively reducing the risk of human trafficking in their communities.

name: Hope for Justice
content: “Every girl we support has different emotional and psychological needs, which need tailored and personalized methods to help them.” Quote from a Therapist at our Cambodia Lighthouse.  At our Lighthouse in Phnom Penh, teenage girls rescued from sex trafficking (and some even younger than teenagers) receive restorative care. Thanks to the newly established Stepping Stone Project, many of the older girls are also equipped with the skills and knowledge they need to make their way... in the world. For many of the survivors we care for, it’s not possible for them to return to their families, often because it was their own family who trafficked them, or because the stigma they would face in the community where they grew up would not be possible to overcome. So after they have physically and mentally recovered from their experiences, we want to empower them to embrace their freedom and live happy, fulfilled and independent lives. Our life skills sessions cover everything from making safe choices and decisions to managing money. We equip the young people with the knowledge and awareness they need to care for their physical and mental health, as well as developing their everyday skills such as cooking and looking after their own home. We also support them in finding a good-quality job, working with local businesses with whom our team has developed excellent relationships with placing the girls in training programs, and subsequently, permanent roles.  Our expert team work with the girls to ensure they not only survive independently but they thrive!

name: Hope for Justice
content: This month we announced we’re recruiting a new team in #Lancashire and North-West England to respond to cases of human trafficking in the region. Here’s our UK & Europe Programme Director, Paul McAnulty, to explain more about the new team and how they will work.

name: Hope for Justice
content: In this article, The Washington Post highlights common misconceptions about human trafficking and modern slavery.  Being aware of these ‘myths’ not only opens your eyes to the reality of the problem but also helps increase your awareness of what could be happening around you. In plain sight.  Share your thoughts of the article in the comments below. https://www.washingtonpost.com/…/aa8f210c-7707-11eb-948d-19…

name: Hope for Justice
content: We all HOPE for Justice but we must all ACT for Justice too.  To each and every one of you who choose to support our work through fundraising activity, we say THANK YOU. From physical challenges like Break the Cycle 200 and Running for Freedom to flipping a house in 7 weeks like Flipping for Freedom with Young Living Foundation we have been blown away by your dedication (and creativity!) Whether you walk, run, cycle, bake... you can make an impact by fundraising for freedom. Kick start your own fundraiser today https://hopeforjustice.org/fundraise

name: Hope for Justice
content: Such important news for those in the UK: something we've long been calling for and now it's live! The Government has just launched a public register of all #ModernSlavery Statements. This is a huge step forward in transparency and businesses will need to adapt or risk falling behind. For the first time, customers, competitors and the general public will be able to see in one simple, central place the steps that a business is taking to combat the risk of modern slavery – or th...at it is not taking steps at all. If you care about buying slave-free products, check this Register before making purchases from big companies. See what they're doing about #ModernSlavery. If they aren't on there, ask why not. While the legislation only demands that companies turning over more than £36m have a Modern Slavery Statement, it is something that ALL businesses should seek to do if they care about this issue.

name: Hope for Justice
content: An 11-year-old boy who was incredibly vulnerable to trafficking and who became addicted to sniffing glue while living alone on the streets is now SAFE with his family and back at school.   Daniel* heard from some other children that he would find a well-paid and easy job if he ran away from home to a city in Ethiopia. He was eventually persuaded to agree to the plan. But Daniel didn’t find a job. He had no choice but to live on the street, trying to survive by scavenging left...over food from hotels and restaurants.   To escape the cold nights and the frightening reality of his situation, Daniel started sniffing glue and soon became addicted. After three weeks of hunger and worry, he was found by the police.  Thanks to your ongoing support, we were able to take Daniel in at one of Hope for Justice’s network of Lighthouses in Ethiopia. Here, our expert team worked with Daniel to free him of his addiction. He was offered counselling to help him recover from his experiences, as well as catch-up education at the Lighthouse.  Read Daniel's full story of recovery and reunion with his family HERE https://hopeforjustice.org/…/11-year-old-freed-from-addict…/ *Name has been changed to protect survivor’s identity

name: Hope for Justice
content: U g a n d a 📍 Over the past 4 years, with YOUR ongoing support, we have grown our network of children's Lighthouses in Uganda. Lighthouses provide temporary, safe accommodation for survivors of human trafficking and children who had been intensely vulnerable to trafficking. In these safe places, they benefit from trauma-informed aftercare, catch-up education and vocational skills training.  The children in our care range in age from toddlers to teenagers. Uganda has one of th...e youngest populations in the world – 56% of its citizens are under 18 years old. Sadly, over half of this child population are deemed critically or moderately vulnerable.  Out of every 100 children, 11 are orphans.  Keeping children safe here can be challenging. The UN Population Fund reports that 60% of adolescents aged 10-19 years have experienced physical violence, 42% emotional violence and 10% sexual violence. Many of these children also experience homelessness. Living on the streets increases the risk of violence, trafficking and exploitation as they struggle for their basic needs.  Working with local law enforcement, Hope for Justice takes in hundreds of vulnerable children each month and reunites them with their family or into loving family-based care when it's possible and safe to do so. To help protect more children in Uganda and support the work being done here, head to the link to donate https://bit.ly/HFJ_Donate

name: Hope for Justice
content: Today we celebrate the achievements of women because empowered women, empower women. We pledge to help and fight for the young girls and vulnerable women who are victims of human trafficking. The 30 million who are exploited by traffickers for profit or personal gain. Those who are deemed worthless by someone else or by societies that continue to hold discriminatory beliefs and practices around women’s access to property, education, marriage rights, basic decision making, and... even citizenship. We say women and girls matter. ALL victims of modern slavery matter and we #choosetochallenge the norms and beliefs that say differently. We choose to #empowerall because we believe in a world free from slavery.  To be a part of the conversation today from 4pm (in your local timezone) sign up for our free, virtual event https://bit.ly/empower_all

name: Hope for Justice
content: What does empowerment mean to you?  Freedom // Success // Independence // Passion // Control // Love // Ownership // Strength // Financial Stability // Choice // Free Speech // Power ? We are so excited to celebrate the success and empowerment of women in business today for International Women's Day. You can join in the conversation from 4pm (in your local timezone) with speakers from NatWest FlyteVu Helsesista OrganiCup Capgemini Grab The Gold and more. Let the countdown begin!! Sign up for the free #empowerall event here https://bit.ly/empower_all

name: Hope for Justice
content: Child wellbeing clubs are a vital part of our anti-trafficking community prevention programs.  Thanks to your generous donations we have been able to implement these programs in urban areas of Ethiopia and Uganda. There are two types of child wellbeing clubs: Child Protection Hubs offer a safe space for vulnerable children to meet, play and study. They empower children with knowledge of their rights and the dangers of human trafficking.  Community Child Protection Committees have been formed with community leaders and stakeholders to address child protection issues, to ensure abuse is spotted and reported, and to ensure perpetrators do not get away with their crimes.  On Monday, learn more about how our programs are empowering women and communities with the knowledge and tools to protect themselves against the risk of human trafficking. There will also be inspiring conversations with female business leaders offering career stories and tips.  Sign up for #empowerall here: https://bit.ly/empower_all

name: Hope for Justice
content: International Women's Day is Monday the 8th of March and we are hosting #empowerall, a free, virtual event. We are delighted to share the full line-up of speakers with you. This eclectic mix of female business leaders will be sharing their career experiences, stories and tips to #empowerall.  You'll also learn about the positive impact that empowering women is having on the fight against human trafficking, through our work in developing countries. The event will kick start at 4pm in your local time (you choose your timezone). We'll be announcing each speaker's interview time slot soon.  Sign up for free here https://bit.ly/empower_all

name: Hope for Justice
content: We’re delighted to announce that thanks to YOUR support, we’re recruiting a new team of staff in Lancashire to provide a lifeline to more people trapped in modern slavery in the area.   From April, our new team will roll out our award-winning response to modern slavery, by identifying and rescuing people who have been trafficked, and empowering them to rebuild their lives. As part of our tried-and-tested approach which has proven so successful in East Midlands and West Yorkshire, we’ll also carry out vital preventative work by training a wide range of professionals, groups and individuals to spot the signs of modern slavery and know how to report them.  Read more about today’s exciting announcement HERE https://hopeforjustice.org/…/new-team-to-fight-modern-slav…/

name: Hope for Justice
content: After spending three years held captive as a domestic slave, a 14-year-old boy has finally been reunited with his parents.   Tuiso*, who grew up in Southern Ethiopia, was 11 when his parents sent him to live with an aunt who had promised him a better life. His parents didn’t have permanent jobs, and struggled to provide for their son.   However, when Tuiso arrived, he was forced to work for free. He was not allowed to go to school, or go out to play with other children. He de...veloped a skin infection but was not taken to a doctor.  After three long years, Tuiso bravely took his chance to run away. But he couldn’t remember the way home. One of Hope for Justice’s team found him on the streets a month later, and took him to one of our Lighthouses.   We supported Tuiso for two and a half months, providing counseling sessions to allow him to begin to recover. We treated his skin infection, and offered catch-up lessons. We worked hard to find Tuiso’s family, as he was keen to return to them. His mother and father were delighted when we subsequently reunited the family.   Our staff also gave the family a helping hand to begin a new chapter. As well as providing Tuiso’s parents with training on child protection and the risk of trafficking, we offered training on how to run a small business. We then offered a loan, allowing Tuiso’s mother to open a shop selling salt, sugar and other essentials. Tuiso is now back at school.   *Name has been changed to protect survivor’s identity

name: Hope for Justice
content: Women and girls face gender-based discrimination that limits their access to education, property and employment opportunities. Risk factors like poverty, abuse and addiction further increase the risk of exploitation.   It's a fact that women and girls are disproportionally affected by modern-day slavery. In some countries, their gender defines their future.  By empowering young girls and vulnerable women with the tools to be self-sufficient, aware and independent, by giving t...hem a voice and the confidence to pursue economic prospects, we can reduce the risks of human trafficking. We can prevent a future that involves forced marriage, forced labour and sexual exploitation. Learn more about the anti-trafficking programs empowering girls and women this International Women's day.  Sign up here https://bit.ly/empower_all

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Deborah Sigmund will attend CSW65, representing Mother’s International and Innocents at Risk

name: Innocents at Risk
content: As teenagers spend more time on their laptops and phones due to online schooling and the continuing pandemic, it's more important than ever that parents know how to keep teens and children safe online. The FBI has seen a huge increase in the number of children and teens being threatened and coerced by adults into sending explicit images online -- a crime called sextortion. These child sexual abuse materials are due to online predators luring young men and women through sextin...g.  Parents must monitor their child's online usage, and talk with their children  about the dangers of chatting with strangers online and sending explicit photos of themselves, says Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund. In fact, in early February, two FBI agents were fatally shot in South Florida and three more were injured while serving a search warrant at a Sunrise residence in a child pornography case.  One of the FBI agents who was fatally wounded had recently spoken to middle school students about cyber safety and fighting crimes against children. Innocents at Risk has seen first-hand how FBI agents respond to calls when children are in danger, and is grateful for their efforts  to put their lives in danger protecting children.  #StopSextortion Call 1-800-CALL-FBI Tips.FBI.Gov

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Don't forget: Today is #WearBlueDay in recognition of Human Trafficking Awareness Day! Take a selfie wearing blue, post it, and use the #WearBlueDay hashtag. Awareness is prevention. Start online conversations about the world's largest criminal enterprise. Share a video on social media explaining why you are participating. Take a group photo and post it. Challenge your friends, family and colleagues to do the same!

name: Innocents at Risk
content: January 11th is Human Trafficking Awareness Day and #WearBlueDay.  And the month of January is National Slavery and Human Trafficking Prevention Month. Please join the Department of Homeland Security's Blue Campaign and Innocents at Risk in raising awareness of human trafficking through discussion and education  of the dangers and risks of child exploitation and human trafficking.  Wear blue on Jan. 11th, snap a selfie, and post it to social media with the #WearBlueDay hashtag. And tag @DHSBlueCampaign on  social media to bring awareness to #human trafficking--the fastest growing criminal industry in the world!

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Innocents at Risk is kicking off our final days of fundraising to close out a year that has brought unprecedented and profound changes around the world. As COVID-19 ran rampant, human traffickers increasingly moved their operations online to attract women and children in quarantine. Our fight to protect women and children from human trafficking is more vital now than ever before. In this season of giving thanks and giving back, would you join us in celebrating the power of giving by donating to Innocents at Risk? Help us keep children and young women and men safe from traffickers.  You can donate online at https://bit.ly/2LOSV6Y  or Text INNOCENTS to 41444. Together we can protect our children with our "Awareness is Prevention" outreach efforts in schools and communities.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Innocents at Risk flags your attention to an excellent article written by Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Nicholas Kristof in the New York Times that exposes the massive sex trafficking of women and minors on the Pornhub website. U.S. senators are demanding federal investigations and introducing legislation targeting Pornhub. Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund says she's "grateful" that Kristof has "joined the fight to help shut down Pornhub." You can join the movement to shut down Pornhub by signing the petition at https://traffickinghubpetition.com/. It has 2.1 million signatures so far!

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Today is #GivingTuesday! You have an opportunity to make a real difference in helping Innocents at Risk expand our awareness and outreach efforts to combat the human trafficking of women and children. Please consider making a tax-deductible gift today. 100% of your donation will help fund our educational efforts to expand awareness and host events,  educate the public and members of Congress on much-needed legislation to protect children, and work with organizations that directly help young women and children who are survivors of human trafficking. The fight to end trafficking is is more urgent because traffickers have moved their operations online during the pandemic. Help keep our children safe; they are counting on us! You can donate here at https://www.facebook.com/innocentsatrisk/app/250457581338 or Text INNOCENTS to 41444.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: As you shop for sales today, #CyberMonday, please consider donating to Innocents at Risk to help us fight to protect women and children from exploitation and human trafficking. Donate online at https://app.mobilecause.com/f/32wx/n?vid=eo2t3 or text INNOCENTS to 41444.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: We hope you had a Happy Thanksgiving! On this Black Friday, let's acknowledge the power of giving, volunteerism and simple acts of kindness. Innocents at Risk is participating in the annual  #GivingTuesday fundraiser, which occurs today, Black Friday; on Cyber Monday, Nov. 30th; and on #GivingTuesday, Dec. 1st. Please join Innocents at Risk in our fight to protect women and children from exploitation and human trafficking. For more information, visit our website www.innocentsatrisk.org. You can donate online at https://app.mobilecause.com/f/32wx/n?vid=el8o9 or text INNOCENTS to 41444.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Innocents at Risk on Nov. 17 joined 82 organizations from 30 states urging the Senate Judiciary Committee to push social media giants to eliminate and suppress child sexual abuse material on the Internet. The groups submitted a letter to the committee's hearing, at which Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified, and asked them to use their unprecedented power for the good in controlling child sexual abuse content. The groups support Senate passage of... S. 3398, the EARN IT Act, which would revoke corporate immunity from liability for the posting of child sexual abuse material on the Web. Tech company lobbyists have been fighting passage of the bill. The groups urged the CEOs to publicly endorse the bill's passage, delete child sexual abuse material on their social media platforms, and report such instances to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. S. 3398 passed the Senate Judiciary Committee in July and is awaiting Senate and House passage. Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund says, "In the name of young women, men, girls and boys who have been victims of online exploitation and trafficking, we need to get the EARN IT Act passed!"

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Innocents at Risk is excited to participate in #GivingTuesday on the Tuesday after Thanksgiving, Black Friday and Cyber Monday. We acknowledge the power of giving, volunteerism and simple acts of kindness on those days. Please join us as we all come together to support the greater good. Our fight to protect women and children from exploitation and human trafficking is more vital than ever before, especially during this pandemic. You can donate to Innocents at Risk by texting INNOCENTS to 41444 or online at https://app.mobilecause.com/form/aRb-RA?vid=eame6.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Congratulations to the U.S. Marshals, the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, and all law enforcement officials involved in recovering 27 missing children in Virginia under "Operation Find Our Children," says Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund. https://www.cnn.com/…/virginia-missing-children-…/index.html

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Please help the National Center on Sexual Exploitation, Innocents at Risk, the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, Enough is Enough and other organizations fight child sexual abuse materials online by supporting passage of bipartisan legislation to hold technology companies accountable for aiding and distributing such harmful material. Over the last 10 years, circulation of child sexual abuse materials online has grown exponentially from 600,000 images and vid...eos reported to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children in 2008, to nearly 70 million such images in 2019. The current law, the Communications Decency Act of 1996, gives near carte blanche immunity to tech companies for facilitating child sexual abuse materials online because they are not considered “publishers.”  The EARN IT Act S 3398/HR 8454, which was approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee this summer and awaits Senate passage, would revoke that immunity from liability by requiring tech companies to help law enforcement access critical information to remove such images. Survivors and state attorneys general would be able to sue tech companies for facilitating child sexual abuse materials online using federal civil law, and state civil and criminal laws. The proposed legislation also would create an Online Child Exploitation Prevention Commission to make recommendations to inform public policy, courts and the law enforcement community about protecting children in the ever-changing digital environment. "Tech companies are in a position to, if the see something, say something," says Deborah Sigmund, founder of Innocents at Risk. "This bill is about creating a safe environment on the Internet and keeping children safe," she adds. Passage of the bill before year’s end would “push technology companies to proactively clean up their own platforms to prevent sex trafficking, grooming and predatory behavior,” Sigmund says. “If tech companies act responsibly and no longer turn a blind eye to child sexual material on their websites, they will be joining the fight to end child trafficking and sexploitation,” she says. You can click on this link to let your senators and congressmen know you want this bill passed before the end of this Congress. https://endsexualexploitation.org/…/earn-it-act-is-our-bes…/

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Last week the Justice Department announced that its Office for Victims of Crime has awarded $35 million in grant funding to provide safe, stable housing and transitional services to victims of human trafficking. The grants will go to 73 organizations to provide six to 24 months of transitional and short-term housing for trafficking victims, including rental, utilities and related expenses. The grants also will provide support to help victims locate permanent housing, secure e...mployment and receive occupational training and counseling. Deborah Sigmund, founder of Innocents at Risk, says, “These much-needed grants can help survivors of trafficking rebuild their lives.”  She noted that the organizations receiving the grants are located in 34 states that are some of the hotbeds of human trafficking in the U.S., including Texas, California, New York, Florida and Illinois.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Our fight to end human trafficking, especially of women and children, has hit the news in a big way these last two days, and Innocents at Risk has been involved every step of the way.  * On July 29th, Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund spoke at the first Zoom event of Voices Against Trafficking, a group of national and international partners, including charter member Innocents at Risk, dedicated to eradicating the multibillion dollar global business of profiting in hum...an lives. The Zoom webinar featured anti-trafficking organizations, members of Congress and the Administration, advocates against child exploitation, national and international dignitaries, and other human rights leaders dedicated to fighting the world’s fastest growing criminal industry. Deborah Sigmund spoke of the Flight Attendant Initiative she launched in 2008 to train flight attendants to spot and report human trafficking on planes and in airports. The initiative has saved thousands of lives. Rep. Chris Smith (R-NJ) praised Ms. Sigmund’s “tenacious commitment to empower others to recognize and effectuate rescue of victims in transit.” Transportation Department Secretary Elaine Chao reported that over 500 executives have now signed her Transportation Leaders Against Human Trafficking Pledge. Leaders from “every mode of transportation, labor and non-governmental organizations from across the country” have agreed to train 1.3 million employees to raise awareness to fight human trafficking. Secretary Chao said “that’s an army of people” that will help law enforcement “fight the battle.” The Voices Against Trafficking webinar, which was watched by over 6,000 people around the world, can be viewed on YouTube at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3sfHbzhhO_A or on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/VoicesAgainstTrafficking/videos/3046436072130554 * An important piece of legislation, “Sami’s Law,” was passed by the House of Representatives on July 29, and is now awaiting action by the Senate. The bill, sponsored by Rep. Chris Smith, is named in honor of Samantha “Sami” Josephson, a senior at the University of South Carolina, who was kidnapped and murdered last year by a predator pretending to be an Uber driver. The bipartisan bill, approved in a unanimous voice vote, will require ride-hailing companies, such as Uber and Lyft, to deploy a verifiable electronic access system to match drivers with passengers before the ride begins, to penhance the safety of the ride-hailing public. Smith also authored the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000, the first comprehensive anti-human trafficking law. *July 30 was the UN’s World Day Against Trafficking in Persons. Ms. Sigmund says we all must do our part to fight this international scourge. “Awareness is prevention,” she says.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: In recognition of World Awareness Day of Trafficking, please join Innocents at Risk in partnership with Voices Against Trafficking on July 29th for this important event.   SAVE THE DATE! July 29, 2020 11 am - 3 pm EDT (UTC-4)... https://www.voicesagainsttrafficking.com  Facebook.com/VoicesAgainstTrafficking Join us at this important Zoom event in recognition of World Day Against Trafficking in Persons, and to help increase global awareness of human trafficking, Human trafficking is the world's fastest-growing multibillion-dollar criminal industry. This vast transnational enterprise is the greatest exploitation of men, women and children this world has ever seen. Your voice is more important now than ever before. Join us "live" a few minutes before start time at Facebook.com/VoicesAgainstTrafficking. Speakers include members of Congress, U.S. Secretary of Transportation Elaine Chao, U.S. Ambassador Senator Nancy de la Sierra (Mexico), Senator Manuel Anorve (Mexico), Bishop Marcelo Sanchez Sorondo from the Vatican, Chief Jerry Garnett/ ICE HSI, Victims Right Advocates, Nonprofits, Internet Safety Leaders, Law Enforcement Experts, and Survivors who are forging a new path for all human rights. More to be announced. Voices Against Trafficking speaks for those who cannot speak for themselves, the victims of human bondage and sexual slavery. We demand vigorous prosecution of their perpetrators. Add YOUR VOICE as we seek justice and compassionate specialized care for all victims of this international

name: Innocents at Risk

Human trafficking is the world's fastest growing multibillion dollar criminal industry. This vast transnational enterprise is the greatest exploitation of men, women and children this world has ever seen. Your voice is more important now than ever before.  W...e would be honored by your attendance, and appreciate your support.  Voices Against Trafficking  International Zoom Webinar Wednesday, July 29, 2020 11 am - 3 pm EDT (UTC-4) A few minutes before our start time, please join us on Facebook @VoicesAgainstTrafficking for the live stream of our event!

name: Innocents at Risk
content: The State Department on June 25 hosted a virtual event to release its 2020 Trafficking in Persons Report. This was the 20th anniversary of the report. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo noted that the report rates each country for its performance in fighting human trafficking, and recognizes heroes from countries around the world who work diligently to  prevent trafficking. Advisor to the President Ivanka Trump said the Administration is dedicated to expanding efforts to combat t...rafficking, and introduced Heather Fischer, the newly appointed Special Advisor for Human Trafficking to the White House's Domestic Policy Council. Ambassador at Large John Richmond said the Office of Trafficking in Persons is encouraged that 22 countries have received higher ratings in 2020, including Singapore and Namibia. Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund commended the diligent work of Ambassador Richmond and everyone working in the TIP Office to produce this 570-page report, even during the coronavirus pandemic. She said "Let's all make a new commitment to join in the fight to help spread awareness to end the greatest human rights issue of our time." You can download the 2020 TIP Report by clicking on this link.  https://www.state.gov/…/2020-TIP-Report-Complete-062420-FIN…

name: Innocents at Risk
content: The Department of Transportation announced that over 200 transportation industry leaders have answered the call by Transportation Secretary Elaine L. Chao to help fight human trafficking. In January she asked transportation leaders to take a public stand by signing DOT's "Transportation Leaders Against Human Trafficking" pledge. The goal was 100 pledges in 100 days; more than double  that number came in from transportation, labor and non-governmental leaders, DOT said.The sig...natories committed to raising public awareness on human trafficking and training more than 1 million employees to help fight the crime.  Chao applauded the transportation sector for helping "to ensure our transportation system is not hijacked for evil purposes." Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund said even during the COVID-19 pandemic, DOT has persevered to get the transportation sector to help end human trafficking. She "is so grateful to Secretary Chao's dedication to this most important issue, turning thousands of eyes to help keep innocent lives safe."  Human trafficking is modern-day slavery affecting nearly 25 million adults and children in the U.S. and abroad. Victims are of every age, race, gender, background, citizenship and immigration status. Some are trafficked within their own communities, while others are transported to other locations using America's roadways, airways, railways and waterways, DOT says.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Innocents at Risk yesterday partnered with Traffickinghub.com in its effort to shut down Pornhub, the world's largest pornographic website. Just as Innocents at Risk joined forces with several non-governmental organizations and members of Congress in 2018 to shut down Backpage, a site that posted prostitution and human trafficking ads involving minors, the groups are now setting their sights on Pornhub. They seek to hold Pornhub and its owners accountable for enabling and pro...fiting off the mass sex-trafficking and exploitation of women and minors on the website. Join Innocents at Risk in signing Traffickinghub's petition to shut down Pornhub.The petition, Shut Down Pornhub and Hold Its Executives Accountable for Aiding Trafficking, already has over 1 million signatures! "It's time that all of us lend our voices to get the sites that are dangerous to our children off the Internet and put out of business," says Deborah Sigmund, founder of Innocents at Risk. https://traffickinghubpetition.com/

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Today is #GivingTuesdayNow, a global day of giving and unity as an emergency response to the unprecedented needs caused by COVID-19. Please remember Innocents at Risk in your giving. We have been busy during the coronavirus shutdown keeping you informed of escalations in human trafficking, and donating to colleagues in need and organizations here in our Nation's Capital. Please help  Innocents at Risk continue our work to keep children and women safe while human traffickers find new ways around social distancing. Stay well and safe! https://www.facebook.com/innocentsatrisk/app/250457581338/

name: Innocents at Risk
content: The coronavirus pandemic has not slowed down the human trafficking industry in Phoenix, but has forced traffickers to change the tactics they use, says Dominique Roe-Sepowitz, director of sex trafficking intervention research at Arizona State University. Experts say traffickers have become more violent and aggressive. Although sex trafficking moved online when the pandemic first hit, victims are now being forced back on the streets and are having a harder time escaping. If you see something or know a child is in danger, call 911; the National Human Trafficking Hotline at 1-888-378-7888; or the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children at 1-800-843-5678, says Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund. See the related article below from the CBS-TV affiliate in Phoenix. https://www.azfamily.com/…/article_784963b6-876a-11ea-9bac-…

name: Innocents at Risk
content: New human trafficking schemes have emerged in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic. The Federal Bureau of Investigations has a task force dedicated to preventing trafficking in almost every FBI location in the the country. The New York FBI's Human Trafficking Task Force recently uncovered and is fighting the rise of coronavirus-related advertisements in human trafficking. We must take action to education ourselves and our loved ones about these emerging new schemes, says Inn...ocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund. Innocents at Risk has received calls from parents who reported that their daughters were missing. In several cases, the girls had met someone online or on a walk outside of their home. In both situations, our office connected the families of the missing girls to the FBI. We are praying for their safe return. Innocents at Risk continues to educate parents and children on how young women, girls, and boys can be easily lured on the Internet.  Read the ABC News article below on what the FBI has uncovered during this coronavirus pandemic. #StopHumanTraffickiing https://abcnews.go.com/…/fbi-task-force-focuses-huma…/story…

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Thank you, Queen Silvia of Sweden, for this important message. Queen Silvia has been a mentor of mine and Innocents at Risk since 2006 when I had the privilege of meeting Her Majesty in Sweden. Queen Silvia taught me that it was important to get the leaders in every community -- “the decision-makers“ as she explained -- to spread the message and work together to protect our children! Innocents at Risk has been doing just that every day since that meeting!! God Bless you and your family, Queen Silvia! #COVID19 #MentorFoundation #InnocentsatRisk

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Dear Friends of Innocents at Risk, April 21st was the date that Innocents at Risk would have been hosting our 15th Anniversary Gala. The Evening to Benefit Innocents at Risk would have been held at the beautiful Organization of American States and honored Secretary Elaine Chao of the Department of Transportation and members of Congress for their outstanding dedication to preventing human trafficking. As you know, our gala had to be postponed due to the coronavirus epidemic.  ...Our 2020 Gala Chairs Omar and Yasmine Ghorbal and all of us at Innocents at Risk look forward to welcoming you to our Anniversary Gala later this year. In the meantime, please be safe and stay well. Warmly, Deborah Sigmund Founder/Director Innocents At Risk The picture is from our 2009 Gala at the Ambassador of France's Residence. Left to right: Former Ambassador of France Pier Vimont; Representative Carolyn Maloney; Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund; and Senior American Airlines Flight Attendant Sandra Fiorini.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: We hope that you are staying safe during this uncertain time of social distancing. Reading for pleasure is a great way to alleviate some stress and pass the time indoors. Innocents at Risk has created a recommended reading list of books about human trafficking, especially child trafficking, Each of these books does an excellent job of explaining the issue of human trafficking. They can be ordered on Amazon via home delivery or the Kindle App. * A Walk Across the Sun, by Corba...n Addison, is a chilling, eye-opening journey into Mumbai's underworld and the nightmare of two orphaned girls swept into the international sex trade following a tsunami. * A Crime So Monstrous, by E. Benjamin Skinner, is about his travels around the globe telling stories of modern day slavery in such places as Haiti, Sudan, India, Eastern Europe, The Netherlands, and suburban America. * The Forgotten, by David Baldacci, is a thriller about an Army Special Agent who investigates the tragic death of his aunt and uncovers a human trafficking ring in the picture-perfect town of Paradise, Fla. * Slave Hunter: Freeing Victims of Human Trafficking, by Aaron Cohen, depicts his journey from rock-star-turned activist to a real-life slave hunter who exposes the sinister flesh trade. * Half the Sky, by Pulitzer Prize winners Nicholas Kristof & Sheryl WuDunn, is a passionate call to arms against the oppression of women and girls in the developing world, told through the lens of stories about women in Africa and Asia. * Renting Lacy: A Story of America's Prostituted Children, by Linda Smith, tells the stories of young girls sold into the commercial sex trade at young ages in America.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: April is National Child Abuse Prevention Month, and this year, more than ever, Innocents at Risk is very concerned about children who are out of school. Children now have more free time and often are not supervised during this time of coronavirus quarantines. We worry especially about children who do not have a full-time parent or guardian. Please read the recent FBI warning that school closings due to COVID-19 present potential increased risk for child exploitation. Stay safe in this time of unchartered territory, says Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund. https://www.fbi.gov/…/school-closings-due-to-covid-19-prese…

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Now that children are home from school, they have greater access to the Internet. The Internet can serve as a platform for predators to exploit young children. Innocents at Risk joins Shared Hope and The National Center on Sexual Exploitation with the following message for parents. Please be vigilant and keep your children safe. Stay Safe and Be Well!!

Innocents at Risk will make a presentation along with a member of the Blue Campaign from the The Department of Homeland Security. We hope to see you there! #AwarenessEventonHumanTrafficking

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Parents and adults everywhere: please stay Alert and Vigilant! We Must Protect Our Children!!!  We are great full that this little girl is safe but law enforcement can not do it alone everyone needs to Keep Your Eyes Open and Protect Our Children!! https://www.necn.com/…/police-say-missing-11-year…/2219032/…

name: Innocents at Risk
content: The White House held a Summit on Human Trafficking on Jan. 31,  in honor of the 20th anniversary of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act. President Trump told the meeting of cabinet secretaries, state officials, members of Congress, nonprofit groups and survivors that an estimated 25 million people around the world today are held captive, manipulated, and abused by human traffickers. In 2018, the National Human Trafficking Hotline identified over 23,000 human trafficking vi...ctims in the U.S.; 65 percent of the victims were women and more than 20 percent were children. At the summit, President signed an executive order targeting human trafficking and child exploitation. The order expands prevention education programs, promotes housing opportunities for survivors, promotes information gathering between law enforcement and federal agencies charged with combating trafficking, and prioritizes the removal of child sexual abuse material from the Internet. The measure also designates a full-time position at the White House dedicated to combating human trafficking. Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund applauds the stepped-up efforts of the Administration, Congress, state authorities and private groups to combat human trafficking.  #FightHumanTrafficking #Awareness #ProsecutionProtectionPrevention

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Large events, like today's Super Bowl LIV in Miami, that bring thousands of people together are also magnets for human trafficking and sexual exploitation. But federal, state, and Miami law enforcement authorities and hotels have been preparing over the last few months to combat the expected onslaught of human trafficking in the area. One organization, A21, last weekend in Miami provided training and awareness to hotels and Uber drivers to stop sexual exploitation of women an...d minors. Over 500 volunteers helped distribute the human trafficking hotline number, as well as a list of missing children to more than 400 Miami area hotels. Innocents at Risk Founder Deborah Sigmund says "with the presence of Department of Homeland Security and law enforcement everywhere, Miami is going to be ready to stop it!" If you see something suspicious, report it to the National Human Trafficking Hotline at 1-888-373-7888 or text 233733 on your cell phone.  #HumanTraffickingAwareness #SeeItReportIt  #AwarenessIsKey

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Human Trafficking & The Super Bowl?! http://go.fightthenewdrug.org/…/b47515b373433fd4d7ae636162b…

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Please join Innocents at Risk at this important event at the Department of Labor on January 28th! Human Trafficking Awareness Month Pledge Event Hosted by U.S. Secretary Elaine L. Chao You are invited to attend the USDOT “100 Pledges in 100 Days” event focused on combating human trafficking in the transportation sector, which will take place on January 28, 2020 at 11 am, in the DOT West Building Atrium, 1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE, Washington, DC 20590. Nearly 25 million people across the globe are victims of modern slavery. Human traffickers utilize transportation systems to transport their victims. Transportation leaders have an opportunity to amplify counter-trafficking efforts to combat this heinous crime. The event will feature remarks by Secretary of Transportation Elaine L. Chao and other public and private transportation leaders highlighting their counter-trafficking efforts. Attendees will be invited to sign the Department’s Transportation Leaders Against Human Trafficking (TLAHT) pledge to combat human trafficking in the transportation sector. Email llemmonds@usiaht.org to register Tuesday, January 28, 2020 Doors open at 10:00 a.m. Ceremony begins at 11:00 a.m. U.S. Department of Transportation West Atrium 1200 New Jersey Ave SE Washington, DC 20590

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Yesterday my daughter-in-law sent me a photo of this sign posted in the ladies room at a resort in Las Vegas.  Innocents at Risk salutes The Venetian Resort for their work to STOP Human Trafficking!!    Hopefully, we will see more and more of these postings!!

name: Innocents at Risk
content: January is designated Human Trafficking Prevention Month, a time to raise awareness, provide education and take action to recognize and report this heinous crime. Here's ways you can get involved: ** Participate in #WearBlueDay on  Sat. Jan. 11th. Join the Department of Homeland Security's Blue Campaign by wearing blue clothes and posting a photo of yourself and others on social media. Use the hashtags #DHSBlueCampaign and #WearBlueDay. ** Learn the indicators of human trafficking. ** Download and share the @DHSBlueCampaign's materials for use at events, posted in your community, or shared online. Learn more by clicking on this link:  http://bit.ly/39K7O1Y ** Use social media to reach your followers about human trafficking.

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Three victims of sex trafficking have sued Hilton Worldwide, Choice Hotels International, and Wyndham Hotels, claiming the hotel chains exercised gross negligence of on-site prostitution at their Houston-area hotel branches and don’t do enough to stop sex trafficking, according to an article in the Houston Chronicle.  That’s despite the hotel chains’ publicly stated corporate policies that promote social responsibility, the Chronicle noted in a Dec. 31 story. Two of the women... were teenagers and one an adult when trafficked in the Houston hotels. The three separate lawsuits accuse the national hotel chains of negligence and violations of federal and state laws prohibiting human trafficking. The suits claim “traffickers have long capitalized on the hotel industry’s refusal to adopt companywide anti-trafficking policies, refusal to train staff on what to look for and how to respond, and failure to establish a safe and secure reporting mechanism, and they have exploited the seclusion and privacy of hotel rooms.”  Annie McAdams, the plaintiffs’ lawyer who’s partnering with other firms on the suits, told the Houston Chronicle that these cases are the first such effort targeted at parent company hotel chains. The parent companies claim they’re not responsible for what happens at their hotel locations, McAdams told the Chronicle. A spokesperson for Hilton Americas told the Chronicle that the chain condemns all forms of human trafficking and sexual exploitation, and provides anti-human trafficking training to all team members at all properties. A Choice Hotels spokesperson told the Chronicle that the hotel chain is a signatory to ECPAT International’s Code of Conduct for the Protection of Children from Sexual Exploitation in Travel and Tourism. Wyndham hotels didn’t comment. Deborah Sigmund, founder of Innocents at Risk, says “It’s one thing to sign the ECPAT’s Code of Conduct. It’s another to be dedicated to protecting women and children, and keeping them safe.” She notes Marriott Hotels signed the Code of Conduct, took out pornography on hotel TVs, hired undercover police, and are a “model of hotels fighting trafficking.” She says Sofitel Hotels, also a signatory to the Code of Conduct, is dedicated to fighting sexual trafficking of women and children. "Unfortunately, some hotels care more about making a dollar than protecting innocent lives," Deborah says. Most of the calls to the National Human Trafficking Hotline involve hotel incidents.  Click on the link to the Houston Chronicle’s story: https://www.houstonchronicle.com/…/Three-hotel-chains-in-Ho…

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Start the New Year right with #WearBlueDay on Jan. 11, National Human Trafficking Awareness Day!! Join Innocents at Risk, the Department of Homeland Security's Blue Campaign, government agencies, city and state legislators, corporations, Airline Ambassadors and our NGO partners to STAND UP AGAINST HUMAN TRAFFICKING!  To raise awareness of this global crime, take photos of yourselves, friends, family, and colleagues wearing blue clothing and share them on social media - Facebook, Twitter, Instagram - along with the #WearBlueDay hashtag. Anyone can participate; all you need is a piece of blue clothing! For move information, go to the DHS Blue Campaign's website at https://www.dhs.gov/blue-campaign/wearblueday. And follow on Twitter @DHSBlueCampaign.

If you donate to Innocents at Risk through our Facebook page early on Tuesday, your donation will be doubled by Facebook. Click here to donate: https://www.facebook.com/innocentsatrisk/app/250457581338/

name: Innocents at Risk
content: I was pleased to speak at the launch of the Alliance to End Human Trafficking this week. Human trafficking is a horrific crime that affects at-risk populations in the United States and worldwide. I hope that the Alliance To End Human Trafficking will be a powerful force in the fight against criminals who exploit children and other vulnerable people. I am grateful for the Alliance’s commitment to ending these atrocities and empowering the most vulnerable among us. Sincerely, Ann Wagner Member of Congres
