name: Innocents at Risk
content: Thank you to CBS-TV for highlighting human trafficking in its latest episode of NCIS: New Orleans, entitled "Overlooked," which aired Oct. 15th. --Phoebe Eliopoulos, Advisory Board Member, Innocents at Risk

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Human trafficking is the most heinous crime on earth, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said this summer, and former Secretary of State John Kerry said fighting human trafficking is a war against evil and money, noted Deborah Sigmund, founder of Innocents at Risk. She told a State Department forum yesterday held by the Associates of the American Foreign Service Worldwide that human trafficking has grown from a $32 billion a year global business when she founded Innocents at Risk... in 2005 to a $150 billion a year business today. She related stories of young women from Moscow flying into Chicago, thinking they would become models in New York City, only to be forced into prostitution, and young girls coming from Brazil into Connecticut being told they would be nannies, only to end up in the sex trade run by organized crime. Ms. Sigmund said it's up to everyone to keep their eyes open in public places, and when you see a young person who stands out and doesn't appear to be in a normal situation, report it immediately to local authorities. Human trafficking is modern day slavery, and the most profitable component is forced sex labor. Alma Tucker, president of the International Network of Hearts, has founded three "safe houses" that are shelters in the San Diego and Tijuana area where victims of human trafficking can live, heal, study and work. She noted that Tijuana, Mexico, is now known for "sexual tourism." Both Sigmund and Tucker said the Internet has become a powerful tool for human traffickers to use to sell young people on the Dark Web. Sigmund noted that more money is spent fighting drugs than fighting human trafficking. She expressed concern about legislation coming up for a vote in the D.C. City Council that would decriminalize violations for buying sex or being in the sex trade. Photos by Neshan Naltchayan

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Human trafficking worldwide has grown to a $150 billion industry affecting 40 million people, including more than 400,000 in the US, experts told a Global Sustainability Network forum at Columbia University this week. Three out of four victims of trafficking are women, and 1 out of 4 are children. "Human trafficking is the greatest crime of the 21st Century," Deborah Sigmund, founder of Innocents at Risk, told the meeting. She said human trafficking hit the US around the year 2000 "like a ton of bricks." Her work has led to the initiative that trains flight attendants to spot and report victims to authorities, and the Transportation Department to spread anti-trafficking information to all sectors of the transportation industry, including truckers.  @InnocentsAtRisk #StopHumanTrafficking #TrainingAndAwarenessIsKey 9m

name: Innocents at Risk
content: Innocents at Risk Founder and Director Deborah Sigmund was a speaker at the Human and Drug Trafficking Workshop at Bible Way Church, Saturday September 21, 2019.  This was an excellent example of how Communities can be educated about the horrific issue of the fastest growing criminal industry in the world today!

name: Innocents at Risk
content: International Network of Hearts Event at the Department of State Burns Auditorium at the State Department Thursday, October 10th 2019 10:30 AM The Associates of the American Foreign Service Worldwide AAFSW cordially invite you to  join us at this informative  presentation on one important issue in Human Trafficking that affects society today around the world. The Panel discussion will take place on Thursday, October 10th at 10:30 AM,  in the Burns Auditorium in the George Marshall Center of the State Department in Washington, D.C. We are featuring two remarkable women; Deborah Sigmund, Founder and  President of Innocents at Risk, and Alma Tucker, Founder and President of  International Network of Hearts, who are doing  an amazing job advocating for the rights and helping the victims of inhumane and slave-like conditions of women and children. RSVP to AAFSW at office@aafsw.orgno later than Tuesday, October 8 and  send us your driver’s license number or passport number and date of birth to submit to the Office of Security in the State Department. In addition, please send a check made out to AAFSW for $ 10;00  to AAFSW Reservations at 4001 North Ninth Street, Suite 214, Arlington VA, 22203. Please come to the 21st Street NW entrance of the Department of State, close to the corner of “D” Street. As you enter rather than reporting to the main desk, please go to the table to your left where one of our members will check you in.

name: International Justice Mission
content: Every year, Congress builds a budget. And every year, Congress needs to hear that you care about programs that will help end modern slavery.  Take 30 seconds to tell your representatives on Capitol Hill to make sure anti-slavery programs are fully funded. Sign our petition today! https://bit.ly/2O0gWsZ

name: International Justice Mission
content: Online sexual exploitation of children is a form of trafficking that exploits children in seconds all around the world. And the Philippines is its global hotspot. As COVID-19 has forced children to be locked in their homes, the rates of abuse have grown exponentially. And one year after lockdowns first began, it’s still on the rise. But because of our Freedom Partners who continue to support our work day after day, against all odds, over 100 children have been rescued during ...lockdown.  The online demand for children is still on this rise, so there’s no time to delay. Will you step in to rescue and restore more of these children back to their childhoods? Become a Freedom Partner today. https://bit.ly/3r1BGyj

name: International Justice Mission
content: This is what safety and security can look like for widows in Uganda; a support group of women free from fear - fear that their land and livelihood will be stolen. They meet together to support each other and build their businesses.  Violence against women and children should not be the norm. That’s why IJM Uganda fights for justice for these families. Since 2004, our Uganda team has helped over 1,800 widows and their families be restored to their homes and land.

name: International Justice Mission
content: #GOODNEWS: IJM Dominican Republic and Aerodom, the largest network of airports in the DR, have signed an agreement to bring an end to #sextrafficking in the country! This exciting new partnership will work with IJM to combat sex trafficking by: - launching awareness campaigns in terminals - training staff to recognize the signs of trafficking... - establishing additional protocols to report these crimes to local authorities This is the first collaborative agreement that IJM DR has signed with the business sector. As IJM makes new partnerships, the aviation industry is an essential private sector partner to ensure greater impact and achieve protection for those living in vulnerable situations. It's wonderful to see growing demand for protection in the DR. We’re excited to see what this partnership will do! https://bit.ly/3vojvW

name: International Justice Mission
content: Solenn was only 12 when she learned what most of her friends and the adults in her neighborhood were doing to make ends meet. They were being exploited in front of a camera, being told what to do by sex offenders on the other side of the screen.    Solenn was a child, too young to understand what was happening, only that it helped put food on the table for her family. Once this child came to understand what was happening to her, she tried to stop it. But there was no one to t...urn to for help. There was no one to protect her.  Thankfully, our IJM team and local law enforcement finally found Solenn and brought her to safety. But there’s still many more who will have their childhood stolen from them unless we all work together to step in and protect them. Become a Freedom Partner today and help us end this form of trafficking for good. https://bit.ly/3rMpwKO

name: International Justice Mission
content: #GOODNEWS – Three teenagers are now FREE from #sextrafficking in the Dominican Republic after being rescued in an operation by Dominican authorities! IJM supported the operation that rescued them from an illegal bar.⁣ ⁣ Two suspects, a 37-year old woman who owned the place and her son, were arrested and will be prosecuted for the crimes of human trafficking, commercial sexual exploitation and procuring.  Read more about the rescue: https://bit.ly/3cmQ7HV... ⁣

name: International Justice Mission
content: The Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons (TIP) is central to the US government’s fight against trafficking around the world. Over the years, advocates like you have significantly increased the available funding for anti-trafficking programming that helps protect victims, prosecute traffickers and prevent trafficking from occurring altogether. Read more about IJM’s advocacy work from Nate King, our US Director of Advocacy. https://bit.ly/3sp7KNO

name: International Justice Mission
content: John Tanagho, director of IJM’s Center to End Online Sexual Exploitation of Children, has been working in the Philippines to help put an end to child trafficking for 6 years. When he first traveled to the Philippines with IJM, nothing could have prepared him for the new and dangerous form of trafficking he found: online sexual exploitation of children.  What began in brothels, bars, and back-alleys made its way online, exploiting children in seconds all around the world. He’s personally seen how it devastates families and entire communities if left unchecked. But he’s also starting to see justice.  When you become a Freedom Partner, you send people like John to help protect these children. Help us stop this form of trafficking for good. Become a Freedom Partner: https://bit.ly/3tbSDHV

name: International Justice Mission
content: Today, online sexual exploitation of children is on the rise as the pandemic forces children inside of homes. This form of trafficking remains hidden from the world behind the curtain of the internet. But it travels all around the world in seconds as online predators transfer money in exchange for livestreaming this abuse. IJM has worked alongside Philippine authorities against the pandemic clock to rescue these children and put their abusers behind bars. Together, we’ve helped secure more than 100 convictions for cases of online sexual exploitation of children during the pandemic. But with this ugly crime still on this rise, we need all of us in this fight to stop it. Will you become a Freedom Partner today? https://bit.ly/38r8nyI

name: International Justice Mission
content: Every day, IJM female staff around the world are fighting for women and #ChallengingInjustice.  Violence disproportionately affects women and children. 570 million women around the world are subject to violence every year. These women and young girls need strong justice systems to defend them and safe communities to heal and thrive.  IJM’s brave women fight relentlessly to make this not the norm, working to make sure all have equal access to justice. On International Women’s Day, we’re taking a moment to spotlight those fighting on the frontlines. Read from them how do they challenge injustice: https://bit.ly/38mdeB7

name: International Justice Mission
content: Ahead of International Women’s Day, Jaki, Victoria and Pachaiyammal, who are leaders of the Global Survivor Network, are #ChallengingInjustice and asking governments to #BuildBackSafer societies for women and girls after #COVID19.  They are #WomenFightingForWomen, raising their voices to say violence against women should not be the norm and offering recommendations to build back safer based on their experience. Learn more about the Global Survivor Network: https://bit.ly/34Vjmhm

name: International Justice Mission
content: More than 570 million women are estimated to be subject to violence due to their gender annually.  In the lead up to International Women’s Day, we are #ChallengingInjustice because violence against women should not be the norm. Join us in sharing and raising awareness.

name: International Justice Mission
content: In the Philippines, our teams are relentless in the fight to end the online sexual exploitation of children (OSEC). IJM’s John Tanagho spoke about the need to improve tech and financial platforms’ detection and reporting of OSEC, especially newly produced child sexual exploitation materials and livestreamed abuse. Read the article: https://bit.ly/3e407bo

name: International Justice Mission
content: Meet Grecia and Marco, two of IJM's incredible partners in Bolivia.  These Bolivian lawyers have been trained by IJM to provide pro bono legal support to victims of sexual violence and their families. Already, they've supported multiple cases, including one which resulted in a 21-year conviction. Training others to work alongside us is essential as we seek to scale towards rescuing millions and protecting half a billion by 2030.

name: International Justice Mission
content: #RESCUE – 31 people are now living in FREEDOM after being rescued from #bondedlabor in South Asia! IJM staff supported Foundation for Sustainable Development (FSD) in rescuing 28 adults and three children from a construction site where they had been held in bonded labor for two years. These impoverished families believed they were signing up for good jobs and regular pay. Instead, they were forced to work extreme hours building a hospital and were not allowed to leave. FSD di...scovered the abuse and alerted local government authorities and our team in South Asia. Together, we planned a rescue operation to confirm the laborers’ experience and bring them to a place of safety. Police took one person into custody who may have been involved in the trafficking scheme. Throughout the operation, local officials showed remarkable care and sensitivity to the victim families. They provided hot meals and brought a healthcare team to provide urgent medical care. Authorities also gave the families Release Certificates, which prove their freedom and help them access government benefits. Now, the families have returned to their home! Over the next few weeks, IJM and FSD will support local law enforcement as they build the legal case against the suspect who trapped these families in bonded labor—hopefully ensuring other vulnerable people are protected in the future.

name: International Justice Mission
content: Today, Raju is learning through our IJM aftercare how to be a powerful advocate for his family to gain the rehabilitation rights they are entitled to—including disability benefits for his father who is blind, housing allowances for the family, and ration cards for access to basic food provisions.  “I was 12 years old when the owner promised to pay 12,000 rupees a year for the work he wanted me to do—but I can now make 12,000 rupees in a single month just by working honestly in freedom. My life has really changed.”  This is how we walk alongside survivors for years to come to ensure they can thrive in freedom. And this is the mission people like you fuel day after day when they support us. Thank you! Learn more about this family’s story and how people like you help reunite them: https://bit.ly/3ufIWJO

name: International Justice Mission
content: Imagine taking a small loan to pay for a medical procedure. The person who lends you the money says that if you work on their farm for a few weeks, your debt will be paid. You agree. But after a few weeks on the farm, the person who lent you the money says the interest has grown and you now owe triple the amount of your original loan. And the only payment they accept is your labor.   This is the #TruthAboutTrafficking for bonded labor slavery, and millions of children, women and men are trapped right now. Learn more and see how you can join the fight to help #EndTrafficking: https://bit.ly/1haa2L9

name: International Justice Mission
content: Today is Shine a Light on Slavery Day. And today, more than 40 million people live in slavery.  We're in it to #endit no matter where we're fighting from, and nothing will slow us down. We're not only working all around the world to free people trapped in slavery, we're protecting them from brutal violence.  Will you join us in this fight? Take action and make your voice heard by sending a letter to Congress:https://bit.ly/3pQYLD2

name: International Justice Mission
content: #GOODNEWS – 18 migrant workers who were reportedly held against their will in a confectionary factory have been RESCUED in Bangkok, Thailand by local authorities.  IJM Thailand was informed by Thailand’s Department of Special Investigation (DSI) of a potential human trafficking and forced labor case that DSI had received from the migrant workers’ home embassy. According to the embassy, the workers stated they were illegally brought into the factory and wanted to leave but cou...ld not.   IJM staff assisted officers from DSI, the embassy and other Thai government agencies in a rescue operation at the factory. The officers attempted to call out to the workers who were locked on the upper floors of a building behind locked gates. Eventually, one worker began to climb out over the gate and a ladder was brought, to help him escape. The other migrant workers followed him to freedom, all of whom may be victims of forced labor and human trafficking. IJM Thailand’s legal and aftercare department assisted the freed workers and Thai authorities at the local police station during interviews and processing.  Now, the migrant workers will continue to receive IJM legal and aftercare support as the victim identification process continues. They are currently being cared for and supported by IJM and the government in a safe location.

name: Love146
content: We grieve the events that have taken place in Atlanta. We condemn this and any form of violence - especially violence related to race, gender, misogyny, or work. This was not the result of “a bad day” but systemic and increasing racism against the Asian community and the dehumanization of people because of their work.

name: Love146
content: This week was the one-year anniversary of our team moving into lockdown. Trafficking has not stopped over the last year, and we’re grateful for those who continue to work to end it and support youth. This week, our Prevention Education team had the joy of being able to gather in-person in Houston – and huddle up quickly for a photo! They came together to train even more professionals to reach youth with our prevention education curriculum, Not a Number. In the past year, this team released an up-to-date and even more inclusive 3rd edition of the Not a Number curriculum, and have continued bringing it into new communities across the country.

name: Love146
content: Happy Black History Month! This month, we want to celebrate just a few of the many Black colleagues and partners who are shaping our history as an organization and fighting to address disparities in their work ending child trafficking and helping support children in their vulnerabilities.

name: Love146
content: FBI special agents Daniel Alfin and Laura Schwartzenberger were killed in a shootout in Florida during an investigation into child sexual abuse material. The suspect in the shooting died at the scene. These agents dedicated much of their careers to helping children, especially those impacted by trafficking and exploitation, and made historic impacts. Miami FBI Special Agent in Charge George Piro shared, "Our chosen profession is fraught with danger. Today this grim reality has taken two of our best from our family.”

name: Love146
content: This is a Rapid Response Backpack. When our US Survivor Care Social Workers meet a child for the first time, it's typically at a Rapid Response.  A Rapid Response is a conversation. We talk about the grooming process traffickers use, how to stay safe online, healthy relationships, and ways out of potentially dangerous situations. We listen. We hear more about what they've experienced. Sometimes we practice calling various hotlines together. We give their caregivers and servic...e providers recommendations of what to do next. If that child has been trafficked (or are highly suspected of being trafficked), a Rapid Response is usually the first of much more time we spend with them.  To support, we bring them a backpack. Sometimes that backpack gets a child to sit down with us when they wouldn't have wanted to give us the time of day. Other times, that backpack serves as an important excuse they can use to explain to others why they agreed to talk with us. The backpack is filled with a range of items children and service providers have identified as being critical for this population. Each of the items inside the Backpacks was thoughtfully chosen based on our experience and conversations with others. From nut-free granola bars to fuzzy teddy bears, and alcohol-free hand sanitizer to activity books, each specific item meets health and safety concerns, and was selected to ensure that children receive critical resources as well as the feeling of being valued. Our Long-Term Care clients come to us first through a Rapid Response. But not all youth we meet with move on to receive Long-Term Case. Even for those who don't continue to receive services, a Rapid Response ensures they have information and resources to help them stay safe and supported. Over many years, supporters like you have sent supplies for the backpacks from our Amazon wish list or you’ve come to our office and assembled backpacks for youth. This month, a Rapid Response Backpack went on display at the Bullock Texas State History Museum in Austin Texas, in an exhibit called “Not Alone.” If you’re in Texas and want to go see, it will be on display at the Bullock Museum until the end of May.

name: Love146
content: Each week in January, for #HumanTraffickingPreventionMonth, we’ve looked more closely at one vulnerability. This week, we’re taking about loneliness and isolation. 👤While the series ends this week, what other vulnerabilities to child trafficking stand out to you that could use a deeper look? Comment here and let us know. A key to preventing trafficking is knowing that traffickers use youth's vulnerabilities to target their victims. There are many forces and situations that cause vulnerability in a child’s life. So for each of us, caring about child trafficking means considering and connecting with a web of other issues.

name: Love146
content: This week, let’s talk about employment.  Each week in January we’re looking more closely at one vulnerability. January Human Trafficking PREVENTION Month. A key to preventing trafficking is knowing that traffickers use youth's vulnerabilities to target their victims. There are many forces and situations that cause vulnerability in a child’s life. So for each of us, caring about child trafficking means considering and connecting with a web of other issues.

name: Love146
content: Today for #HumanTraffickingAwarenessDay, we participated in a Twitter chat with @MissingKids and a bunch of other anti-trafficking orgs and activists. Here are a few highlights from the chat. To check out the whole conversation, head over to Twitter and look at the hashtag #HTAD2021 to read through a wealth quick info about ending child trafficking.

name: Love146
content: Monday this week is Human Trafficking Awareness Day & January is Human Trafficking Prevention Month. We’re focusing each week this month on a different issue that’s key to preventing child trafficking. This week, we’re looking at housing insecurity – one of the most common issues that make kids vulnerable to trafficking.

name: Love146
content: January is Human Trafficking Prevention Month. A key to preventing trafficking is knowing that traffickers use youth's vulnerabilities to target their victims. There are many forces and situations that cause vulnerability in a child’s life. So for each of us, caring about child trafficking means considering and connecting with a LOT of other issues. Last year for HT Prevention Month, we addressed some basic facts & myths related to child trafficking. This year, we want to take a look wider than just child trafficking, and talk about other issues that are very much related and critical for prevention. We’re going to focus on just a few common vulnerabilities this month; we’ll share how that issue relates to child trafficking, how COVID has exacerbated it, how our programs respond, and what you can do to help.

name: Love146
content: Most of the world never saw it coming. 2020 took us by surprise. Maybe you’ve been caught off guard this year by loss, grief, fear, uncertainty, sickness, and suffering. At Love146, we can relate. We are living in a really messed-up world and through a really hard year. But there is more to the story. We have also been caught off guard by generosity, perseverance, defiant hope, and even unfiltered joy.  We’ve seen these things profoundly displayed in the lives of the children... and youth we work with. And we have seen it in you. We have heard the oft-used description this year, “essential workers”, which has included everyone from frontline medical professionals to grocery store clerks. The people we can’t live without came clearly into focus. As a supporter of Love146, you are our equivalent of “essential workers.” We simply could not provide the care needed for survivors of child trafficking, or do the work we do to prevent children from being exploited....without you. You sustain this work and your friendship sustains us.  Thank you for helping add so much “beautiful” to a year that had the potential to only be “terrible." You are more than essential. May your new year be filled with more defiant hope and unfiltered joy.

name: Love146
content: Love146 journeys alongside children impacted by trafficking today and prevents the trafficking of children tomorrow. Tag a friend who cares about ending child trafficking!

name: Love146
content: This is a letter from Michelle (a pseudonym), a 19-year-old survivor of sex trafficking. Your donations have provided holistic care for Michelle for the past two years. 2020 has been pretty tough for many of us - especially the children we work with at Love146. But now when they need it most, you're helping children overcome.

Big thanks to @k_fitts11 of the @azcardinals and Britton Colquitt of the @vikings for not just representing @love146 but for remembering a girl who once wore that number – and all those children affected by trafficking #endchildtrafficking #nfl @nfl #vikings #azcardinals #love146 #defianthope #brittoncolquitt #kyliefitts

name: Love146
content: Wow.  Like every day in 2020, we didn’t know what to expect from #GivingTuesday. Knowing circumstances weren’t at all like last year, we still set the same lofty goal: $100,000. This year has been so unpredictable — and that has created real and new vulnerabilities in the lives of children we serve. But your commitment to helping kids is rising to meet the needs. There was cheering last night at 6pm as we reached our goal, and amazement as we woke up this morning to see the #...GivingTuesday 2020 campaign had raised $131K by midnight. We’re speechless at your generosity. Thanks to you, and the Colquitt family who matched your donations, #GivingTuesday raised more than it ever has. We are so moved seeing people give during such extraordinary times… and in such extravagant ways. Because of what you’ve done, more children will be reached by our Prevention Education and Survivor Care programs. It matters for each of them. In the time they need it most, you are helping children overcome.

Even though you’ll probably never meed the young person you’ve impacted, know that a child will feel your support making a difference in their life. https://donate.love146.org/campa…/givingtuesday-2020/c312815

And in 2020, #GivingTuesday means more than it has before. For many, we know your generosity means greater sacrifice – but for the children in our care, the support is more critical than it’s ever been. In the time they need it most, you are helping a child overcome. Don’t forget to give today or tomorrow to be a part of it & your donation will be matched! https://donate.love146.org/campa…/givingtuesday-2020/c312815

name: Love146
content: “What can I do? We get that question almost every day.  I always suggest that you do what you already love to do and find a way to connect it to ending child trafficking. We have so many inspiring examples of people doing just that.  From the 5th grader who sets up a lemonade stand and sends us $14.25, to the NFL Superbowl Champion who kicks a football farther than I can see, who has helped us build #GivingTuesday into the most significant day on our fundraising calendar. The...y are doing what they love and connecting it to building a safer world for children. And that matters! This #GivingTuesday, Britton Colquitt, NFL Superbowl Champion and punter for the Minnesota Vikings along with his wife Nikki and their amazing kids are once again providing a very generous matching gift. And, from today through Tuesday, the Colquitt family will match your gift  $1 for $1. If you share the desire to create a safer world for children, we invite you to give, too. Whether it’s $14.25 or thousands, it matters!” - Rob Morris, Love146 CEO & Co-Founder  Give Today for 2x the impact: https://donate.love146.org/give/312815/#!/donation/checkout

name: Love146
content: When Peggy* says she’s thankful for Love146, that’s you, too. You are one reason that children are giving thanks. We know it’s been a hard year, and perhaps this week looks different for your family. But gratitude is powerful and healing. To our followers in the U.S. who are celebrating, Happy Thanksgiving! Thank you for joining with children on a journey of overcoming.  * * * *... * (*For privacy and protection, Love146 changes names and obscures details about our clients, and no identifiable images in our communications are of children known to be exploited.)

name: Love146
content: Doesn’t it seem like recently we’ve all been spending more time than the usual thinking, talking, and even debating “issues?” We care a lot right now about issues and that’s ok, even good. But behind almost every issue, including child trafficking, is a real person. And behind the name of Love146 is one child.

name: Love146
content: #GivingTuesday is less than 2 weeks away! From right now until Dec 1, you can be a part of raising $100,000 to help end child trafficking! Following a spree of days dedicated to commercial spending like Black Friday, Giving Tuesday is a global day focused on giving back to those in need. And that’s super important this year. 2020 has been tough. We know for many of you, generosity requires greater sacrifice right now. But for the children in our car, your support is more critical than it’s ever been. From now until giving Tuesday, your donation will be doubled by Super Bowl champ and Minnesota Vikings punter Britton Colquitt and his family! Even if you can’t give right now, would you share this post and let people know why you care about ending child trafficking? Give here: https://donate.love146.org/give/312815/#!/donation/checkout

name: Love146
content: Sound on 🔊😌 This is a recording of dawn sounds from our safe home in The Philippines. We hope it gives you a slice of peace today. One of the children who lives here reflected: “Every morning I want to hear the sounds of birds. I am happy whenever I hear them and it makes me feel peaceful. And everyday, I don’t loose hope because I know life is waiting for me. Never waste life.”

name: Love146
content: 2020 began for Love146 with ash raining over our heads, as a nearby volcano began a dangerous eruption near our safe home in The Philippines. As the year progressed, evacuations turned to quarantines. We do not make light of the storms and the threats; indeed sometimes, there are even conditions where you cannot take a deep breath. But today, there were sunny skies over our safe homes while the children continued home school. It was peaceful. When things are cloudy and uncertain, look towards those who love you for bravery. As one child in our survivor care reflected: “All people here on earth have their own hardships, happiness, and chaos in life. I didn’t know if I could bear mine. But when someone is loving you and helping you, you can be brave.”

name: Love146
content: An important read from our friends at Dressember.

name: Love146
content: Days right now at our safe homes in The Philippines are filled with cooking together, remote learning, keeping up with tutorials, tests, and practicing our phonics, virtual Catholic mass for some clients, watching documentaries, tending our farm and animals (and watching chicks hatch!), playing games, singing, and crafts… with plenty of glitter. Safety can look lots of ways, but maybe our safe home doesn’t look so different from some of your homes today. #endchildsextrafficking #homesweethome

name: Love146
content: It’s tomorrow‼️ Whether you’re a teacher, mentor, parent or that awesome aunt or uncle, tomorrow you’ll get some good tips you can use for keeping the young people in your life safe. Sign up now to save your spot. If you can’t be there at the time, it’s ok. We’ll send out the recording afterwards. Click here to register: https://us02web.zoom.us/…/6715990…/WN_M6Ec5Ca6QtOf02S8p-JPOA Drop a ❤️in the comments if you’re signed up!

name: Love146
content: In a world full of hidden (and not so hidden) agendas, we have one. The end of child trafficking and exploitation. Nothing less.

name: Love146
content: Child trafficking is a bipartisan issue and working together to change systems is part of ending it. Believe it or not, combating child trafficking and exploitation is something our national leaders have agreed on for decades. The Trafficking Victims Protection Act (or TVPA) was signed into law by President Bill Clinton in the year 2000. It was reauthorized and strengthened under Presidents Bush, Obama, and Trump and congresses led by both Republicans and Democrats. Love146's... VP of Global Programs, Erin Williamson, serves on the National Advisory Committee on the Sex Trafficking of Children & Youth in the United States. The Committee was appointed by President Obama and launched in 2017, under President Trump. Like most of America, Committee members represent diverse experiences and opinions. We don’t always agree. But, we’ve experienced a remarkable commitment to work through differences and towards solutions and witnessed inspiring collaboration. Many assume that ending child trafficking just requires us — as individuals — to care enough. But that alone won't do it. We also need systems and policies to change. Does that mean systems and policies are trafficking children? No. But it means that if they're working right, they can stop and prevent trafficking. Ending child trafficking will require challenging society's response. This is driven by both individual action and system change.

name: Love146
content: "Republicans and Democrats have historically put real differences aside in service of a greater truth: Americans stand united against human trafficking."

name: Love146
content: "My two youngest daughters were in their room recently with their door closed. I asked, 'Who’s in there?' One replied, 'It’s just us.' We are living in a time that’s increasingly polarized. An “us and them” culture permeates so many areas of our lives. This is especially clear as one of the most contentious elections in recent memory draws closer. So many of us are trying to navigate relationships with friends, family, and co-workers who see the world differently than we do. ...These conversations seem more uncomfortable and harder than ever. This is made worse by separation created by quarantine and our increased reliance on social media, where it’s far easier to be confrontational in a tweet or a Facebook post than when we can sit and talk things over with a friend. At Love146, we have been very deliberate in creating what we call a “big table”. We recognize that people come into the movement to end child trafficking carrying their own opinions and agendas on a ton of different issues. That can create tension, but more often than not, we are inspired by the mix of people willing to join us at the table. Whatever “us” and “them” represent for you, if you care about ending child trafficking then there is a place for you at the table. I get that it’s sometimes really hard to intentionally share space with people who have a different viewpoint than us. But in the end, we hope that each of us here cares more about fighting for children, than we do about fighting against each other. In a world full of hidden (and not so hidden) agendas, we have only one: The end of child trafficking and exploitation. Nothing less. We don’t have all the answers. No one does. We come to the table as learners, and we invite you to do the same, knowing that we will always do what we believe is best for children, based on research and our 18 years of experience. Though we have our differences, maybe now more than ever, we can agree there is value in naming some of the things that bring us together. Ending child trafficking is one of them. When it comes to creating a safer world for children, we really are all in this together. When someone looks into the Love146 room and asks, 'Who’s in there?,' we can together respond with conviction… 'It’s just us.'" - Rob Morris, Love146 CEO & Co-founder

name: Love146
content: When you see something horrific and you want to stop it, there is a difference between being reactionary and making the time to take THOUGHTFUL, COMMITTED steps to change it. We deal with this tension all the time in work to end child trafficking, and we know many of you do as well. And maybe you’ve felt that as you’ve seen viral stories about child trafficking blowing up in the news and on social media. We know that when we react without being thoughtful, it can be less effe...ctive — and sometimes can even cause more harm than good. Dispelling myths and having a clear understanding of the problem is a responsible step we can all take. So if you weren’t able to attend our web series live, start now by watching this session at www.love146.org/web-series. You can also register today for session 2, which will be on October 29th. This next session will shed light on how traffickers can hide in plain sight, will help identify red flags, share tactics traffickers use to recruit children, and discuss practical steps adults and caregivers can take to address the issue: www.love146.org/web-series

name: Love146
content: We don’t just want to tell you how many children we help. We want to assure you that our help makes a lasting impact in their lives. We see that transformation in the stories unfolding for youth and their families, but in order to be accountable to our vision to end child trafficking, we need to be measuring impact and creating effective programs that can be replicated. The University of New Hampshire’s Crimes Against Children Resource Center (CCRC) is one of the most highly ...regarded institutions in answering questions like this with robust methodology. Last week, the U.S. Department of Justice  awarded funds that will allow the CCRC to partner with Love146’s US Survivor Care Program and take first steps towards a rigorous evaluation that will measure its effectiveness. “This can be a difficult population to help,” said study director Lisa Jones, research associate professor of psychology. “Victims often have multiple problems like abusive families, foster care histories, running away and substance abuse. We want to find out if programs are making a difference.” Measuring this work well is not easy, but you deserve answers about the impact of this work, and children deserve it too. This process is not quick. It will take many years, but stay tuned, because we are committed.

name: Love146
content: Here's a snipet from the conversation Our CT Survivor Care Director, Tamarra Clark, had this week with FOX 61. “We call it defiant hope… If we all are so outraged that we get involved, TOGETHER we can end child trafficking.”

name: Love146
content: Our CT Survivor Care Director, Tamarra Clark, had a great conversation with Fox61 this week. She shared about the unique risk factors this year has brought for children and a few practical tips for parents. Along with the rest of us at Love146, and so many of you who are journeying with us, Tamarra has hope that collectively, we can end child trafficking and exploitation. Click the link to watch the video! (Note: No identifiable images in this news segment are of children known to be exploited.)

name: Love146
content: Today is National Child Health Day! First celebrated in 1929, this day was created to increase awareness about the importance of health in children. However, we know that there is more to child’s well-being than what you see with your eyes. Mental health is exceptionally important to a child’s wellness. How does this relate to our work ending child trafficking? Research has found that survivors of child trafficking often experience depression, PTSD, and other mental health is...sues during and after being trafficked. 65% of the children come into our survivor care with a history of mental illness. The cause of experiencing mental health issues in survivors of child trafficking can be due to the duration of their experience, abuse prior to and while being trafficked, social support, and unmet needs. There is little known about the influence of human trafficking on mental health in various genders, races, and ethnic groups. We know that Black and Latinx children and girls are more likely to experience trafficking. Some studies have found that trafficked girls experienced depression and anxiety. However, a lack of research in mental health issues and vulnerable groups leaves unanswered questions and gaps in service provision. As we recognize National Child Health Day, keep in mind the various ways children can be affected by human trafficking and how this information intersects with our work.

name: Love146
content: We’re excited to share that we’ve recently been awarded two grants from the federal government! Both will help us implement the Not a Number curriculum and supportive prevention education programming over the next 3 years. In New York and Connecticut, we’ll be working to reduce and prevent the victimization of girls who are vulnerable to sex trafficking in their juvenile justice systems, funded by the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention. And in the Metro Atlanta area with the DeKalb County School District, we’ll also be working to implement our skill-based prevention training and education for school staff and students, funded through the Office of Trafficking in Persons. We’re ready to get to work in these communities and reach more youth over the coming years!

name: Love146
content: Spots are filling up for folks who want to attend our web series live! Make sure you sign up to save your place! And get ready to take notes as our team dives into the things you need to know to help end child trafficking. And register even if you can’t make those times because you’ll get access to the session recording. Click the link to register: www.love146.org/web-series/  Who do you know who would be interesting in this series? Give them a tag!

name: Love146
content: A message from Matt, one of our teammates here at Love146: The suicide rate in the United States is at its highest in nearly 30 years. Between 40,000-50,000 people will take their own lives this year. For many of us, this hits close to home. I’m one of those. Someone dear to me took their own life. I live with the loss and carry a sadness that I never expect to leave me, along with so many haunting and unanswered questions. Unsurprisingly, suicide is a risk for victims of tra...fficking. In our survivor care program in The Philippines, 30% or more of the children we care for have experienced thoughts of suicide. Here in our US Survivor Care Program, 47% of the survivors we work with have considered suicide and 45% have deliberately harmed their body - for example, cut or burned themselves - to cope with intense emotional feelings and pain. Those are crushing numbers. It’s those numbers that make me so deeply grateful for my front line colleagues at Love146, working everyday with children who might be considering suicide or self-harm. At Love146, we provide wrap around, holistic care for those working through the immense trauma of child trafficking. My co-workers are there everyday, helping a child filled with potential know they are loved and learn to respond to temporary (but really hard) circumstances without feeling like their only options are suicide or self-harm. Love146 is there to show children who have been trafficked another way forward. We don’t ever want those who love these children to live with the loss, sadness, and haunting “what if?”, questions that too many of us know too well. When you give to Love146, you’re providing  protection and care for individual children, ranging in age from infants and toddlers to teens and young adults, who have been trafficked and exploited or are at risk.

name: Love146
content: “I don’t think about it so that I won’t be afraid, and I just pray that there won’t be any more victims of the virus.” - A 7-year-old in Love146's program for children recovering from child trafficking Many children, including the survivors in our care, are going back to school – in-person, virtually, and in homeschool settings. The choices aren’t easy and however you’re navigating this, there’s anxiety for caregivers, and sometimes the child too. No one has done this before, and it's hard. Thank you for supporting the children in your own family, community – and even in our Survivor Care around the world – during this time. 💕

name: Love146
content: You’ve been probably hearing a lot about child trafficking lately. It can get confusing as you look through various articles, blogs, and online discussions. That’s why we put together a free web series to make sure that you’ve got accurate info to do your part protecting kids. Love146 has almost two decades of experience; we’ve journeyed with hundreds of child trafficking survivors and we’ve reached thousands of kids through our trafficking prevention curriculum. In a couple of webinars, we’ll use that experience to give you some useful info. So join us on October 1st & 29th.  Register at www.love146.org/web-series  — and register even if you can’t make those dates, because you’ll get access to the session recording.

name: Love146
content: Many survivors of child trafficking enter adulthood without a stable housing situation. COVID has heightened this vulnerability. A lot of the youth we’ve worked with are reaching back out to us during this time concerned about housing and revictimization. Last week, we joined Senator Blumenthal and Community Solutions, Inc. to celebrate funding towards this critical gap.

name: Love146
content: Raise your hand if you read the whole article before commenting.

name: Love146
content: Our VP of Global Programs, Erin Williamson will be presenting at a national webinar hosted by the Department of Education. We want to encourage any of followers who work within the educational system to attend the webinar. Here is the description: In this dynamic webinar, subject matter experts who work directly with survivors of trafficking and those who support them will address questions compiled from the most recent webinar which addressed online safety. It will provide o...pportunity for deeper discussion of topics raised by past participants and provide tips and strategies for school staff members in addressing human trafficking. The event is designed to provide administrators, teachers, specialized instructional support personnel, parents, caregivers, and students with trauma-informed and survivor-centered information to help protect students from online trafficking activity. Speakers featured in this webinar will include:  • Savannah Sanders, founder, Sex Trafficking Prevention and Lived Experience Expert;  • Erin Williamson, VP of global programs at Love146; and • Tanya Street, founder, Identifiable Me and Lived Experience Expert. In addition, Ruth Ryder, Deputy Assistant Secretary at the U.S. Department of Education, will briefly share the Department’s commitment to addressing human trafficking, including upcoming activities. Dr. Shauna Knox, the Department’s lead on human trafficking, will moderate the event. Click the link to register: https://us02web.zoom.us/…/register/WN_5likb623SgKbhMFZIn3haA

name: Love146
content: Trafficking is often not the first thing to go wrong in a child’s life. It is often the convergence of many other problems that we need to be addressing as a society in order to prevent it from happening and support survivors. As we come together to address the issue of trafficking it's important to remember that for a child, one trauma is no more or less important than another.  There are many risks and systemic forces contributing to children’s vulnerability, and we must work hard to address every one of them.

name: Love146
content: People from every perspective and walk of life can agree that child trafficking is horrible, and that children should not be exploited and sold. That consensus is a powerful thing. And it can be exploited, too.

name: Love146
content: The well-being of children is at core of our work, the forefront of our minds, and they’re the determining factor of every decision we make. Thank you for your support. It's phenomenally important in the lives of children affected by trafficking.

name: Love146
content: Today, July 30th, is the United Nations’ World Day against Trafficking in Persons. Here is a powerful message from the Secretary General of the UN, António Guterres:  “This year’s World Day against Trafficking in Persons honours the first responders helping to end the crime of human trafficking: law enforcement officers, social workers, healthcare professionals, NGO staff and many others working around the world to protect the vulnerable. Like the frontline heroes saving live...s and sustaining our societies in the COVID-19 pandemic, these providers are keeping vital services going throughout the crisis -- identifying victims, ensuring their access to justice, health, social assistance and protection, and preventing further abuse and exploitation… If the world is to put human dignity and human rights at the centre of the COVID-19 response and recovery, we need to do more to protect trafficking victims and prevent vulnerable people from being exploited by criminals. On this World Day against Trafficking in Persons, let us pledge to work for inclusive societies and economies that leave no one behind.” #humantrafficking #worlddayagainsttrafficking #covid19 #humanrights #recovery #humandignity #covidresponse

name: Love146
content: An important read.

name: Love146
content: Trafficking has been happening forever. But in the 1990’s human trafficking got a name and moved into conversations in human rights circles. Only in the year 2000 was it recognized as a crime by the US Government & the United Nations. Love146 and many other activists on this issue began to come alive at this time in history.  When the world named it, and began noticing that it was occurring to so many people - including millions of children - it felt awful. When we start shin...ing a light on something it can seem like the problem is intensifying or it seems worse to those who had never noticed it. We hear people say things like “This wasn’t happening back in the old days.” But this is not true. Bygone eras weren't better times. For some, realizing there's a problem does give the feeling that world is getting worse. Even though that isn’t necessarily true, your feelings about this problem do matter! Your rage, indignation, determination, defiant hope, it all matters — especially what you do next with it. The more clearly we understand what is wrong, the better we can take action to build a safer world for children, and everyone.

name: Love146
content: We asked a 12-year-old boy in our Survivor Care program, “What is the most beautiful thing in the world to you?” He said, “Just to be happy. Like, enjoy playing together with your friends and family because they are the ones who make you happy.” This is a recent photo of some of the boys in our Survivor Care in the Philippines; playing on the rooftop of the safe home.  It’s trying times, but remember the things that are beautiful to you. ...And know that YOU are part of what makes the world more beautiful and happy for someone else out there.

name: Love146
content: Queer youth are especially vulnerable to exploitation and disproportionately trafficked for sex. LGBTQ+ identifying youth experience higher rates of violence, discrimination, and homelessness. Because of this, they are vulnerable to predators who would offer a sense of acceptance, belonging, safety, or security in return for other “favors.” A big part of the equation is the ostracizing of LGBTQ+ children, many of whom are shunned by their families, bullied by peers, denied ac...cess to resources because of their identity, and have gotten messages from society that there is something wrong with them. And in this scenario, Pride — yes, with a capital “P” — matters. When we accept, support, and are proud of children for who they are, we will see the numbers of trafficked and exploited youth, including LGBTQ+ youth, drop. Our Not a Number prevention curriculum is written to be inclusive, and address the trafficking of all youth, including LGBTQ+. We stand with all queer youth, not just for June’s Pride Month, but tomorrow, and all year long.

name: Love146
content: Over recent months, our prevention team has been conducting professional human trafficking trainings remotely, and discussing with Not a Number curriculum facilitators across the country how to engage youth while they are being schooled from home, with a focus on keeping them safe as they spend more time online. But a few weeks ago, we were able to do an in-person Not a Number facilitator certification training! With participants in the training spaced apart and wearing masks, we pushed forward in equipping 11 new facilitators to reach youth with our Not a Number prevention curriculum. Thank you for sticking with us — and with children — as we all persevere through the pandemic with a focus on stopping exploitation. We continue to remain responsive on a case by case basis with our trainings, as conditions change.

name: Love146
content: 5 years ago, a former Love146 intern, a current Love146 board member, and a Love146 staff member came to the Love146 office after hours for a passion project and collaborated to make this video. 5 years later, it is still just as relevant.

name: Love146
content: Many apps, including Facebook, come with not enough privacy, even for children. It’s insanely easy for predators to open an account with a fake identity, and send out lots of friend requests. Some of us want as many online friends as possible, and will hit “accept” even if we’re not sure we know them. Now the predator, who could even be posing as a teen, can friend request all those kids’ friends, and, as a “mutual friend,” gain their trust, and freely lurk in order to identi...fy the most vulnerable to target. Armed with buckets of intimate info from reading a child’s posts, the predator can appear as a sensitive friend, a potential love interest, or someone who can offer an escape from a bad situation. The good news: you can take simple steps to stay safe. Start by checking the privacy settings in any social media or gaming apps you use. On Facebook especially, go to “Settings” and select “Privacy.” We suggest changing “Who can send you friend requests” to “Friends of friends” (the most private setting) and “Who can see your friends list” to “Only me.” For instructions on how to change the privacy settings on other social networks, apps, and web browsers, check out The National Cyber Security Alliance at https://staysafeonline.org/…/mana…/manage-privacy-settings/…

name: Love146
content: This week at Love146: We are relieved to report that the impact on our safe homes from the recent typhoon in the Philippines was minimal, and that all staff, children, and farm animals are safe. Check out this and other stories of hope and progress from our work to end child trafficking and exploitation. - https://mailchi.mp/love146/may2020-52020

name: Love146
content: These days, staying in touch with our friends and loved ones is really important. It’s just as important for children — and that’s OK. Their desire and even need to be connected isn’t a problem — it’s actually healthy. But as adults, we can’t help but be concerned about our children getting tangled up online with people who want to harm them. How you approach talking with them is just as important as what you want to tell them. Here’s how we frame the conversation with youth ...that we’ve found to be effective. We’ll start by saying, “This may not have happened to you. This may not happen to you in the future. But this is what we've seen happen to other youth.” Then we share information about safety planning. And let them know to be careful. Just in case. And keep the lines of communication open. Visit www.love146.org/staysafe for more tips.

name: Love146
content: While we’re sheltering in, it can be easy to feel distant and isolated in every way, instead of only physically distant. Reaching out to a friend, those you love, and those who may have helped you out in the past can make you feel less isolated. Sometimes hearing a familiar voice even by phone or video call can provide us with a sense of safety. If you haven’t heard from them in a while, don’t let it stop you: they may be struggling, too. Now is the time to stay connected to ...people who can support you. Remember, though, that not everyone you meet is safe. While you’re chatting online, it’s good to be especially careful. Here are some of the red flags that a relationship isn't healthy: 🚩The person asks you to DM them, or chat through a private channel, like WhatsApp.  🚩They ask if you are alone 🚩They ask you to send them a pic.  🚩They offer you a job where you can “earn money fast.” 🚩They threaten you if you don’t do what they ask. If you get these or similar messages from someone you’re well connected to or can’t separate from, get help by calling the CyberTipline at 1-800-843-5678. If this is an online connection and you can block them and unfriend them, do that. Here’s a place to check out more redflags: https://love146.org/action/online-safety/

name: Love146
content: COVID-19 makes online safety more important than ever. Here’s a tip to stay safe for you, or to pass along to youth in your life: If you ever feel uncomfortable or think that something is sketchy, tell an adult you trust! Whether it’s a teacher, a parent, or a school counselor. It’s better to talk to someone about it now, even if it means you have to confess something you did or it’s difficult to share. If you wait it could become a bigger problem. You can also talk to someon...e and get help anonymously by calling the CyberTipline at 1-800-843-5678. As a general rule, just as you wouldn’t walk down dark alleys alone at night try to avoid sites and apps that seem a little sketchy. You could stumble on photos or videos you don’t want to see (or maybe are even illegal!), or end up connecting with people who are looking to take advantage of you. Trust your gut, and don’t walk down the alleyways of the Internet. ••• For more tips on staying safe online, go to www.love146.org/staysafe

name: Love146
content: COVID-19 makes online safety more important than ever. Here’s a tip to stay safe for you, or to pass along to youth in your life: Be a tiny bit paranoid that what you send or post could be reshared — now, or in the future. Because once you post something, a picture or a few embarrassing sentences, you can’t always control how it will be seen — or whether it’ll be shared by others. If you feel like there’s any chance that a picture or post could get into the wrong hands, don’t... risk it, don’t share or post it. If anyone ever threatens to share something private of yours — unless you do something else they’re demanding — that’s called Sextortion. It’s real, and you can get help. You can also talk to someone and get help anonymously by calling the CyberTipline at 1-800-843-5678, or visit www.stopsextortion.com. ••• For more tips on staying safe online, go to www.love146.org/staysafe

name: Love146
content: Here’s a tip for you, or to pass along to youth in your life: Pay attention to your own mental, emotional, and physical health, and notice the things you do that help you feel better when you need a lift. This kind of “self-care” is something most of us don’t do enough of in day-to-day life, and it’s even harder when times get tough. Think about things like listening to music, going for a walk, drawing, exercising, writing in a journal, or yoga. Whatever works for you.  Then ...write them down for when you need a reminder. The more of these kinds of coping skills the better! Each coping skill is a tool in your toolbox. If a sad, scared, or angry thought comes to your mind, that’s OK! Feel it, allow the tough feeling to pass through, and breathe through it until the wave passes. If the wave doesn’t pass, think of the activities that help lift your spirits. If one tool doesn’t work, try others until you feel a little better.

name: Love146
content: COVID-19 makes online safety more important than ever. Here’s a tip to stay safe for you, or to pass along to youth in your life: One good thing about being online is that you have some control over who you share info with. If you’re talking to or being followed by people who aren’t your close friends  avoid posting things that reveal how to find you in real life (like the name of your school, where your soccer team practices, etc). Sometimes, “friends” online are not who the...y seem to be, so it’s also smart to make sure that your user name or handle is different from your real name, that way if you get into a conversation that’s making you uncomfortable you can exit it without the fear of someone tracking you down. And if someone is sketchy, you shouldn’t hesitate to unfriend them, block them, or report them! After all, that’s exactly why these tools exist. For more tips on staying safe online, go to https://love146.org/staysafe/

name: Love146
content: We want to share a happy update from our work in the in Philippines!  The Round Home is a place for children recovering from sex trafficking. The children help tend the farm animals and the gardens at the home. This is primarily a part of our holistic approach to therapy, but an added benefit is that this practice has made the home somewhat self-sustaining. While the children are learning to nurture, they are also helping to meet their own physical needs amidst sudden local s...carcity. Meanwhile, the children are processing the instability of our world and that can be especially difficult for survivors of child trafficking. But our workers are there with them, finding therapeutic messages during this global crisis that will help the children to persevere in their healing journey. To learn more about how Love146 is supporting children globally, visit www.love146.org

name: Love146
content: COVID-19 makes online safety more important than ever. Here’s a tip to stay safe for you, or to pass along to youth in your life. Think of it this way – when you’re hanging out online it’s like being in your own room. If you want privacy in your room, you can shut your door. Unfortunately, most websites, social media apps, or gaming devices come to you with the door wide open so that anybody, even creeps, can chat with you. (Worst of all, sometimes it’s almost impossible to tell that they’re creeps.) But you can take steps to help keep them out. Most websites, apps, and games have settings that allow you to shut the door. You just need to change your privacy settings so that only your real friends can connect with you.  If you need help learning how to do this, or for other online safety tips, go to https://love146.org/staysafe/.

name: Love146
content: It’s May 10th! On this day 1 month ago, there were literally 20x the number of donations we see on a typical day! Why? On April 10th, we introduced “10 on the 10th,” a movement within the Love146 family to simply give $10 on the 10th day of the month to protect children. It was a stunning number of you showing up and giving what you can to send a clear message: children impacted by trafficking are a priority right now. This is the collective power of Love146 friends and family. Can you give just $10 today? Small gestures, multiplied, make an inspiring impact. www.love146.org/10

name: Love146
content: Every child who’s been trafficked is someone's child. Today, in the midst of the COVID-19 crisis, there are mothers of survivors we care for who can get support for urgent needs, like rent & groceries. That’s because people like you are still giving what they can to care for survivors and reduce children's vulnerability. Your donations mean that together, we are holding steady for children during this crisis. #HappyMothersDay to all of you life-giving women.

name: Love146
content: Thank you! The Great Give was a success. Your generosity will help care for children in our community who have been affected by trafficking. Even though you'll probably never meet the young people you‘ve impacted, know that there’s a child who will feel your support making a difference in their life. Thank you for helping us give children the care and encouragement they deserve. #TheGreatGive... #love146

name: Love146
content: There are still 12 hours left to make a donation through The Great Give’s 36-hour fundraising campaign and help child survivors of trafficking in your community. During the instability and stress of this pandemic, it’s more important than ever to be there for vulnerable children. Your donation to Love146 is a lifeline that sends a clear message to a child affected by trafficking: “We’re in this together.” The Great Give ends at 8 p.m. so donate now! https://www.thegreatgive.o...rg/…/love146-8c901ff4-302b-4e48-9… Please share this fundraiser with your friends and family and help make a safer world for children. #TheGreatGive #love146

name: Love146
content: The Great Give 36-hour fundraising campaign is on now. Your gift to Love146 supports our work caring for survivors of trafficking in the 20 towns served by the Community Foundation of Greater New Haven, from Shelton to Madison. Love146 is the primary provider of Survivor Care for domestic victims of child trafficking in Connecticut. Child trafficking is not just an “issue” or a “cause” involving mind-numbing stats. It’s about someone’s daughter or son. Someone who might live ...in your town. Especially during these difficult times, your gift will help a child in your community find stability, hope, and a brighter future as they recover from trafficking. Give now: https://www.thegreatgive.org/…/love146-8c901ff4-302b-4e48-9… Please share this fundraiser with your friends and family and help make a safer world for children. #TheGreatGive #love146

name: Love146
content: Today is #GivingTuesdayNow. As a response to the unprecedented need caused by COVID-19, The GivingTuesday community has called for #GivingTuesdayNow – a global day of generosity & unity. When coronavirus struck, it quickly became apparent that for many of the survivors in our care, getting basic needs met was going to be a challenge and this puts children at risk of being trafficked again. During this critical time, your donations are meeting survivors’ very practical needs: ...You’ve paid rent. You’ve bought groceries. You’ve sent hygiene products. You’ve ensured survivors have the school supplies needed to keep persevering in their education. And in the Philippines, you've ensured survivors have all their needs met while sheltering in our safe home. And your donations have gone beyond practical needs, providing continued care and connection for survivors. Your donations protect children. Be a part of this movement of generosity & consider a gift of anything you can this #GivingTuesdayNow.  Give at https://donate.love146.org/givingtuesdaynow2020

name: Love146
content: Give where your heart is! #TheGreatGive officially kicks off tomorrow, Tuesday, May 5th at 8 a.m. for a 36-hour giving campaign (but is open for donations now!). In these challenging times victims of child sex trafficking need you more than ever. It’s critical that together we hold steady for children. Love146 has directly impacted more than 500 children who have been affected by trafficking across all regions of Connecticut, including many from Greater New Haven and the surr...ounding area. Your gift through the Great Give will fill a critical need in supporting children in your area who are recovering from the experience of being trafficked or exploited. And it will send a clear message to a child affected by trafficking: “We’re in this together.” GIVE NOW: https://www.thegreatgive.org/…/love146-8c901ff4-302b-4e48-9… #TheGreatGive #love146

name: Love146
content: This week, our US Programs Director, Erin Williamson, presented in a National Listening Session hosted by the Department of Health & Human Services Office on Trafficking in Persons. This session focused on Preventing Online Child Sexual Exploitation. Erin talked about the fact that right now, we’re online more. For youth, increased internet use is critical for education. It’s keeping youth (and all of us) connected with friends. All that is important. But being online more al...so has risks. Now, of all times, it’s NOT the time for us to shame using the internet —  but it IS the time for us to talk to youth about online sa fety. Erin, along with leaders from @Thorn and New Jersey State Police, shared for over an hour altogether, focused specifically on stopping online exploitation. It was a powerful and insightful time for professionals to connect on the topic and ask questions — and here is a short clip from our time together.  @hhsgov acf_gov @newjerseystatepolice  #lookbeneaththesurface

name: Love146
content: This is a completely unique and scary experience humanity is sharing. It’s going to be intense. We thought you may need to hear some of the same messages we’re giving children in our care right now. This video features Love146’s Survivor Care workers. We’re locked down in our safe home in the Philippines with children, and in the US  and UK have been meeting with youth on video chats and lots of texting. We’re listening. We’re meeting a variety of urgent needs. And we’re being present through the ups and downs of this experience. Your donations mean that survivors of child trafficking continue to get this message from someone they trust – when they need it most. To give, visit www.love146.org/give

name: Love146
content: Thank you! Give Local Greater Waterbury and Litchfield Hills was a success. Your generosity helps to care for children in our community who have been affected by trafficking. Even though you'll probably never meet the young people you‘ve impacted, know that there is a child who will feel your support making a difference in their life. Thank you for helping us give children the care and encouragement they deserve. #givelocalGWLH...  #love146

name: Love146
content: Love146 is a human rights organization… we work with humans; and frankly with work with a very very specific problem. But we know that everything is connected; intersectional. Including the environment. And so nature and the earth finds its way into our Survivor Care programs in many ways. 🌏 We bring youth to wilderness school, for snowshoeing treks, ropes courses, and mountain hikes. We do beach retreats. We climb volcanoes on horseback. We have a farm in the Philippines tha...t children help tend to. Goats and chickens and catfish and other animals that they care for. We do beekeeping! (With stingless bees, of course). We incorporate caring for others – and the earth – as a way to allow the children to be active participants in restoring the world around them. And discovering, in a deeper way, their own power. The children also use reflection on nature as a part of their healing process. So we’ll leave you this Earth Day with a few quotes from children, about how the earth itself sparks their realizations of recovery: 🌾 “I’m like the grass: even though it is stepped on again and again, it rises again and again. It can be cut down, but it grows back. The grass refuses to stay down. Like me.” 🌊 “I’m like the sea. The sea is full of life and beauty, and no matter what it is done to it, it is still a sea. Like the sea, I will always rise. No one can make the sea smaller.” 🌳 “I used to be like this leaf. When the storm comes the leaves of the tree fall. Just like the times when I felt that I was the tree whose leaves all fell — hopeless. I felt that my life was hopeless. ...But now, I’m different. I’m like a strong tree that no one can fool anymore. I can not be downtrodden and laughed at anymore...It was here that I felt loved. It was here that I became strong. It was here that I learned how to be loved.”

name: Love146
content: There’s still 12 hours left to make a donation through Give Local Greater Waterbury and Litchfield Hills’ 36-hour fundraising campaign and help survivors of trafficking in your community. During the instability and stress of this pandemic, it’s more important than ever to be there for vulnerable children. Love146 is the primary provider of Survivor Care for victims of child trafficking in Connecticut. Child trafficking is not just an “issue” or a “cause” involving mind-numbing stats.
