name: Love146
content: We’re participating in Connecticut Community Foundation’s Give Local Greater Waterbury and Litchfield Hills, the 36-hour statewide giving movement, starting tomorrow, Tuesday, April 21st. We’re reaching out to you because in these difficult times victims of child sex trafficking need Love146 more than ever. It’s critical that we hold steady for them. Love146 has directly impacted more than 500 children who have been affected by trafficking across all regions of Connecticut, i...ncluding many from the Greater Waterbury and Litchfield Hills area. Your gift through Give Local will fill a critical need in supporting children in your area who are recovering from the experience of being trafficked or exploited. And it will send a clear message to a child affected by trafficking: “We’re in this together.” DONATE: https://www.givelocalccf.org/…/love146-200d6531-9a9f-4bfe-a… #givelocalGWLH #love146

name: Love146
content: Earlier this year in the Philippines, we gathered the children in our Survivor Care and evacuated to remain safe from the eruption of a nearby volcano. Now, because of COVID-19, we’re sheltering in place in our safe homes. 2020 has been difficult because one of the most important things for children recovering from trauma is stability. It’s a struggle — and we know that our presence and calm in the chaos is what we must offer right now. The safe home is like an oasis. I’ve al...ways said: A safe home should be safe, and a safe home should be a home. And that is truer today than ever: children must know they will not experience danger or lack right now. We are defending them. Even before it was ordered, the children were pulled from school, and are homeschooling. While the daily activities are structured around education, even though we’ve locked down the safe home, everybody is having fun. All staff now stay in, except for those who are buying food. Food access locally is an issue for us and many supermarkets are skeletal at this point, so we’re relying more and more on our own safe home farm. We have chickens, catfish ponds, beekeeping, mushroom growing, and many vegetables from our farm. We use moringa and papaya leaves grown on our property to boost immunity. We’ve always used our garden and farm therapeutically, but they mean even more to the children now. What also means so much is knowing we are all in this together as humanity. That includes you. So in that spirit, let these words directly from the children in our care encourage you today, as we survive together: “You need to fight. Strengthen your body’s resistance and be brave. Do not panic and avoid crowds.” “What the world experiences today will soon end. It will turn into light, and the fear that the people feel will soon be gone.” Thank you for being steady for children during this time when they need it.

name: Love146
content: Join us today at 4PM PST / 7PM EST for a Q&A call about COVID-19 and trafficking. On the call will be #Love146 founder Rob Morris, along with Amanda Eckhardt, Ph.D., the Executive Director of Restore NYC, a nonprofit serving survivors of sex trafficking in New York City. This event will be hosted and moderated by our friends at Dressember Foundation, a community of thousands of advocates that started around the simple act of wearing a dress every day in December. ••• Register at https://bit.ly/3al5ldD.

name: Love146
content: “The only hope we have is our children and the seeds we give them and the gardens we plant together.” — Richard Brautigan .... We see the beauty of the future garden in every child we care for. #DefiantHope

name: Love146
content: “It was dark when Binh and I started delivering the boxes – we know the young people worry about where and how they will get food, so we will get it to them – whatever the time of day.” – Lynne Chitty, Love146 Director of UK Survivor Care Throughout this pandemic the youth in our care are processing their anxieties and worries. And one of those is food. Will they have enough food? How will they get it? Many of us can empathize with this right now. In the Philippines, were growing a lot of food in our gardens. In the US, grocery gift cards are going out constantly. And in the UK, we'd love to thank our dedicated care staff & local grocery workers- our food #heroes of this week. 🥬🥛🍎 Thank you for coming together to hold steady for children in our care.

name: Love146
content: Introducing: $10 on the 10th. Today, on April 10th, (and again on May 10th and June 10th) would you give just ten bucks? We want to give you and every other person who's part of the Love146 community a chance to say the one most encouraging thing you can say to a child right now: “I’m still here.” Really, we get it. It seems ridiculous to ask for money when we’re all struggling and the future seems uncertain. But in the midst of crisis, we see the very best in people shine through. We see people rise up. We see the collective power of Love146 friends and family. We see small gestures, multiplied, make an inspiring impact. Give at www.love146.org/10

name: Love146
content: Introducing: $10 on the 10th. Today, on April 10th, (and again on May 10th and June 10th) would you give just ten bucks? We want to give you and every other person who's part of the Love146 community a chance to say the one most encouraging thing you can say to a child right now: “I’m still here.” Really, we get it. It seems ridiculous to ask for money when we’re all struggling and the future seems uncertain. But in the midst of crisis, we see the very best in people shine th...rough. We see people rise up. We see the collective power of Love146 friends and family. We see small gestures, multiplied, make an inspiring impact. A simple gift of $10 sends a clear message to a child: We’re in this together. Give at www.love146.org/10

name: Love146
content: You’re not really supposed to leave your house at the moment. So you’re spending a lot more time online. Here's the deal though: There are creeps out there and they're spending more time online too. They may pretend to be your age and act like they’re your friend. They could seem cool at first, and then things can turn bad. We work with a lot of young people who met their traffickers online. The good news is that, just like with COVID-19, you can take steps to protect yourself and still stay connected online. Check out love146.org/staysafe for 5 practical tips on how to avoid traffickers.

name: Love146
content: Survivors of child trafficking, dancing during lockdown to #LeanOnMe. No truer words than Bill Withers’ here: “Sometimes in our lives we all have pain, we all have sorrow. But if we are wise, we know that there's always tomorrow. Lean on me, when you're not strong. And I'll be your friend, I'll help you carry on. For it won't be long 'til I'm gonna need somebody to lean on. You just call on me brother, when you need a hand, we all need somebody to lean on. I just might have a problem that you'll understand. We all need somebody to lean on.” #RestInPower #BillWithers

name: Love146
content: As our team comes to the end of week 3 of a new way of working and living, we leave you with these words from author EB White: "As long as there is one upright man, as long as there is one compassionate woman, the contagion (hope) may spread and the scene is not desolate. Hope is the thing that is left to us, in a bad time. I shall get up in the morning and wind the clock, as a contribution to order and steadfastness. Sailors have an expression about the weather: they say, th...e weather is a great bluffer. I guess the same is true of our human society — things can look dark, then a break shows in the clouds, and all is changed, sometimes rather suddenly. It is quite obvious that the human race has made a mess of life on this planet. But as a people we probably harbor seeds of goodness that have lain for a long time waiting to sprout when the conditions are right. Man’s curiosity, his relentlessness, his inventiveness, his ingenuity have led him into deep trouble. We can only hope that these same traits will enable him to claw his way out. Hang on to your hat. Hang on to your hope. And wind the clock, for tomorrow is another day.”

name: Love146
content: When we come into the lives of survivors, they are often hesitant. They’ll even ask: “Will you be here tomorrow? Will you be there if I move across the state? Will you be here next week? next month? next year?” Thanks to your support, we can answer with a resounding: “YES.”  ...We’ve never had a youth ask us if we’ll be there when a pandemic strikes. But the answer is still yes. Yes, of course. This is our mission. The isolation we are all dealing with because of COVID-19 is ...particularly fraught for children who have experienced the trauma of being exploited. They’re cut off from many of their supports and may feel more anxious, worried, trapped, and some are attempting to run from the situation. But the children in our care know: We will always be there for them.  Because of your gift, children affected by trafficking are more equipped to navigate the challenges of this pandemic. They will continue to receive the love and care they need to know that they have a future, no matter what their past or present circumstances look like. www.love146.org/give

name: Love146
content: March is #NationalSocialWorkMonth. First responders run towards a crisis instead of away from it. COVID-19 shows us that grocery store workers, neighborhood clinic staff, and social workers are now heroes. Our team shows up every day for the survivors in our care. This looks like connecting on calls, video chats, and lots of texting. We’re listening, providing for immediate needs, and supporting their families. To all social workers: Thank you for what you do.

name: Love146
content: The COVID-19 pandemic is affecting all of us, including children. What was startling about watching the economic downturn 12 years ago in 2008 was realizing that kids would have such increased vulnerability. This crisis is showing even more severe impacts. Many children and families are cut-off from school meals and food pantries. People will be newly facing homelessness. Children won’t be able to see the teachers, coaches, youth group leaders, and counselors who made them fe...el safe. Children who are used to connection and excitement may experience a void. These are the same factors that make children at increased risk of trafficking. Kids need food, safe places to call home, and nurturing people to provide stability and support. If you and I aren't providing that for them a predator could be. Love146 will continue to hold steady for the survivors in our care today, and we know our prevention work has strengthened thousands of children already.  While our frontline staff are still serving youth, it will take more than one dedicated organization to support all the children who need help. If there are youth you’ve been connected to, keep reaching out to them across the physical distance. If your school system isn't putting plans in place to make sure kids have meals, you could be that voice. If your town isn't talking about how to support families and provide stability and connection, you could be that voice. I don't have all the answers, but we must do our part in making sure that the people who are making decisions know that we care, that kids matter, and that this is a top priority to us all.

name: Love146
content: Children are spending more time on social media and online games these days while home from school during the Covid 19 pandemic, leaving them more exposed to online predators. Our experience tells us that children meet and communicate with traffickers online, as this public alert by the FBI states. For tips on how to help the children you're caring for stay safe, visit our online safety guide at https://love146.org/action/online-safety/.

name: Love146
content: A few years ago, a teen in our care did some writing she passed along to us. One thing she said was: "Love146 will never abandon me, because Love146 is my family.” Many of you have reached out with concerns about COVID-19. During this pandemic, we are committed to staying a constant in a child’s life. One thing that’s clear: the needs of children won’t go away. As schools and many community activities close, many children will spend more time online. This is where most youth ...in our care met their traffickers. They may be more lonely, stressed, or even burdened by added financial strain their families will go through. Traffickers see opportunity here and certainly won’t stop working right now. We cannot stop working either. We’re being responsive as new information becomes clear. But these are the present steps we’re taking to keep our staff and the children we care for as safe as possible. Children in our safe homes in the Philippines are all moving to homeschooling. We’ll continue to connect with and be available for youth in the US Survivor Care program. We're still getting calls about children who need help, and we're answering those calls. Our offices are working from home and avoiding mass transit. Trainings, meetings, and events over the coming months are being handled case by case, and we’re watching closely to decide what gets cancelled and postponed. If you’re wondering how you can help right now, the biggest need is to hold steady in our commitment to be there for children. The weeks ahead will be stressful. It will be easy for many people to put charitable giving aside, and many nonprofits are understandably worried. One of the best things you can do today is give whatever you can. If you haven’t yet, set up a monthly gift, of whatever amount you can. And right now, still, there is a donor who is adding $100 to your first monthly gift. www.love146.org/monthly Many of us are rightfully concerned about those we love who are vulnerable because of their advanced age or compromised immune systems. Having experienced complex trauma is also a vulnerability that can impact our body’s ability to fight off disease. Know that the support you’ve given to protect children and help survivors recover from trauma is an investment in more resilience through this and future trials.

name: Love146
content: Right now, a generous matching donor will give $100 for the first 146 new or upgraded monthly donors!  When you give monthly to Love146 you are, in essence, joining hands with children. Not just for a moment, but in an ongoing, consistent, meaningful way. That kind of commitment is absolutely essential to sustaining this work for the long haul. And that’s what it means to journey hand-in-hand with children. It is reassuring, comforting, and a powerful expression of love. Thank you for joining together with children and extending your hand.  www.love146.org/monthly

name: Love146
content: Today is #InternationalWomensDay, and this generous mamma is matching your donations, but only for this weekend! The survivors in our care are 85% women and girls. Stand up for children impacted by gender-based violence. www.love146.org/women

name: Love146
content: This Sunday is Women's Day. Surprise your partner, friend, grandma, or boss with a Love146 e-card!  This weekend, every donation you make for an e-card will be doubled!! E-cards are simple and wonderful gifts; and they provide support for children affected by trafficking. www.love146.org/women

name: Love146
content: March is #WomensHistoryMonth, and this Sunday – March 8th – is #InternationalWomensDay! This week, your gifts will have 2x the impact thanks to one generous anonymous woman. Give – and even pick out an ecard to honor a special woman in your life – at www.love146.org/women.

We’re reflecting on what it means to journey hand-in-hand, and we’re asking you to join hands with children by giving monthly to #Love146. When you sign up for ANY amount, Love146 will receive an extra $100 immediately from Export Solutions Inc.! Make the difference:... www.love146.org/monthly

name: Love146
content: Because we all refuse to stand for it – and are LISTENING to victims – justice is catching up to high-profile abusers. Recent news reports allege that fashion exec Peter Nygard may be added to a list of exploiters like Jeffrey Epstein, R. Kelly, and Harvey Weinstein. Ten women have filed a lawsuit accusing Nygard of sexual assault, and using his company and employees to obtain young victims and give them alcohol and drugs. (Nygard is also the target of a sex trafficking inves...tigation in New York City.) The lawsuit's allegations resemble the crimes that Jeffrey Epstein was accused of: Nygard is said to have “shared women with local politicians,” and “groomed victims to recruit ’fresh meat,’” according to The New York Times and other reports. The alleged victims were said to have been “lured to Nygard’s Bahamian home by the prospect of modeling jobs or a taste of luxury.” He and Epstein are even said to have shared a connection with Prince Andrew. “He preys on poor people’s little girls,” Natasha Taylor, who worked there for five years, told the Times. (Through a spokesman, Nygard has denied the allegations.) Recent cases are sending a message that even the rich and powerful can’t commit these crimes without facing justice.

name: Love146
content: Reposted• @roblove146: Child trafficking is not just an “issue” or a “cause” involving mind-numbing stats. It’s about someone’s daughter or son. It’s about human beings. (I’m getting some help here from kids in our @Love146 safe homes on how to form a heart with my very white hand). #enditmovement #humantrafficking #love146 #endit #enditmovement❌ #endit❌

name: Love146
content: Last month we shared 10 facts with you about child trafficking and exploitation. Here they are compiled into a 5 minute video! The more you know about this issue, the better you’ll be able to keep children safe. Which of these facts were new to you? Let us know in the comments!

name: Love146
content: There will be tens of thousands of people today, inspired by the #EndItMovement, who will wear a red ‘X” on their hands to symbolize a commitment to end human trafficking. ❌ Philosopher and rhetorician Kenneth Burke wrote extensively on the power of symbolism. He believed that people naturally respond to symbolism in their quest for identification and that it is a powerful means of “inducing cooperation in beings that by nature respond to symbols.” Throughout history symbolis...m has been used to inspire and galvanize social movements. Symbols have even helped unite people within a movement who have differing philosophies, approaches and agendas for a common good. Sometimes words aren’t even necessary. Symbols can speak volumes in their imagery, history and the feelings they provoke. And, at the end of the day, symbols don’t bring about any meaningful change. But the people behind them do. A symbol doesn’t change anything. People do. And if a symbol can help “induce cooperation” and inspire more people to the fight… then we’re in. So… a red ‘X’ or 146 won’t end child trafficking. But the people who carry these symbols might.

name: Love146
content: Do many fans come to the Super Bowl with a pocket full of cash to buy sex? And do traffickers amp up their businesses to cater to this flash audience? These are provocative questions, for sure. You might call them headline-inducing, which could explain why you’ve probably seen a story (or ten) based on this premise in the last few days and years. The trouble is that there’s little evidence to suggest the answers are “yes,” at least in significant numbers. ...When claims are made that “the Super Bowl is the largest human trafficking event,” additional damage comes to the credibility of the anti-trafficking movement. If we’re going to succeed in ending child trafficking, we need people to trust us when we say what we actually do know: the problem IS REAL, and it’s not all hype.

name: Love146
content: Human Trafficking has been happening forever, but only in the year 2000 was it recognized as a crime by the US Government & the United Nations. Once it had a name, the world began noticing that millions of people were being exploited. After learning about it, you may even feel like the world is getting worse. But bygone eras weren’t “better times.” Knowing that this horrific crime is happening might feel worse; but those are feelings, not facts. And those feelings matter! Bec...ause in reality, your rage, indignation, determination, and defiant hope — are the means by which the world IS changing for the better. The means by which we will end it. Trafficking Prevention Month is just about over, but so many people are choosing to journey alongside children as Love146 monthly partners and you can join them in prioritizing this issue every month. Visit www.love146.org/give

name: Love146
content: Training to recognize and respond appropriately to trafficking, as well as making sure there are trauma-informed spaces to heal, help create pathways for more victims to exit exploitation.  Many children in our Survivor Care haven’t been physically removed by law-enforcement from their exploitation. Rather, they’re connected to Love146 or child welfare agencies by caring adults who notice something is wrong – or sometimes they have even reached out themselves and asked for he...lp. Love146’s professional training equips adults to recognize and appropriately respond to children who are vulnerable or being exploited. If you or someone you or someone you know is being exploited, or if you have reason to believe that someone you know is being exploited, call the national human trafficking hotline at 1-888-3737-888 To learn more facts, visit: https://love146.org/child-trafficking-some-facts-stats/

name: Love146
content: Love146 has connected with situations of trafficking in which exploiters have been family members, peers, romantic partners, educators, employers, community leaders, and clergy – of all ages, ethnicities & genders.  Informed by our work with survivors, our Prevention Education helps youth spot traffickers and peers in trouble and can even help victims self-identify. To learn more, visit: https://love146.org/child-trafficking-some-facts-stats/

name: Love146
content: This MLK Day, those of us fighting to end child trafficking can honor his legacy by continuing to see and address how racism and systemic injustices contribute to the problem.  It's true that any child can be a victim of trafficking. However, the fact that the majority of victims are people of color should not be undermined or understated. Trafficking disproportionately affects people of color. When we’ve looked at records* of how many children are referred for trafficking se...rvices or whose cases have been investigated, we’re finding that children of color are about 4x times more likely to be trafficked than white children. It’s important that we recognize the intersection between trafficking and racism in order to address the root causes and be proactive about transforming the systems that perpetuate these injustices. /// *Citation: The US Department of Justice found that between 2008 and 2010, children of color accounted for 77.8% of child sex trafficking cases they investigated, compared to the 48% of nonwhite in the general population, according to the US Census during this time. In Connecticut, where Love146’s US Survivor Care program is based, 73% of all child sex trafficking referrals to the state’s Department of Children and Families in 2018 were children of color, compared to 43% of children being nonwhite in the Connecticut state general population at that time.

name: Love146
content: The ILO report claims about sex trafficking that “the vast majority of victims (99 percent) were women and girls.” However, when we’ve adjusted our perspective and programs to make space to see and care for sexually exploited boys, we’ve seen identification rates jump significantly. As of 2019, in Love146’s programs for victims of child sex trafficking, we’ve seen 13.5% are boys and 1.6% non-binary youth. Some research suggests this number of boys affected could be as high as 30-50%. Until we see less stigma around the abuse of boys, we won’t be able to know how many boys are being exploited or help many of them. The more you know, the better you'll be able to see victims and keep children safe – no matter their gender. Learn more at: love146.org/child-trafficking-some-facts-stats/

name: Love146
content: Under US federal law, all children involved in commercial sex are victims of human trafficking. Sadly, only about half of US states have laws that protect sexually exploited children from being prosecuted for prostitution.  Children are vulnerable because their brains are still developing, because they depend on adults for safety and resources, and because they lack many basic legal rights. Although all youth are vulnerable to being groomed by traffickers, some are particular...ly vulnerable, including children in the foster care system, runaway and homeless youth, youth that identify as LGBTQ, and those with a history of complex traumatic stress—resulting from continuous exposure to family dysfunction, trauma, sexual abuse, and other forms of abuse or harassment (i.e. bullying). The after-effects faced by children include long-lasting physical and psychological trauma, disease (including HIV/AIDS), drug addiction, unwanted pregnancy, malnutrition, social ostracism, and even death.  The more you know, the better you'll be able to keep kids safe.  Learn more: https://love146.org/child-trafficking-some-facts-stats/

name: Love146
content: UPDATE: Love146 staff and children in the Philippines are being evacuated due to the eruption of the Volcano Taal. Ash is currently falling on our safehomes there. // Pictured here is Emilia, a survivor in our care, looking out on the Volcano (seen in the distance) during more restful times on a retreat a few years ago. She & friends from the safehome had rode up the volcano on horseback a few hours before this photo was taken.  @ Taal Volcano Tagaytay

name: Love146
content: If you looked at a map of trafficking referrals, major highways, and human population density, you’d find they are often closely aligned. Where there are more people, more children are likely being exploited. Spikes in reported trafficking may also be influenced by an increased focus in that region on research, training, law-enforcement efforts, or an awareness campaign promoting the national hotline – and though the increase numbers may not seem like it at first, that can indicate a good thing — that anti-trafficking efforts are bringing the issue out of the shadows, and finding more people who need help. To learn more, visit: https://love146.org/child-trafficking-some-facts-stats/

name: Love146
content: Thanks to the federal Administration for Children and Families for sharing our US Programs Director Erin Williamson's thoughts on National Human Trafficking Prevention Month. "In order to end trafficking, we must prevent it from ever happening."

name: Love146
content: A lot of the youth we work with have been trafficked in plain sight. They’re not missing. Sometimes they might run away or be living on the streets but rarely have the victims that we've worked with experienced anything like being kidnapped, and some youth even continue to live at home, go to school and participate in extracurricular actives all while being trafficked. To learn more, visit: love146.org/child-trafficking-some-facts-stats/

name: Love146
content: At any given moment, an estimated 40.3 million people are being victimized in situations of trafficking and exploitation worldwide. 25% of these are children. (ILO) Human Trafficking is an underground crime, so it’s difficult to measure, and more research is desperately needed. But we know the problem is real. We know the problem is big. And behind every estimate is a real person who cannot be dismissed. In 2017, the International Labour Organization expanded their reporting ...on trafficking & exploitation (what they call modern-slavery) to include forced marriage. Under that definition, 40.3 million are estimated to be victims at any given moment. For most of our organizational history, our programs focused on children who’ve been sexually exploited. In 2012 we expanded our mission to also include children exploited in labor trafficking. Today, our Survivor Care in the UK, as well as some of our prevention work, help children affected by labor trafficking as well. To learn more, visit: https://love146.org/child-trafficking-some-facts-stats/

name: Love146
content: Over the course of National Human Trafficking Prevention Month, we'll be sharing some facts with you about child trafficking. First, let's define it. Human trafficking is any situation of exploitation that a person cannot refuse or leave because of threats, violence, coercion, deception, and/or abuse of power. (ILO) In the case of child sex trafficking, force, fraud, or coercion do not need to be present, and the crime is simply the exchange of any sex act with a child for anything of value. Learn more at https://love146.org/child-trafficking-some-facts-stats/

name: Love146
content: January is National Human Trafficking Prevention Month. Many of us are parents and caregivers and we play a critical role in preventing child trafficking. Here are ways you can help keep your child safe.

name: Love146
content: It’s a new decade. We’re sometimes asked, “We’ve been fighting child trafficking for a long time. Do you think we’re making an impact?”  Well, on this day 2 decades ago, human trafficking hadn’t yet been defined as a crime by the United Nations & United States. Because of the momentum of this movement, that changed. On this day 1 decade ago, people like Jeffrey Epstein, R. Kelly, and many others were exploiting victims with impunity. Because of the momentum of this movement, ...that changed. And because of you, I believe a decade from now things will be very different. Last year, we received more referrals for trafficked youth than ever before. And our gut says that 2020, we’ll probably top that. But this is not cause for despair. Rather, our society and systems are seeing the problem where we didn’t see it before! We’re responding to the needs of children and coming together to make this a safer world for them. This isn’t a sprint, it’s a marathon. We won’t end child trafficking in the next decade. But hear us: we are winning. Pace yourself and don’t get tired. Keep listening to survivors. Keep raising a collective shout about this atrocity. Because your heart, your attention, and your voice matters – and together our refusal to fail children is why this will end.

name: Love146
content: 💛 This is one of the youngest trafficking survivors in our care... dancing. Let this little one remind you: whatever challenges face you, one of your greatest weapons is defiant hope. Happy New Year!

name: Love146
content: Listen as our survivor care team shares stories from working with survivors of child trafficking. People think that we, as a human rights organization, are fighting for children. But honestly, it's the kids who are doing the lion's share of the fighting. They're fighting to take back their lives. As a supporter, you are opening doors, journeying with them, and giving them a fighting chance. Your donation makes this work possible.  www.love146.org/give

name: Love146
content: Children who have experienced trafficking and have been out of school for long periods of time may have difficulty reentering classroom settings. We work with schools and other professionals so that the youth in our care get the support and love they need. Understanding that recovery happens step by step gives kids a fighting chance.  Your donation makes this work possible! Give now at www.love146.org/give

name: Love146
content: Listen as our survivor care team shares stories from working with survivors of child trafficking. Because of your support, they can come to Love146, no matter how much their trauma has impacted them. Knowing a youth has experienced trafficking means we work with them. We believe in a future where that child is free to flourish. Your donation gives kids affected by trafficking a fighting chance.  www.love146.org/give

name: Love146
content: In a recent video (https://vimeo.com/376045293), you heard a Love146 social worker tell you how beautiful it was to watch one of the youth in our care fall in love with her local library. So what’s the big deal? Our US Programs Director, Erin Williamson shares 3 reasons why it excites us when kids who survived trafficking, have new experiences like this. Your donation gives kids affected by trafficking, a fighting chance. www.love146.org/give

name: Love146
content: Children who have survived trafficking have experienced so much bad in their young lives. Love146 helps them to experience beauty so they can believe that life is so much more than trauma and pain. You make this work possible. Your donation give children affected by trafficking a fighting chance. www.love146.org/give

name: Love146
content: Children who've experienced trafficking are fighting to ensure that their past doesn’t define who they are today or who they’ll be tomorrow. Maybe you’ve struggled to believe that you’re more than what you’ve experienced in the past. But it's true for you and for children. You can stand with them, and give so that their future can be bright. Your donation gives kids affected by trafficking a fighting chance. www.love146.org/give (None of the identifiable children in this video are known to be exploited.)

name: Love146
content: Children who've experienced trafficking and exploitation often feel anger or other strong emotions. That's ok! It's a completely normal response to a horrific experience they NEVER should have had. Your support allows us to walk along side a child as they learn new ways of expressing and channelling those emotions. It not only changes their life; it can change the world. Gives more kids affected by trafficking a fighting chance: www.love146.org/give

name: Love146
content: “These kids fight. They fight to get their childhoods back. They fight for a future. They fight for their rights. They fight for justice. They fight for their lives. What we do as Love146? What you do as friends and supporters? Is give them a fighting chance. I took these videos last week at our Love146 Safehomes in the Philippines. Yes, we have punching bags for therapy. And let’s just say that I’m glad I’m not one of those punching bags. When you support this work, you’re a part of giving children a fighting chance.”  -Rob Morris, Love146 President & Co-founder  #humanrightsday #love146 #defianthope #childtrafficking

name: Love146
content: Parents: Don’t underestimate the concern around gaming systems. There’s a false sense that online games are somehow safe. Your child could be in their bedroom and be groomed and recruited by a predator. We all need to be paying a lot more attention to this virtual world because, especially for adolescent youth, that world is so critical to their personal identity. What can you do? Talk with your children about how to stay safe online. Explain that you understand their desire ...for privacy, but that it’s your job as a parent to keep them safe. Be aware of their online activities. Learn about the games they’re playing. Hang out with them while they play, and ask them questions. Help them know that people they meet online may not be who they say they are, and that they shouldn’t chat with anyone they don’t know. Caution them to never send photos to anyone. Finally, let your child know that if they are uncomfortable with something, or if they have done something that’s making them nervous or if they have been threatened, they can talk with an adult they trust.   For our online safety guide for teenegsr and caregivers, go to https://love146.org/action/online-safety/

name: Love146
content: Caption: Hear 8 children tell you what trafficking — and recovery — is really like. You’ve supported all of these children in reclaiming their futures. Your gifts ensure more children affected by trafficking have a fighting chance: www.love146.org/give (This video features actors & has some details changed for privacy & protection)

name: Love146
content: “I arrived in the Philippines this week the day after Typhoon Tisoy tore through the country. Spent the day with children in our care at Love146. Children who know something about surviving storms. Terrifying storms. They fight so hard to come through. To experience peace again. To feel safe. To know joy. And they do. They insist on it. They seem to carry some kind of knowledge, or call it a defiant hope, that tomorrow can be a better day. That storms do indeed come to an end.... That they will breath deep again. Rest again. See the sun another day. I’m only beginning to understand. (This is a photo I just took of one of the younger boys in our care, soaking up the light and calm after the Typhoon.)”  - A reflection from Rob Morris, Love146 President & Co-founder. Your gifts give more children affected by trafficking fighting chance: www.love146.org/give

name: Love146
content: Recently, we asked some youth in our Survivor Care program to write notes of encouragement out of their wisdom and experience. This is one that a child wrote. Letting others help is hard. Especially if you’re not used to good people offering real help. The children in our care are learning to let others help because of people like you, who show up again and again with tangible support. Yesterday, you exceeded the #GivingTuesday goal of raising $100,000. Thanks to you, and the... Colquitt family who matched your donations, #GivingTuesday raised more than $110,000 to help children. We cannot thank you enough. This morning, our staff were so uplifted by yesterday as we began to put these funds to use. Today in our office, we are training dozens of new facilitators of our prevention curriculum, who’ll go back to their home states equipped to protect more children. At the same time, our Survivor Care staff is answering calls about youth in crisis, and heading out to meet them. Thank you for the kind of generosity that sends a message to young people that they can let others help.

name: Love146
content: This #GivingTuesday be a part of raising $100,000 to prevent child trafficking & care for survivors of exploitation. We’re already at 61% of our goal! www.love146.org/GivingTuesday19

name: Love146
content: From now until #GivingTuesday, every $1 you give is worth $2, thanks to Super Bowl Champion, husband, father, Love146 supporter, and @Vikings punter, Britton Colquitt. Give more kids a fighting chance: www.love146.org/givingtuesday19

name: Love146
content: You are one reason children are giving thanks, and that's no small thing. May your time with loved ones today be a warm reminder of why freedom and love are worth fighting for. Happy Thanksgiving from the Love146 Family

name: Love146
content: Thanks – because you make it happen. 💛 Here's our impact through 2019 – and more kids are being helped every day. Right now through #givingtuesday your donations will be doubled for 2x the impact! www.love146.org/givingtuesday With every gift, there’s a team in the Philippines, UK, US & Africa preparing to reach more even children with Prevention Education & Survivor Care. As one of those children shared recently, “I’m thankful because I met good people like you who treated me like a human being with worth and dignity.”

name: Love146
content: This guy! For the next week, all the way up to #GivingTuesday he'll be matching your donations to @Love146! Britton Colquitt, the punter for the Minnesota Vikings, and his family are pledging to make every $1 you give worth $2.  Go to www.love146.org/givingtuesday19 #GivingTuesday, on December 3rd, is a global day focused on giving back. Be a part of helping raise $100,000 to end child trafficking. Let's make it count!

name: Love146
content: “I still have fight left in me. I’m not ready to give up.” People mistakenly think that we as a human rights organization are doing the fighting for children. Or that donors, or legislators, or police are fighting for children. If there is one thing we've learned in 17 years of this work, it’s that children do the lion’s share of the fighting.  Most of the time all they need is a chance. What you do through your generosity, is give them a fighting chance. www.love146.org/holiday19

name: Love146
content: Parents & caregivers alert: WashPo investigation finds more than 1,500 complaints of unwanted sexual approaches, many targeting children, about random chat apps like Monkey, Yubo, ChatLive, Chat for Strangers, Skout and Holla. Love146 cares for survivors of child trafficking. Many youth in our care were exploited online. While we continue to demand change, your gift today protects children: www.love146.org/holiday19

name: Love146
content: Trigger Warning⚠️  At only 9, Gabi* was being abused in front of a webcam. She came to Love146 and your support meant she had a fighting chance… and wow did she take it. She caught up in school. She continued working through immense trauma. She went on the first hike of her life. She helped bring her perpetrators to justice. Today, she’s about to finish a bachelors in Information Systems… & dreams to go back to study Social Work.  Your past doesn’t define you! Your gifts give more children like Gabi a fighting chance: www.love146.org/holiday19 *name & some details changed for privacy & protection

name: Love146
content: “When I meet with a survivor, one of the first things I tell them is: “We’ll always be there for you.” Recently a survivor called and told me she’d moved. “Can you still meet me all the way out here?” she asked. “Of course,” I told her. Many kids I work with assume that everyone is going to hurt or disappoint them. After so many people have come into this child’s life for the wrong reasons, Love146 staff & supporters are showing up for the right reasons." – Love146 Staff

name: Love146
content: Photos and videos of child sexual abuse are rampant on the web, haunting and impacting victims for years. But as this story shows, tech companies have the power to do more to screen and delete these horrific images. (Warning: This story contains some graphic descriptions of child exploitation that could be triggering.)

name: Love146
content: Trauma bonding is beautifully explained in this piece written by Yvette Young, a colleague on Connecticut's Human Anti-trafficking Response Team. "Sex traffickers utilize various strategies to attain control and obedience from their victims, which results in their victims’ dependence on them. These strategies include 'subjecting their victims to starvation, rape, gang rape, physical abuse, beating, confinement, threats of violence toward the victim and victim’s family, forced drug use, and shame.'”  As our US Programs Director Erin Williamson says in the article, “We can have youth recognize the horrible exploitation and even physical abuse they sustained at the hands of their trafficker, and in the same breath tell us that they still ‘love’ them.”

name: Love146
content: “I refuse to live in fear. …You’re a child for such a short period of time! Enjoy it!” 👏Parenting, Anti-Trafficking, Work/Life Balance, and Nonprofit teamwork.. hear all this & more in some excerpts from of a recent podcast from our friends at @hyggeclt

name: Love146
content: A few months ago we reached out because we needed your help. There were more children who needed our care than we had the capacity to care for. Well, thanks to your incredibly generous response and increased government funding, we now know that if a child needs our long-term care, we have a social worker who can begin working with them, and they won’t end up stalled on a “waitlist” for help. ••• Hear our team reflect on the work at https://bit.ly/2pvpdck

name: Love146
content: A dress historically has represented fragility and oppression, but Dressember has reclaimed the dress as a symbol of strength and dignity. In their annual style challenge, people from around the world wear dresses and ties during the month of December to raise funds and awareness for anti-trafficking programs around the world. We’re grateful to announce that funds raised during #Dressember will benefit #Love146's Survivor Care in the Philippines! You can be a part of the impact too! ••• Create a campaign page or join a team at www.dressember.org

name: Love146
content: A detailed write-up of #Love146’s Survivor Care program was featured this August in the journal of Child Abuse & Neglect’s special focus on child trafficking and health. The journal was sharing information “intended to raise awareness of innovative counter-trafficking strategies emerging worldwide.” The Love146 paper, specifically, was published to “detail the successes, challenges, and lessons learned... in facilitating US survivor access to services that can improve medical and mental health outcomes.” ••• Preview the article at https://bit.ly/2PvvaRg

name: Love146
content: We’re inspired by people coming together around what they love and using that community to help others. The SYFY network’s Wynonna Earp is a kind of horror-camp hybrid, centered on the great-great-granddaughter of Wyatt Earp. Unless you’re an “Earper,” a member of the show’s rabid fan base, you may not know that #WynonnaEarp’s remarkably positive online community has rallied around ending trafficking. #LoraInnes, the artist who turned Wynonna Earp into a graphic novel, recently auctioned Wynonna Earp autographed banners to benefit #Love146, raising a spectacular $15,395 for children affected by trafficking. Our deepest thanks to Lora, the cast, and to the “Earpers,” who show that love can come to life on the Internet.

name: Love146
content: It’s a long journey for a trafficked young person from Southeast Asia to the UK — but a much shorter journey moving into a new flat once you’ve been removed from your exploitation. When one of the young people we work with received the good news that he was cleared to stay in the UK, our team helped him move into a new, unfurnished apartment. We took him shopping and helped him create the kind of home he wants to live in while he receives the support he needs to recover from his exploitation. As he settles into home, we'll still support him, because we never close a case.

name: Love146
content: When supporters ask us what they can do to help, we often say, “Start from doing what you love.” A group of Boston Red Sox fans in Denver took that message to Coors Field where they hosted a fundraiser for #Love146 while the Sox were in town playing the Rockies. They sold tickets and held a raffle, with proceeds going to Love146. They also invited a local volunteer team to set up a table and share about the issue, our work, and opportunities for people to get involved. And, oh yeah, the Sox won the game, 10-6.

name: Love146
content: “Why prevention education?” That was the topic at a keynote speech recently that our President & Co-founder Rob Morris gave to the National Roundtable on Safeguarding Children and Prevention Education, hosted by the McCain Institute and The Department of Health and Human Services. You might think it would be the shortest speech ever: “Because Prevention Education will create a safer world for children.” Simple, right? But getting there is hard. “We have to be thoughtful becau...se we want our solutions to be effective and sustainable,” Rob told government officials, law enforcement, and selected leaders from the anti-trafficking movement in attendance. “We deal daily with the tension that exists between thinking through solutions and the knowledge that children are being exploited and trafficked every day. That's what makes prevention so difficult, because it takes time.” ••• See Rob’s full speech at https://bit.ly/2J0ZrTV.

name: Love146
content: Join with other activists in the greater Hartford area! Walk to some amazing local eats & be a part of helping hundreds of children right here in Connecticut to find freedom after trafficking & exploitation.

name: Love146
content: 500 children in the United States now you’ve supported with Survivor Care. Shown up & been there when it was needed most. In addition to tens of thousands cared for through prevention, our US Survivor Care program just did our 500th “rapid response.” Rapid Responses are one-time meetings with youth who are at high risk of trafficking, or are suspected or confirmed victims. We listen, give resources, help them realize it’s not their fault, and talk about how to find safety and... support. Afterwards, we make suggestions to their caregivers & social workers about follow up (which sometimes leads to that youth joining our long-term Survivor Care). Every youth who receives a Rapid Response gets to walk away with a backpack full of things like a blanket, granola bars, gloves, a teddy bear, deodorant, a card with hotlines, a cell phone that can call 911, chapstick, colored pencils, and lots of other goodies. Love146 also provides long term holistic survivor care in the U.S., journeying with survivors for many months. Some youth that receive a rapid response go on to get that level of care, and every youth in our long-term care begins with a Rapid Response.

name: Love146
content: Matching goal reached! That was one epically low-key evening — and thanks to you, it still made BIG impact for children affected by trafficking. Thank you for choosing to be generous and stand against child trafficking, even without a fancy night out. Cozy nights are great, but we still love to party for a cause! Our gala will be back in Houston in May 2020, so don’t miss it!

name: Love146
content: Just because there wasn't a gala last night doesn't mean you can't do your part for children affected by trafficking... We've raised 60% of the goal for this weekend's matching challenge. Will you make a difference in a child's life? Give before midnight to make sure every dollar is matched! https://donate.love146.org/give/229136/#!/donation/checkout

name: Love146
content: Double your gift for children‼️Until Sunday at midnight, everything you give for the Not a Red Gala will be matched up to $5K by Emma Walker at @bhgrealestate Paracale. Today is the big day! Stay home & make a difference. ❤️

name: Love146
content: What are you doing tomorrow instead of being a Love146 gala?! We’re not having a gala tomorrow, but you can still make a difference from the comfort of your own sofa! Don’t attend, just donate: www.love146.org/notaredgala

name: Love146
content: In 2019, there’s NO Love146 gala. We’ll miss it (and the introverts are a little bit pumped), but we’re taking a break so we can focus on reaching more children. This year, you can give to our NOT a Red Gala, and know that all the funds are going to our work and none of it goes towards a fancy dinner & decor. Give today: www.love146.org/notaredgala

name: Love146
content: Our latest quarterly Impact Report is now available. If you’re one of those people who like to know how many children we’ve served (spoiler: it's over 55,000) or are interested in knowing the ages, genders, and risk factors of the children in our care — and a whole lot more — our Impact Report is for you. ••• Read our latest Impact Report at https://bit.ly/2YZFl5U

name: Love146
content: Natural disasters are known to be a situational vulnerability that traffickers prey upon. In April, our Philippines office in Manila was shaken by a 6.1 magnitude earthquake. Following this, our Philippines Survivor Care Team led a community training for families about earthquake preparedness. Twenty-seven participants learned what to do before, during, and after earthquakes in order to keep their families safer. The training opened with remarks from a survivor of trafficking who is a former #Love146 client. One parent shared afterwards, “I’m glad that we’ve learned new things so we can save ourselves and especially our children.”

name: Love146
content: After many years of use in Asia, #Love146 introduced the “My Body is Mine” flipchart in Africa in 2017. We’ve now reached over 18,000 children. We started in Liberia, then Madagascar, and now have trained facilitators to reach children in Sierra Leone. During the recent training in Freetown, one facilitator shared, “We must remember that it’s never the kid’s fault if violated. Children should not be blamed for sexual assault.” Another facilitator shared, “My community is full of issues of trafficking and abuse. I think the flipchart will be useful. I will organize sessions to teach it.” ••• Learn more about our work in Africa at www.love146.org/programs/africa-prevention

name: Love146
content: Our US Programs Director Erin Williamson traveled to Arizona in May to join national experts, advocates, members of law enforcement, and government officials for a meeting of the National Advisory Committee on the Sex Trafficking of Children & Youth in the United States. The Committee advises the Attorney General and the Secretary of Health and Human Services on the nation’s response to child sex trafficking, and is writing a report on best practices and recommendations for governors and child welfare agencies. Erin is co-authoring sections on child welfare and service provision, as well as providing input into the section on prevention. The report is scheduled to be finished in the new year.

name: Love146
content: On July 1st, 2019, #Love146 welcomed new US Executive Director Amy Casavina Hall to the #NewHaven office. Amy brings over 20 years of experience in the nonprofit sector to our mission. "What got me excited was the bold statement around ending trafficking. Love146 is known for having amazing services. But what gets me up out of bed every day smiling and ready to go is a group of people coming together saying we are going to end something that should never be happening, and throw everything we can against it. That’s the team I want to be a part of."

name: Love146
content: Some of the brightest minds are gathered today at Facebook HQ for the 4th Annual Child Safety Hackathon, working on advanced technology to protect children. It would be a great time to remember there are 3 common-sense and simple steps Facebook still needs to take in order to protect children from predators. Children are connecting with traffickers on Facebook. And even with dozens of hackers in a room focused on the problem at Facebook, their commitment to protecting children remains unclear. What are we talking about? Learn more & sign the petition: www.love146.org/facebook

name: Love146
content: In the interest of deepening our awareness of child trafficking, we invited Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times journalist Ian Urbina to take over our Instagram this week and share from his experience the past several years reporting on crime & exploitation at sea, including child trafficking. Today is Ian’s final post:  ●●●  “We are deeply dependent on the ocean. My posts over the past week have show horrifying abuses that take place on our seas. All of these types of abus...es stem from a core problem, which is a lack of governance at sea, especially on the high seas. Specifically, there are three ways in which misbehavior happens offshore routinely and with impunity: too few rules, a lack of enforcement, and insufficient awareness of what is happening there. All of these problems are also connected in that they occur with a certain tacit complicity from all of us who live on land. We all are the beneficiaries of the lawlessness on the high seas, where 90 percent of all the products we consume comes by way of ships, and the commercial channels are usually unbothered by the government and therefore, rules. We have been able to access impossibly cheap products that arrive to our shelves with incredible speed. Ninety percent of everything travels by ship, 50 percent of our oxygen is from the ocean, and 70 percent of the protein we consume comes from the sea: we are deeply dependent on the ocean.” ●●● We at Love146 are thankful for the tenacity of reporters like Ian Urbina who can give us a glimpse into the broader realities of exploitation and human trafficking. For more reporting on #TheOutlawOcean from @Ian_Urbina, visit the link in our bio.

name: Love146
content: In the interest of deepening our awareness of child trafficking, we invited Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times journalist Ian Urbina to take over our Instagram this week and share from his experience the past several years reporting for his new book on crime & exploitation at sea, including child trafficking. Trigger warning: This story has graphic detail of abuse and death. ●●● “Illegal ‘manning agencies’ trick villagers, some as young as 13, in the Philippines with false... promises of high wages and send them to ships notorious for poor safety and labor records. When Eril (the boy in this photograph) left this small village, he was healthy and hoping to earn enough on a fishing boat on the high seas to replace his mother’s leaky roof. Seven months later, his body was sent home in a wooden coffin: jet black from having been kept in a fish freezer aboard a ship for more than a month, missing an eye and his pancreas, and covered in cuts and bruises, which an autopsy report later concluded had been inflicted before death.” ●●● For the dignity of particular children Love146 works with, and because we try to focus on hope, we rarely discuss the fact that murder does come up in our Survivor Care work. Some youth in our care have survived attempted murder; and some live with the knowledge that fellow victims did not make it. For those who survive trafficking, aftercare is important. Love146 is caring for young people from the Philippines, Vietnam, and other locations in Asia through our Survivor Care programs. ●●● For more reporting on #TheOutlawOcean from @Ian_Urbina, visit the link in our bio this week.

name: Love146
content: In the interest of deepening our awareness of child trafficking, we invited Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times journalist Ian Urbina to take over our Instagram this week and share from his experience the past several years reporting for his new book on crime & exploitation at sea, including child trafficking. ●●● “I had heard of many stories of people being kidnapped or sold into the fishing industry. This one about Lang Long in particular stood out to me: Lang’s ordeal be...gan in the back of a truck. After watching his younger siblings go hungry because their family’s rice patch in Cambodia couldn’t provide for everyone, he accepted a trafficker’s offer to travel across the Thai border for a construction job. It was his chance to start over. When he instead arrived at the sea port, the trafficker sold him to a boat captain for about $530, less than a water buffalo typically costs. Lang was kept for days by armed men in a room near the port. He was then herded with six other migrants up a gangway onto a shoddy wooden ship. It was the start of three brutal years in captivity at sea. “I cried,” said Lang, recounting how he was resold twice between fishing boats. After repeated escape attempts, one captain shackled him by the neck whenever other boats neared. Lang’s crews trawled primarily for forage fish, which are small and cheaply priced. Much of this catch comes from the waters off Thailand, where Lang was held, and is sold to the United States, typically for canned cat and dog food or feed for poultry, pigs, and farm-raised fish that Americans consume.” ●●● For more reporting on #TheOutlawOcean from @Ian_Urbina, visit the link in our bio this week. Photo by: @adamjdean

name: Love146
content: The bystander effect is real. Employees at an airstrip in St. Thomas saw Jeffrey Epstein repeatedly flying in underage girls, after his conviction for sex crimes. “We didn’t say anything because we figured law enforcement was doing their job," said one worker. "I have to say that that is regrettable, but we really didn’t even know who to tell, or if anyone really cared.” Stand up for children. Know the signs at https://love146.org/action/report/ If you see something, call the National HumanTrafficking Hotline at 1 (888) 373-7888.

name: Love146
content: In the interest of deepening our awareness of child trafficking, we invited Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times journalist Ian Urbina to take over our Instagram this week and share from his experience the past several years reporting for his new book on crime & exploitation at sea, including child trafficking. ●●● “In this photo you see girls waiting for their next customer. This was in Ranong, Thailand, where I saw how karaoke bars double as brothels & debt traps. It’s a n...otorious place where traffickers in the fishing and prostitution industries operate with impunity. The hardest thing that I witnessed was in the karaoke bar. A girl who could not have been older than 12 was presented to me and my photographer for sale, not just in providing sexual services, but actually the very person of the girl was offered for us to buy. When I realized this was a genuine offer and how vulnerable and young that girl was, I was just shocked at the depravity of it all.” ●●● For more reporting on #TheOutlawOcean from @Ian_Urbina, visit the link in our bio this week. Photo by: @fabio.nascimento

name: Love146
content: In the interest of deepening our awareness of child trafficking, we invited Pulitzer Prize winning New York Times journalist Ian Urbina to take over our Instagram this week and share from his experience the past several years reporting for his new book on crime & exploitation at sea, including child trafficking. ●●● “In the outlaw ocean, the victims are many — above and below the waves. Labor abuse at sea can be so severe that the boys and men who are its victims might as well be captives from a bygone era. In interviews, those who fled recounted horrific violence: the sick cast overboard, the defiant beheaded, the insubordinate sealed for days below deck in a dark, fetid fishing hold.” ●●● For more reporting on #TheOutlawOcean from @Ian_Urbina, visit the link in our bio this week. Photo by: @adamjdean

name: Love146
content: In the interest of deepening our awareness of child trafficking, we invited Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times journalist Ian Urbina to take over our Instagram this week and share from his experience the past several years reporting for his new book on crime & exploitation at sea, including child trafficking. ●●● “Two centuries ago, ships carried people enslaved across the sea. Our better angels would like to think those horrific human rights abuses ended, when many countr...ies passed laws against such bondage within their borders. But the commercial exploitation and trafficking of people on the ocean is a global blind spot – as governments, companies, and consumers either don’t know it occurs, or, when they do, they prefer to look the other way.” ●●● For more reporting on #TheOutlawOcean from @Ian_Urbina, visit the link in our bio this week. Photo by: @fabio.nascimento

name: Love146
content: In the interest of deepening our awareness of child trafficking, we invited Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times journalist, @Ian_Urbina, to take over our social media this week and share from his experience reporting for his new book on crime & exploitation at sea, including child trafficking. ●●● “Hi, My name’s Ian Urbina and I’m an investigative reporter for The New York Times. For the past five years I’ve been working on a series called “The Outlaw Ocean,” which chronicles the various types of crimes that occur at sea around the world. ●●● Love146 here again: you’ll be hearing from Ian over the coming week, and a lot of it will be really intense stuff. For more reporting on #TheOutlawOcean from @Ian_Urbina, visit https://love146.org/the-outlaw-ocean/ Photo by: @fabio.nascimento

name: Love146
content: Well, Love146 isn’t here to tell you to go shopping, that’s silly. But… if you’re ALREADY engaging in Amazon’s “Prime Day” this Monday & Tuesday (the 15th and 16th), then you should definitely do it all on Amazon Smile. Love146 has received nearly $24K in proceeds from your Amazon Smile shopping!✌️Go to smile.amazon.com and check right below the search bar to select Love146 as your charity. Then just be sure if you’re shopping from smile.amazon.com and you can be sure it’s benefiting children affected by trafficking.

name: Love146
content: It’s normal to feel sick and dizzy. The week began with sex trafficking charges for Jefferey Epstein & is ending with sex trafficking charges for R. Kelly. Some of us are cheering – but many of us see news like this and ask “What is the world coming to?!” Let us assure you of this: Even though sex trafficking was only widely recognized as a crime less than 20 year ago, it is NOT a “modern phenomena.”  What’s the world coming to??? The truth is it’s coming to a place where we ...see things that have ALWAYS been wrong… where we are sick of it… where we demand justice…. where we say NOT ANYMORE. We believe — with defiant hope — that the world is coming to a place where this will end. And although weeks like this may feel like the world is getting worse, it is just the opposite. Sex trafficking has been happening for thousands of years. Bygone eras weren't "better times." It does FEEL worse now; but those are feelings, not facts. And those feelings matter! Because in reality, your rage, indignation, determination, and hope — are the means by which the world IS changing for the better. The means by which we will #endit ❌

name: Love146
content: Picture a group of young people, together in a room with a trained facilitator, learning about the realities of trafficking; exploring their vulnerabilities together, learning about safety planning. That’s what our Prevention curriculum, #NotANumber, looks like. To reach more youth, we train facilitators from other organizations and we stay in touch to support them. Here’s some feedback we received from one #NotANumber facilitator: "Our county has truly embraced the curriculum. We are providing much of our training to youth involved with foster care... I feel like there is a support network available and we aren’t just flying blind! I look forward to continuing to provide this training to our young people in rural Northern California." ••• More about #NotANumber at www.love146.org/notanumber

name: Love146
content: It’s been a year since we announced our pilot project bringing Prevention to Africa, and we‘ve now reached over 13,000 children! Recently in Madagascar, graduate students at the University of Antananarivo were trained to use the “My Body is Mine” flip chart, and presented it in primary school classrooms. When the grad students returned to the classes, the children remembered all the key messages. To follow-up further on the children’s learning and retention, the grad students... shared more scenarios and asked what was wrong and why. The children responded with clear understanding, saying things like, “You shouldn’t go back to that man’s house, he will steal you.” and “Safety is her right, so when she told her mom, her mom shouldn’t have dismissed her.” ••• Watch the video and learn more about our work in Africa at www.love146.org/programs/africa-prevention

name: Love146
content: “Race plays a role in every part of trafficking. It plays a role in the vulnerability of youth, and traffickers use race to try to exploit youth. It also can play a role in the exploitation, where youth are being sold for different amounts based on their race.” — Love146 US Programs Director Erin Williamson Yes, trafficking affects all children — but it disproportionately affects children of color. Check out this courageous conversation on race and trafficking with Love146's Erin Williamson, anti-human-trafficking advocate Chris Bidorini, and Yvette Young, the coordinator of Connecticut’s Human Anti-Trafficking Response Team, on Babz Rawls Ivy’s radio show, Lovebabz Lovetalk.

name: Love146
content: Many people imagine kicking in the door of a trafficker’s home. That’s not always how interventions take place. But this weekend that’s exactly what federal agents did to hedge fund manager Jeffrey Epstein’s 21,000 square-foot Manhattan mansion. Today, federal prosecutors charged Epstein with sex trafficking and conspiracy to commit sex trafficking. The indictment is a big first step for justice for Epstein’s victims, who were not consulted by Florida prosecutors before the m...ulti-millionaire was given an exceptionally lenient plea agreement in 2008. Epstein was convicted in Florida only of soliciting a prostitute. He served 13 months in jail, was allowed to travel to and from his office, and he avoided prosecution for federal sex-trafficking offenses. For many reasons, proving trafficking is often a challenge for prosecutors. There are youth in our care we know were trafficked, yet their traffickers evade charges, or plea to lesser crimes. This is where people like you make a difference. In addition to the bravery of victims & sharp journalism from the Miami Herald, this case is moving forward because of public outcry. Til now, Epstein's case sent a message that people, especially powerful people, can do this without facing justice. Let's continue to demand more. #enditmovement❌

I have been with this foster daughter for over 2 years, and Love146 has worked with her on and off during that time. Love146 has made a difference in my girl's life. Additionally, the organization I work with has monthly trainings for us. A few months ago a marvelous rep from Love146 came to speak. I wanted to thank Love146, so I made a donation.” ••• Join this foster mom and donate today at www.love146.org/give2019

name: Love146
content: For years, Love146 and others have sometimes said things like - “She is someone’s sister/daughter. Imagine how you would feel if someone did that to a woman you cared about.” We couldn't agree more with Aqsa Sajjad on this, when she said: “This is probably one of the most common arguments against abuse and harassment. Men are often shamed into behaving themselves and treating women like human beings by being told that the girl they are thinking of disrespecting is someone els...e’s sister, mother, daughter or wife. The point is to make them think of how they would feel if someone disrespected their own sister, mother, daughter or wife. I’m sure everyone who advocates this argument has their heart in the right place. Their intention is to make the victim more relatable, but what they usually forget in the process is that women are people too, and their value does not lie in their relation to a man—or another woman, for that matter. But here’s a piece of shocking news: I am not someone’s property. I am not anyone’s sister. I am not anyone’s daughter. I am not anyone’s future wife. I do not want you to associate me with a man just to show someone else my worth. Don’t respect me because of my relation to a man, a relation to a man does not warrant me any respect... I am someone, not someone’s.”  Read the entire blog here: https://www.elephantjournal.com/…/i-am-not-someones-sister…/

name: Love146
content: Goal reached! <3 This weekend we had a matching challenge that doubled donations so we could raise $6,000 to help children. We had until midnight tonight to hit our goal, but we didn’t need that long! Thank you everyone for your generosity. Even though you’ll probably never meet the young person you’ve impacted, know that a child will feel your support making a difference in their life.

name: Love146
content: ⚠️ TRIGGER WARNING: The image in this post features disturbing real headlines about child trafficking. Perpetrators in many of these headlines have hurt children in our care. When I see the headlines, I always ask myself, "Where are the children?" One of those children is Maya. When we say "survivor" we mean a lot of things. But one of the things we mean is that some don’t make it out alive. Maya made it out alive. About the man in one of these headlines above, Maya said: "I ...hope he rots in jail. He will go to the devil. He will never do to other children what he did to us." We are intentional about communicating hope, but sometimes I worry we don't tell you enough about what kids go through in order for you to fully celebrate with them. The stories we tell of hope and perseverance mean so much more when you know the kinds of trauma children have experienced. I noticed recently that at the root of the word "persevere" is the word "severe." Simply put, you can't truly celebrate perseverance unless you know the severity of what is being overcome. Know that whether the children in our care are climbing a ladder to our therapy treehouse or climbing the steps to the courthouse to confront their trafficker, whether they are experiencing struggle or triumph, you, our donors, are walking beside them. Today, Maya is a 5th grader. She struggles sometimes with the impact of what she's lived through. Still, she loves playing outside and doing ballet. She plays the guitar and dreams of becoming a famous singer. Maya can rock a sweat band and would knock you out in a game of badminton. Maya came into our care over six years ago, and steadfast people like you have been supporting her ever since. Two weeks ago we welcomed another child into our care and she needs you too. And there will be others after her... And they will need you. Rob Morris Love146's President and Co-founder ••• Will you stand with children, like Maya, persevering to end child trafficking? Give before this Sunday at midnight and double your impact ▶️ www.love146.org/give2019 // links to all news sources can be found at www.love146.org/headlines

name: Love146
content: The experiences of children in our care are severe. A child accompanied by armed guards to testify against her trafficker. Children who require long-term medical care for the trauma, injuries and infections they’ve sustained. A child coming into our care still in diapers. The potential threat of perpetrators who can come against staff or children in our care for retribution. Ultimately, children affected by trafficking and exploitation are the embodiment of perseverance. They... journey towards recovery day after day, after day, and you and I are privileged to walk alongside of them. Will you give to support their care & honor their perseverance? www.love146.org/give Even though you’ll probably never meet the young person you’ve impacted, know that a child will feel your support making a difference in their life. Whatever you sacrifice to give this gift, we can promise you: it’s worth it.

name: Love146
content: Because of you, children affected by trafficking aren’t in it alone. As a Love146 supporter, you are part of the community that comes alongside children with steadfast love. You stand with children affected by trafficking. Will you give today? Right now? - www.love146.org/give - Even though you’ll probably never meet the young person you’ve impacted, know that a child will feel your support making a difference in their life. Whatever you sacrifice to give this gift, we can promise you: it’s worth it.

name: Love146
content: Though Facebook has a long history of taking a vocal and ardent stance against child sexual exploitation, it continues to be one of the most popular platforms traffickers use to groom and recruit the youth we serve. Still, Facebook encourages children to use its platform, and does nothing to further protect their privacy. But there is one obvious tweak the company can make to address the problem, and it hasn't done it yet - read more in this blog about what that is.

She is responsible in part for generosity & events that have generated well over $70,000 to care for children affected by trafficking. In between her time spent as the pastor of a vibrant church in New Hampshire, you’ll find her doing things like wake surfing, pull ups, and climbing mountains, life coaching, and leading workshops on how churches can engage in ending trafficking. This #internationalwomensday, we're celebrating the determination of women like Katrina Keefe. Katrina is one of many phenomenal women who support our work, and we’re GRATEFUL FOR EVERY SINGLE ONE OF YOU.
