name: The Asservo Project
content: The National Human Trafficking Hotline identified domestic work as the industry with the highest occurrence of labor trafficking. Agriculture/animal husbandry and traveling sales crew came in 2nd and 3rd.  #theasservoproject #thetruthabouttrafficking

name: The Asservo Project
content: According to the information from the National Human Trafficking Hotline, escort services were the highest identified instance of human trafficking. Followed closely by Illicit massage, health and beauty situations. The third highest identified situation was pornography. #theasservoproject #thetruthabouttrafficking

name: The Asservo Project
content: Human trafficking is the use of force, fraud or coercion to get another person to provide labor or commercial sex. While it is believed that labor trafficking is more frequent than sex trafficking, sex trafficking has more awareness in the U.S. than labor trafficking. #theasservoproject #thetruthabouttrafficking

name: The Asservo Project
content: Over the course of the coming weeks and months, we will be sharing more from the heart, passion and people behind The Asservo Project.  One story that we would be remiss in sharing is how The Asservo Project got its start. While we aren’t going to be sharing the full detail today, we wanted to kick off with an impactful response from our founder.  When Joseph Sweeney first found out about the severity of the problem of human trafficking and child exploitation, all he could th...ink about was, “Once you know about it, how can you walk away and do nothing?” You may find as you read the stories of our nonprofit, and the volunteers behind it, that we have answered this question with a resounding, “We can’t!”  To  learn more about The Asservo Project today, to donate to our mission, or learn how you can become involved go to https://www.theasservoproject.org.  #theasservoproject

name: The Exodus Road
content: What are the facts about human trafficking in the U.S.? What legal protection exists for survivors of human trafficking in each of the 50 states? Get answers to these questions in our latest podcast episode! 🎙️ In this episode, we are joined by Jamie Beck, the President, and Managing Attorney at Free to Thrive. Free to Thrive empowers survivors of human trafficking to be free from exploitation by providing them with holistic and trauma-informed legal and support services in c...ollaboration with service partners. Episode 13: https://anchor.fm/…/EP-13--Jamie-Beck--Free-To-Thrive-erh8dq Learn more about the work of Free to Thrive by visiting freetothrive.org. Podcast Host: Preston Goff

name: The Exodus Road
content: Celebrating survivors is central to our work and team culture at The Exodus Road. One way we honor their freedom is by holding rock parties, where we take time to write the names of new survivors on Colorado river rocks as we hear the details of their story and rescue. Each new rock displayed throughout our office is a visual reminder of a son or daughter now free from exploitation. "Every rock has a name. Every rock has a story. Every story now has freedom in it." - Laura Parker, President, and Co-Founder, The Exodus Road. 💙

name: The Exodus Road
content: Because of you, a young woman is free today in India! 🥳  Your national teams around the globe all believe that the rescue of even one survivor is always worth the effort. That’s the heart and ethos of The Exodus Road. And one by one, they will continue to seek out the enslaved and empower freedom because of your support.  In this particular case, your Search + Rescue team in India coordinated with local police to bring freedom to Kaija*. She is out of danger now. Kaija is at a safe home where they will assess her initial needs and help determine the next steps.  Her three traffickers, two men and one woman, have all been charged and await legal action.  Because of the expert work of the national Search + Rescue team, local police, and you, the traffickers’ criminal business of abuse has been stopped. The Search + Rescue Team in India has been working closely with this particular police team for several years, and this completes 16 successful missions together. It’s a testimony to the relationship of trust that has been built over time as they collaborate to bring justice and freedom.  And they could not do this without your support in providing resources, training, equipment, and encouragement to keep moving forward.  Thank you for all you do to lift up our teams in this abolitionist work.  *Name and image representational.

name: The Exodus Road
content: Human trafficking disproportionately affects women, with over 28.6 million women and girls estimated to be victims of modern-day slavery in our world today. This International Women's Day, we are #ChallengingTrafficking. We're honored to celebrate the world-changing women who work tirelessly to bring freedom to survivors. To all female investigators, law enforcement officers, social workers, and freedom advocates in our community – thank you for consistently rising up in this fight to find and free survivors! #IWD2021 💖  International Women's Day

name: The Exodus Road
content: Celebrate with us because you have empowered the freedom of 2 young women in India. 🥳 Police were suspicious of the business taking place at a hotel-based brothel. They quickly reached out to the Search + Rescue team to investigate and collect evidence of human trafficking.  In just 2 days, your national operatives had collected enough evidence against the traffickers and provided valuable information to the police. Often, young women are lured into leaving their homes with offers of domestic jobs such as housekeeping. In an area that is grappling with poverty, steady work is sought after. But all too often, the job offers are merely a cover for the horrific reality that is forced sex work.  Because of your support, our national team was able to mobilize immediately, investigate the tip, and equip police with all they needed to take action. And these brave survivors were rescued!  The young women are now beginning their healing journey at a safe house.  And the traffickers? They are in jail, awaiting their trial.  Thank you to TER supporters, your national teams and local law enforcement for making this possible! *Names, image, and some details are representational.

name: The Exodus Road
content: Episode 12 is LIVE! In the fight against human trafficking, there are many great men and women advocating for the most vulnerable. At The Exodus Road we believe that when we fight human trafficking together, survivors win. Ben Cooley is the co-founder and CEO of Hope for Justice, a nonprofit that exists to bring an end to modern slavery by preventing exploitation, rescuing victims, restoring lives, and reforming society. Ben is known for his encouragement and resolve in the m...idst of a dark issue, and we're honored to welcome him on this episode of Until All Are Free. Listen Now:  https://anchor.fm/…/EP-12--Ben-Cooley--Hope-for-Justice-eqa…

name: The Exodus Road
content: 3 traffickers in Latin America have been stopped and are now in jail! 💪 We are thrilled to bring you another story of how you have empowered justice and made the business of human trafficking more difficult for traffickers.  Police in Latin America reached out to your national operatives for help in investigating suspected traffickers. This part of the country, that’s best known for its tourism, is also a place where kids are being sold for profit.   The traffickers had been recruiting children through school networks and social media and threatening them with extortion.  Travelers on holiday typically visit this area for just 3 to 4 days at a time. The challenge was deploying a team to go undercover with a believable cover story to stay and collect evidence for 2 full weeks.   But that’s exactly what your covert operatives did.  They put together a strong case, and authorities scheduled the raid. Local police were able to apprehend 3 traffickers from their own homes. Because of the location of the raid, no survivors were present. But, because of you, these traffickers will never be able to hurt children again. Thank you for equipping national operatives and local police in this strategic fight against child trafficking, and making this corner of Latin America a safer place for children.  *Names, image, and some details are representational.

name: The Exodus Road
content: It's 2021, and virtual dating is here to stay. So what does that even mean? Tip #2 Get to know each other better over a virtual date. ⬇️⁠ ⁠ ⁠ Most dating apps have introduced video dating features that allow you to...⁠ ⁠... ❤️  Have a video call without giving out your personal info. ⁠ ⁠ 📲  Further verify someone's identity.⁠ ⁠ 🤝  Decide if you'd like to meet each other for an in-person date. ⁠ ⁠ It may sound like a silly or even awkward concept 🤪, but it's a great way to stay safe.

content: Digital dating is the new normal, but how can you stay safe while in the pursuit of love? name: The Exodus Road
content: 2 young Indian women are free today! 🎉  Ela and Maira fell prey to one of the most common traps used by traffickers. Poverty and lack of opportunity made the promise of good jobs, the lure of stability, and a chance at more than mere survival seem worth any potential risks.  But your national operatives in India have been vigilant in their investigations. And they’ve been working to build a strong partnership with regional police leadership which is resulting in expeditious o...perations.  Within 17 days, they collected case evidence, and equipped police partners in organizing the raid and rescue.  And they found and freed Ela and Maira!  The women were immediately taken to a safe house to begin assessing their needs.  Their 5 traffickers were stopped and are now in jail.  Lives are being changed, and because of our strategic approach, the business of human trafficking is now even more uncertain in this region.  Thank you for your part in making these rescues and arrests happen. Your national operative teams are highly specialized in their investigative skills, but they can only do this work if they are equipped by people like you who care.  *Names, image, & some details are representational

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: NEW JERSEY - An investigation began when a 17-year-old victim escaped from a hotel where Ashley Gardener, 32, and her co-defendant, 28-year-old Breon Mickens, were forcing her to engage in sex work. When state troopers found her walking along I-295, she told them she was escaping from a hotel where she was forced to perform sex acts. Investigators found out that Gardener and Mickens took the victim to hotels against her will to engage in sexual intercourse with anywhere from four to 15 men each day, all the while being deprived of food, given marijuana to smoke, and prohibited from contacting family.

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: Have you or someone you know made a call on behalf of a victim of human trafficking? We know that calls are being made to the National Human Trafficking Hotline and to 911 and local law enforcement by members of the trucking, bus and energy industries. One of those heroes could be this year's winner of the Harriet Tubman Award presented by Protective Insurance, which includes a $2500 prize and gala weekend at the Indy500! Is it someone in your company? Is it you? Is it someone you've heard about? Nominations will be accepted until April 30: www.truckersagainsttrafficking.org/harriet-tubman-award

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: Let's talk about demand, man to man. A moderated discussion with Alan Smyth, Executive Director of Saving Innocence and Louie Greek, TAT training Specialist.

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: Reminder! Join us TONIGHT at 4pm PT / 7pm ET here on Facebook for our interactive watch party on the demand for commercial sex! We'll watch TAT's Man to Man video on the topic and have a dialogue moderated by TAT Training Specialist Louie Greek and Saving Innocence Executive Director Alan Smyth.  Tune into here on our Facebook page tonight! We hope to see you there!

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: TEXAS - A tip from the National Human Trafficking Hotline in reference to two 16 year old females being commercially sexually exploited was relayed to the Beaumont Police Department, who began investigating and were able to identify the teen victims and locate them. As the Beaumont Police Department said: "We would also like to thank the anonymous citizen who had the courage to submit the information they had about this crime to the National Human Trafficking Hotline, which u...ltimately led to the recovery of two minors and the arrest of a trafficker! Thank you!" Your call can make a difference! US: 1-888-3737-888 Canada: 1-833-900-1010 https://kfdm.com/…/human-trafficking-hotline-leads-to-recov…

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: Polaris has put together a beautiful gallery of survivor perspectives and work. As they put it: "Survivors of sex and labor trafficking are the true experts and the engine of innovation in the anti-human trafficking field. But they are also so much more than that. Some work in the field and some don’t. They are teachers and parents, artists and writers, doctors and lawyers. They are fierce, resilient, talented and diverse." Sean M. Wheeler wrote this poem, originally created ...for Fight the New Drug, about being used in child pornography. It begins:  "Give voice to the words that cannot be spoken. Speak words for the voices that cannot be heard." Read the full poem here:

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: Many traffickers brand their victims with tattoos across their necks, arms, inner thighs, breasts, sometimes even their face or lips. The tattoos take the form of flowers, names, barcodes, and gang affiliations. Some of them say “slut” or “daddy’s girl.” But they all mean the same thing: ownership. Cosmopolitan follows three survivors of human trafficking on their journeys to remove the tattoos used as branding by their traffickers. These women chose not only to share their stories but also to show their faces and tattoos in an effort to raise awareness and advocate for others. Read their stories here:

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: Calling all members of the truck stop and travel plaza industry in the Midwest! Join us on April 7 for a virtual training on the issue of human trafficking and how YOU can play a role in combating human trafficking. The program will include testimony from a survivor of human trafficking, local law enforcement's perspective and ways your location can get involved. This is one the second of four regional virtual trainings TAT has planned for employees, managers, and owners of t...he truck stop and travel plaza industry. The midwest region of the United States includes: ND, SD, NE, KS, MN, OH, MO, WI, IL, IN, and MI. Register here: https://us02web.zoom.us/…/register/WN_fTcjZ3-7Sr-vUN6iEN6NrQ

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: KENTUCKY - In September 2020, a federal jury convicted Prince Bixler of 15 federal felonies related to his extensive and violent sex and drug trafficking operation that forced young, drug-addicted women into prostitution and to sell drugs throughout the Lexington area.  Evidence presented at trial, including the testimony of three victims, established that defendant Prince Bixler compelled three victims into prostitution between 2013 and March 2018 by physically assaulting them and others to create a climate of fear and intimidation. He exploited their drug dependence, using it to worsen their addictions and to keep them around him.

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: Happy #TruckerTuesday to all! Keep on trucking!

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: "Data shows that the vast majority of trafficking victims identified in the United States are people who have historically faced discrimination and its political, social and economic consequences: People of color, indigenous communities, immigrants and people who identify as LGBTQ+ are disproportionately victimized. People living in poverty, or foster care, or are struggling with addiction, trauma, abuse or unstable housing, are all at comparatively higher risk for traffickin...g.   What ties all these disparate groups of people and experiences together is that there is something they need, sometimes desperately. Survivors have taught us that traffickers expertly seek out people whose specific need they can fill – or pretend to fill... Preventing human trafficking at the scale of the problem means changing the underlying systems – the inequities and injustices we mentioned above – that make people vulnerable and therefore make trafficking possible."

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: March 16 is the 5th annual #MyFreedomDay, a student-led and social media driven event to raise awareness of modern-day slavery. The annual event asks individuals and organizations: “What are you doing to help end slavery?” Whether it's getting trained to recognize the signs, implementing actions to be a responsible consumer, spreading awareness of slavery in supply chains, or putting a TAT decal on your truck, we all can play a role in combating human trafficking. Share your ...answer with us in the comments! You can learn more about human trafficking and #MyFreedomDay here: CNN.com/MyFreedomDay

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: TAT's message is clear!  By federal law, if you see anyone underage being prostituted, they are a victim of human trafficking. In addition, any evidence of pimp control, no matter the age of the prostituted person, is human trafficking. Make the call, save lives!... US: 1-888-3737-888 Canada: 1-833-900-1010

name: Truckers Against Trafficking
content: NEW YORK - A New Jersey man used death threats and beatings to force five young women and teenage girls into prostitution in New York City. Akin “Damion” Martin, 28, found girls for his sex trafficking scheme online and then coerced them into prostitution at hotels throughout the city over a two-year period. After coercing the women, Martin stole their passports and other documents. He pocketed a total of more than $50,000 from the victims, often beating them if they refused to hand over money. In January, he threatened to shoot and kill a woman from the Bronx if she reported him to the NYPD. He was arrested Feb. 25 after the terrified woman went to authorities.

name: United Abolitionists
content: Happy Birthday to our fearless leader, founder of Florida Abolitionist, now United Abolitionists, Tomas J Lares.  Tomas is also the co-founder of the Greater Orlando Human Trafficking Task Force and has been a leader in the anti-Human Trafficking effort in Florida for over 15 years.  He’s worked tirelessly since 2009 at addressing the crimes “in our own backyard” by training first responders in our community - including law enforcement. For years he advocated to Orange County... that a shelter for adult females was desperately needed. Since its opening in January of 2018 the UA hotline has triaged hundreds of calls from the greater Orlando area with 65 percent of them being referred to that shelter.  Today, on his birthday, let’s celebrate his gift of the fight. Tomas will never tire and will never stop fighting for others. He gives so much of himself and deserves recognition every day, but especially today on his birthday. 💕🙌🏼🎂🎈

name: United Abolitionists
content: Happy President's Day! The right of every person to be free is both fundamental and universal. Former U.S. President John Quincy Adams understood this. He knew slavery was immoral and fought throughout his career to advance universal freedom. His advocacy helped lay the groundwork for the abolition movement. Though he was president from 1825-1829, John Quincy Adams became known for his passionate anti-slavery advocacy in Congress. Amid his campaigns to end slavery, he also petitioned Congress to provide land for displaced Native Americans. #HistoryMatters #Abolitionists

Women who live transformed lives can transform the lives around them. ❤️ #FemaleEmpowerment #EmpoweringWoman #FemaleLeadership #Woman #FemaleEntrepreneurship #motivation

name: Unlikely Heroes
content: Her name is Sarah* and she just celebrated her 15th birthday! 🎉 For Sarah, this birthday is especially MONUMENTAL.  Trafficked at just 8-years-old, Sarah was beaten and sold for years. She rarely had a safe place to sleep at night and was not allowed to attend school. Celebrating birthdays and holidays were non-existent for her - until now! For her birthday, Sarah picked out a beautiful gown and even had her hair done to celebrate! 🥰 We are overjoyed to share her story with y...ou.  The journey to healing is hard but these special moments give our kids the strength to keep moving forward!  #yourloveisheroic #freedom #quinciñera #hope #unlikelyheroes *names and details have been changed for security and privacy of the survivor

name: Unlikely Heroes
content: From his epic role as Dr Martin Luther King Jr in the movie “Selma”, he brought to light some of the most historical moments in our nation that have resulted in vital conversations about race inequality, and social justice. Across the board, Golden Globe nominated David Oyelowo has given his voice for change.  We’ve been honored to experience David’s commitment for social justice both on and off the stage. A long time supporter of Unlikely Heroes, David and his wife Jessica h...ave hosted our children in their home, spent holidays and late nights sharing stories and getting to know our girls in ways that few have taken the time to truly do.  David and his family use their voice for freedom. We are grateful for their heroic love and we love to celebrate people who make this world a better place! 🤗 #yourloveisheroic #together #love #blackhistorymonth #davidoyelowo #freedom

name: Unlikely Heroes
content: Did 2020 catch you by surprise??  Last year was hard for us all but we are looking forward to a brand new year with some great tools to conquer 2021. This TEDx talk from our CEO & Founder, Erica Greve, talks about her years of research watching kids change their lives through resiliency. They are not just merely surviving, but thriving! Erica teaches us how to learn from their resiliency and implement these skills into own our lives. It’s the perfect TEDx for 2021!  💫💫🙌🏻 Watch the full video in link below.  #bebetter #resilience #tedx #nonprofit #enditmovement #humantraffickingawareness #endchildslavery #childtherapy #parentingteens #parentingadvice #instachallenges

name: Unlikely Heroes
content: Her name is Kaya*, and after enduring 3 terrible years of exploitation, she’s finally safe. Trafficked from the young age of 6, we are so grateful for her freedom and that we can finally say welcome home sweet one, you are safe now!!  Kaya was brought to our home by the Prosecutor’s Office that specializes in high impact crimes. Unfortunately, Kaya's trafficker did not allow her to attend school, so she only tests at a 2nd-grade level. Our dedicated education team will work w...ith Kaya to get her caught up, and get the educational support she needs to become a confident, star student!  We can already tell that Kaya is a fighter and we can already see that her resilient nature is going to carry her through the challenging seasons of healing she faces in the coming days. Let’s celebrate Kaya’s recovery together. She finally has a future that will be marked with freedom. 💖 *Names and details have been changed for the privacy and security of the survivor. No identifiable images are of children known to be exploited.

She is courageous.  She is a survivor. ... She is an unlikely hero.   And her name is Evie. Thank you for making Evie’s story possible. Thank you for standing with us to end human trafficking.

name: Unseen
content: Today in Unseen’s #NamesToKnow, we’re featuring Amy Smith, the co-founder and Executive Director of Unseen Partner, Fortify Rights. Amy is a force to be reckoned with, and a mighty advocate in the movement to ensure human rights for all. She previously worked with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Regional Office for Southeast Asia, Secretariat of Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, the Chin Human Rights Organization, and Refugee and Immigrant Center for Education and Legal Services (RAICES). She is a licensed U.S. attorney with a J.D. from Northeastern University School of Law and a B.S. from Northeastern University in the U.S. Amy is currently a vocal advocate with Fortify Rights as they stand against the military coup in #Myanmar. Read one of their latest press releases at the link in bio.

name: Unseen
content: An important part of the anti-trafficking solution that doesn’t always get the spotlight is aftercare. In the aftermath of a trafficking situation, there are still years of healing and care that are crucial to restoring an individual’s sense of dignity and respect. Unseen Partner, Willow International, offers an aftercare program that has walked with many trafficking survivors through the journey of healing and restoration—and in today’s #StoryofHope, we see how that changed ...the life of a woman named Ellen*. Ellen traveled to China in 2012 with plans to work in a hair salon. However, when she arrived, traffickers forced Ellen onto the streets to sell her body. They demanded that she smuggle drugs in Macau in order to pay off a never-ending debt. Ellen endured a life of exploitation for over a year before she was arrested by Chinese authorities for overstaying her visa. She was imprisoned for six years and gave birth to her first child while incarcerated. And yet, from the darkness of a Chinese prison cell, Ellen held onto hope. After serving her sentence, Ellen returned home to Uganda and joined an aftercare program with Unseen Partner, Willow International. The aftercare program helped Ellen heal from years of trauma. Through the program, Ellen restored her independence and completed a vocational education in Interior Design and Decorating. Today, Ellen is the proud owner of a wedding decorating business and works as a part-time mentor to the girls in Willow’s aftercare homes. Her joy, her strength, and her commitment to fostering growth in others provide light to everyone she meets. Ellen has shared that she hopes to expand her business in the coming years. And of course, she will continue helping other survivors practice self-love and find peace in the knowledge that there are people out there fighting for those who have yet to be rescued. *Names and photos changed to protect Ellen's privacy. #antitrafficking #traffickingsurvivor #weareunseen

name: Unseen
content: Myth or Fact? There are many misconceptions when it comes to sex trafficking. Here's the reality. Sex trafficking can look different in various areas of the world. From illicit massage parlors, to red light districts, to online sexual exploitation—they’re all forms of sex trafficking. It’s a lucrative business where exploiters earn up to 1000x profit from a single victim. Sex trafficking alone accounts for ⅔ (or $99 billion) of the total $150 billion human trafficking industr...y. In our upcoming newsletter, we’ll be breaking down more myths and facts about the industry, as well as highlight Unseen partners who work with survivors of sex trafficking. Our goal with our newsletter is to equip anti-trafficking advocates like you with helpful information, so we can all work together to #endhumantrafficking. Sign up here: https://www.weareunseen.org/get-email-updates

name: Unseen
content: Today Unseen’s #NamesToKnow is the incredible Boom Mosby, the Founder and Director of HUG Project, an Unseen partner in Thailand. HUG specifically focuses on ending the sexual exploitation and abuse of children. They’ve supported over 300 investigations and cared for 150+ child survivors. Mosby was named a TIP (Trafficking In Persons) Report Hero by the US Department of State in 2017.  “At the end of the day, survivors care about who is willing to walk with them through each situation and who is still standing with them when it’s over. Child victims need unconditional love and healthy attachment. They want to know and trust that we will always be there for them.” - Boom Mosby #endhumantrafficking #weareunseen #antitrafficking

name: Unseen
content: We’d like to share an important resource for every anti-trafficking advocate: the Global Report on Trafficking In Persons. The recently released 2020 report is the fifth global report by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC). It draws on data from 148 countries, and explores issues such as the impact of the pandemic and traffickers’ use of the internet. “In order to act, we need to understand better the factors that facilitate human trafficking,” writes Ghada W...aly, Executive Director of the UNODC. “By bringing visibility to this crime, and shedding light on trafficking patterns and flows, this report can assist...in developing solutions capable of addressing root causes and risk factors.” She continues, saying, “We cannot allow the pandemic recession to reverse this progress or put more women, men and children in danger of being trafficked.” We’ll be breaking down information from this report in posts to come, as well as in our newsletter (sign up at weareunseen.org/get-email-updates). We encourage you to take a look, here: https://www.unodc.org/…/…/tip/2021/GLOTiP_2020_15jan_web.pdf #antitrafficking #endhumantrafficking #GlobalTIPReport #weareunseen

name: Unseen
content: Today, on International Women’s Day, we celebrate the women around the world who are fighting to end human trafficking and its root causes. We are proud to work with many incredible female leaders, and will be featuring some of them throughout this month. To all the women who advocate for freedom — today we celebrate you! - Photo is of Amy Churchill, co-founder at Just One Africa, an Unseen partner that collaborates with Kenyan leaders to bring clean water and sustainability ...to the region. #womensday #internationalwomensday

content: “It takes great courage to open one's heart and mind to the tremendous injustice and suffering in our world." Vincent A. Gallagher, "The True Cost of Low Prices: The Violence of Globalization"

name: Unseen
content: Recently, we shared reports from the United Nations about increased child labor trafficking due to COVID-19 school closures. Today, our #StoryofHope is about a child who fell victim to these circumstances—Asif. 12-year-old Asif dropped out of school a few weeks after India went into a nationwide lockdown. By April, his parents could only afford two meals a day and were getting desperate. When a person in their village offered Asif a job in Delhi with decent pay and suitable l...iving conditions, Asif’s parents agreed he should take the offer. So, Asif and four other boys made the day-long journey to Delhi. But when they arrived, the job was far from what was promised. The boys were put to work in a congested room for nearly 12 hours a day, cutting, stitching, and packaging leather gloves. They were not paid for their labor, and they were fed one meal a day. Asif was never allowed to leave the building, speak with his parents, or interact with outsiders. This continued until January 14, 2021. Unseen Partner, Justice Ventures International (JVI), along with their partner NGO, aided the local administration in a child labor rescue intervention.  Asif and four other minors were successfully removed from the facility, and the building was shut down. The employer is currently being prosecuted with the assistance of JVI lawyers. Asif was given medical care, and is now in a children’s home where he is receiving aftercare support. JVI and its partners in Bihar are working to establish contact with Asif’s parents to ensure they are reunited as a family once again. Photos courtesy of JVI.

She felt a tugging on her heart to work within the anti-trafficking movement, and found Unseen at the perfect time. Other cool Hailey facts: she’s lived and worked in Nepal, she loves spicy food, her favorite movie is Sound of Music, and her favorite recent read is “Chasing the Dragon” by Jackie Pullinger. We’re so grateful to have Hailey as part of the team! You can get to know Hailey more, here: https://www.weareunseen.org/team/hailey-brenden

name: Unseen
content: #StoryofHope: Aran’s Story Aran was a good student and friendly with his peers at school. Like most teenagers, Aran spends a lot of time on his phone and chatting with friends on social media. Over the course of a few months, Aran’s parents noticed his attitude changing at home. He became distant and his grades began to suffer.  Aran was ashamed to tell his parents that someone he met online and trusted had been forcing him to send sexual photos. A college student pretending to be a girl who was interested in Aran convinced him to have an online relationship with “her.” The abuser then threatened to expose Aran’s photos to friends and family if he did not continue to engage. Aran felt trapped. But one day, he summoned up the courage to finally tell his parents what was happening. Read the rest of Aran’s Story, here. https://www.weareunseen.org/blog/arans-story

name: Unseen
content: What is happening in Myanmar? On Monday, thousands of Myanmarese—doctors, supermarket cashiers, bubble tea servers, civil workers—declared a general strike and poured into the streets. They held signs reading, “We don’t accept military coup” and “Respect our votes.” Many were seen lifting three fingers in the air—a symbol of solidarity and resistance against oppression (a symbol that has now been banned). Protests have been growing across Myanmar since February 1, when a mili...tary coup seized power from the elected government. Top elected leaders such as Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, former State Counsellor and head of the National League for Democracy (NLD), were dragged off by soldiers and imprisoned. But, why? “The grievances which have been driving tension between the military and the government are well enough known,” said Jonathan Head, BBC’s South Asia Correspondent. “The military-backed party, the USDP, performed poorly in last November's general election, whereas the NLD did even better than in 2015.” The coup took place during the first week of parliament, which is no longer happening. Instead, nightly curfews are in place, international and domestic TV channels are off the air, and banks said they were forced to close. The United Nations, the United States, and the UK have condemned the military coup. Unseen partner, Fortify Rights, has people on the ground in Myanmar and is also calling for Myanmar to reverse the coup. “This violent crackdown must end now,” said Matthew Smith, Chief Executive Officer of Fortify Rights. “The people of Myanmar are exercising their rights, and the military junta should heed their calls and immediately reverse this coup.” Fortify Rights’ mission is to defend and ensure human rights for all. They join us in the global movement to ensure lives of freedom and dignity for every person—a world where there is no place for oppressive forces like human trafficking and military dictatorship. Follow Fortify Rights to learn more about the situation in Myanmar. Learn more here: https://www.fortifyrights.org/mya-inv-2021-02-10/ Photo credit: Aung Naing Soe, 2021 and Fortify Rights #WhatIsHappeninginMyanmar

name: Unseen
content: Unseen’s #NamesToKnow today is Roseline Eguabor. Roseline is an anti-trafficking advocate based in Italy, where she helps Nigerian and West African human trafficking victims leave trafficking situations and integrate into Italian society. Roseline works with the International Organization for Migration to bring a victim-centered approach to human trafficking screening, identification, and protection protocals on a global scale. “Inequality in the world is the major bane of hu...man trafficking, a phenomenon that we all must stand against in order to liberate victims.” — Roseline Eguabor Roseline was named a TIP (Trafficking In Persons) Hero in 2019. Read more about Roseline’s work here: http://www.tipheroes.org/roseline-eguabor/ #NamesToKnow #antitrafficking #weareunseen

name: Unseen
content: Today is World Social Justice Day, and the United Nations has announced the 2021 theme: “A Call for Social Justice in a Digital Economy.” In light of 2020 and the COVID-19 pandemic, the digital divide has become even more apparent, they write. “The crisis has laid bare and exacerbated the growing digital divide within, between and across developed and developing countries, particularly in terms of the availability, affordability and...access to the internet, deepening existin...g inequalities.” While digital work has allowed for more access to jobs, the UN notes that it also brings challenges around income, right to fair working conditions and social protection, for example.  This is why this year’s commemoration “...aims at fostering dialogue... on actions needed to overcome the digital divide, provide decent work opportunities, and protect labor and human rights in the modern era of digital technologies.” Read the full statement and history on World Social Justice Day, here: https://www.un.org/en/observances/social-justice-day #WorldSocialJusticeDay #weareunseen

name: Unseen
content: It’s Random Acts of Kindness day! ✨ A simple day, but a sweet one; a reminder to do something special for someone else. At Unseen, we do our best to share the somber reality of human trafficking with you. However, we know it’s also important to balance this with reminders of the goodness of people.  Today is a day to celebrate this—to look for little ways we can bring hope and a smile to each other. Maybe it’s bringing a blanket to someone who is in the cold, gathering your c...anned goods and donating them to a local shelter, or calling someone you haven’t talked to in a while to say, "Hello!" Share your random act of kindness with us! 👇🏼 #RandomActsOfKindnessDay #RandomActsOfKindness

name: Unseen
content: As school closures due to COVID-19 continue across the world, trafficking among children is on the rise, the United Nations reported this month. “It is particularly alarming that in recent years more and more children are being targeted by traffickers," UNODC Executive Director Ghada Waly said during a virtual briefing. “Youth who are denied their right to education will particularly find themselves easier prey for traffickers.” While worsening poverty and job losses spurred ...by COVID-19 have left millions of people globally at risk of trafficking, out-of-school children are especially vulnerable, according to UNODC. An estimated 25 million people worldwide are victims of labor and sex trafficking, UNODC reports. As the pandemic continues to slow down support services and efforts to secure justice, concerns are growing that even more will be affected. Last month, the United Nations launched the International Year for the Elimination of Child Labor. Their goal is to end the practice of child labour by 2025—although urgent action is needed, they said, as the pandemic is threatening decades of progress. Reach the whole article from Thomson Reuters Foundation here: https://tmsnrt.rs/2OyBLfe #endhumantrafficking #weareunseen #antitrafficking

name: Unseen

You made an incredible impact yesterday. ❤️  Because of your gifts, more men, women, and children will be rescued out of human trafficking—bringing us one step closer to a world where human trafficking is no more, and all people can live lives of freedom and dignity. Thank you! #givingheartsday #HelpSomeone

name: ZOE International
content: In Japan, you can scroll through your phone and select a girl to be delivered to your place in less than an hour. Pornographic sites are just a click away, easy even for a child to access. Sex has become such an accessible, disposable product in the culture. Like fast food, it’s ready for you as soon as you crave it. Such disposable consumption makes us grow numb to true satisfaction. In the process of numbing our consciences to the sacredness of human life and sex, human tra...fficking begins to creep into our society. There are sex traffickers who dare to think that they are “helping” their victims by providing a job. There are even pedophiles who believe that they are “educating” children when they are horrifically abusing them. A person does not become a sex trafficker overnight. It is through the process of devaluing human life and the impact of sex that lead to exploitation of others for selfish gains. As long as society makes sex a convenient disposable product, vulnerable people and children will be objectified for exploitation and human trafficking will continue. We must emphasize the importance of teaching the youth about their true value and the psychological, physical, spiritual impact of sex. Because once boundaries are violated, it doesn’t stop. Sex is not a vending machine product that we purchase and dispose of on our way through life. It is God’s beautiful design, meant to be cherished, protected, and sacredly valued. This is an extremely important and urgent subject to teach, especially to young generations, to prevent them from becoming a victim or perpetrator. At ZOE Japan, we have the opportunity to share love and true satisfaction through Jesus Christ, shedding light that instant gratification will never fully satisfy our soul.  #humantrafficking #nonprofit #endit #childtrafficking #awareness #education #girlpower #stoptrafficking #advocacy #movingforward #selflove #justice #love #inspiring #changealife #nevergiveup #empowerothers #bethechange

name: ZOE International
content: Many people wonder: "How do people becoming victims of human trafficking?" Common ways victims are forced, tricked, threatened, or lured into trafficking are (in no specific order): False Job Advertisement False romantic relationship False Immigration... Peer recruitment Trafficked by "friend" Abduction Sold By Family Please pay attention to these red flags. Make sure your friends, family, and children know this information by sharing or tagging them in this post.  #humantrafficking #sextrafficking #humantraffickingawareness #endhumantrafficking #childtrafficking  #humanrights  #enditmovement #endit #trafficking #childsextrafficking #childabuse #slavery #survivors #stophumantrafficking #freedom #love #modernslavery #endtrafficking

name: ZOE International
content: Last Year, the ZOE Thailand team reached over 17,000 people with education about human trafficking to raise awareness, prevent trafficking, and identify victims.  Even with COVID restrictions and following safety protocols, we continue to push forward because trafficking hasn't stopped during the pandemic. We stay focused on our mission to #endchildtrafficking.

name: ZOE International
content: Seven people were arrested in connection with operating an extensive sex and labor trafficking ring out of massage parlor and skin care businesses in three Southern California counties - Ventura, Riverside, and San Bernardino. The businesses were owned and operated by a family targeting women from Mexico to work in these businesses, some of whom were living in Southern California on refugee visas. Once these women were recruited, sex advertisements were placed on various internet sites to sell them. https://ktla.com/…/7-arrested-in-connection-with-operatin…/…

name: ZOE International
content: "Who will rise up for me against the wicked? Who will take a stand for me against evildoers?" Psalm 94:16. ZOE International is dedicated to standing up against the evil of human trafficking, and we will not stop until we #endit.

name: ZOE International
content: Japan is known for its hardworking culture. Fathers are often working excessively to provide for their family and live up to society’s expectations. There is even a term karoshi which means to literally work yourself to death.  This can lead to children often growing up without many opportunities to see or build close relationships with their fathers. Many young boys don’t have a role model to teach them to value and honor women. Instead, they might consume whatever the media... feeds them. Many young girls learn about life – and love – from friends, movies, or online. In addition, culturally, these topics are not openly discussed between parent and child. To fill the emotional void, children often turn to a popular networking app where they can interact with randomly selected strangers, ignorant of the danger of traffickers just waiting to take advantage of their vulnerability. What starts as a seemingly innocent online friendship soon leads to a face-to-face meeting with the trafficker during which the child is sexually abused. Photos and video footage taken during the abuse become key weapons that the trafficker uses to instill fear and force the child into further submission and continued abuse. Due to shame, fear, and not having a family dynamic where these types of concerns can openly be discussed, children find themselves alone and not knowing who to turn to for help. #endhumantrafficking #endit #zoe #zoeinternational #endslavery #advocacy #nonprofit #ministry #passion #compassion #life #love #outreach #losangeleslove #lanonprofit #localsupport

name: ZOE International
content: One of our ZOE children was getting ready to leave ZOE and attend a university. He was in the process of packing up his things and going to his new dorm room.⁠ ⁠ However, before leaving, he wanted to say goodbye to all the staff, children and missionaries.⁠ ⁠ As he said his goodbyes, he started to tell Carol Hart, our founder, what ZOE meant to him. He said, “ZOE has given me a lot of opportunities…. a good education, a place to stay, good food, safe and a environment.” This ...was all very important to him, but in his wildest dreams, he never thought that ZOE could ever give him something that he thought was impossible to have.⁠ ⁠ He said, “ZOE gave me a mom and dad.” He began to weep uncontrollably as he said this in front of his ZOE mother and began to hug her. He never thought as an orphan, he could have a mom and dad. Today, he still calls these ZOE parents his mom and dad.
